Ellis preferred ὡς ἔρωτ᾿ ἄγειν, ‘for estimating love.’ It is curious that there should be a reference to Ἔρως in the immediate context of both authors who cite the fragment, since Sophocles appears only to have been concerned with the inexorability of Death. H. further notices that the phrase ποιεῖν τὸ προσταττόμενον (τὰ προσταττόνενα) is also to be found in both. Whatever may be the relation of Clement to Plutarch, if we suppose that their similarity is other than accidental, I should in any case hold that, so far as the text of Sophocles is concerned, the words ὡς Ἔρωτα have displaced the original script, and are to be attributed to a commentator who thought fit to compare the inflexible power of Love with that of Death, and had in view such passages as Ant. 781 ff., Track. 441 ff., Soph. fr. 684. That such is the way of scholiasts hardly needs proof: a typical instance maybe read in the scholia on Track. 460. The conjectures mentioned above are based on the assumption that ὡς ἔρωτα is a mutilation of the original; but, if the view I have advocated is correct, it is idle to guess at the lost words. Tucker, following the same idea that occurred to J., proposed πρὸς δ’ οἶον εἴξει δαιμόνων Ἔρωτά τι. But, if Plutarch really intended to adduce the authority of Sophocles for the purpose supposed, is it likely that he would omit the verse which contained the pith of his statement?

2 f. τοὐπιεικές is contrasted with τὴν ἁπλῶς δίκην, much as we oppose ‘ equity ’ — in the non-technical sense—to the ‘rigour of the ’ J. quotes Arist. eth. N. 5. 14. 1137b II τὸ ἐπιεικὲς δίκαιον μέν ἐστιν, οὐ κατὰ νόμον δέ, ἀλλ᾿ ἐπανόρθωμα νομίμου δικαίου. See also his n. on Ο. C. 1127 Cf. Eur. fr. 645: if the gods show mercy in certain cases, ἤτἄρα θνητῶν εἰσιν ἀσυνετώτεροι, | ἢ τἀπιεικῆ πρόσθεν ἡγοῦνται δίκης. Valckenaer (diatr. p. 188) gave a good illustration from Plutarch’s description of the younger Cato, who, following the Stoic pattern of the wise man (Chrysipp. II 640 Arn.), refused to deviate from the strictest norm of Justice: διαφόρως τοῦ καλοῦ τὸ περὶ τὴν δικαιοσύνην ἀτενὲς καὶ ἄκαμπτον εἰς ἐπιείκειαν ἢ χάριν ὑπερηγαπηκώς (Plut. Cat. mi. 4).

lg.l: σκαιοῖς δὲ φαῦλον κἀν βραχεῖ διδάσκαλον.

div.p: 771 Clem. Alex, strom. 5 p. 659 Σοφοκλῆς ὁ τῆς τραγῳδίας ποιητής φησί που ῾καὶ τὸν . . . διδάσκαλον,᾿ τὸ φαῦλον ἐτὶ τοῦ ἁπλοῦ τάσσων: vv. 2 and 3 are also quoted by Plut. de Pyth. or. 25 p. 406 F εὖ γὰρ εἰδέναι χρὴ τὸν θεόν, ὥς φησι Σοφοκλῆς, ῾σοφοῖς. . . διδάσκαλον.᾿

The fragment is variously interpreted.
Brunck remarked: ῾ aeque aeque vera videretur sententia, si duabus transpositis vocibus legeretur: σκαιοῖς μὲν αἰνικτῆρα . . . σοφοῖς δὲ φαῦλον κτἑ Sed alteram tuetur auctoritas librorum. In his nihil decerni potest, quuni ignoretur a qua persona et qua occasione sententia recitata fuerit.’ It is plain that he had no clear conception of the meaning. There is little profit to be had from the older versions, and C. W. ’s rendering of the third line — ‘ to fools a bad instructor even in trifles ’—is certainly wrong. J.'s runs as follows: ῾ σοφοῖς . . . σκαιοῖς: cp. Eur. El. 972 ὅπου δ᾿ Ἀπόλλων σκαιὸς ᾖ, τίνες σοφοί; (“foolish ”—“wise”). By αἰνικτῆρα θεσφάτων it is implied that the god wishes to exercise the understanding of the “ wise, ” and to give them subtler or deeper lessons than suit the σκαιό—not that he wishes to keep them in the dark φαῦλον= ἁπλοῦν to Clement), “ simple ” : that is, he speaks in the language of φαῦλοι, the common sort, to those who can understand nothing more subtle: Eur. Hipp. 988 οἰ γὰρ σοφοῖς | φαῦλοι παρ᾿ ὄχλῳ μουσικώτεροι λέγειν. So Thuc. 3. 37. 3 ὁ φαυλότεροι πρὸς τοὺς ξυνετωτέρους.᾿ J. evidently thought that the verses express the char- acter ὁ purpose of Apollo, that he chooses to be enigmatical to the wise, but straight- forward to the foolish. I agree, however, with H. (Proc. Camb. Phil. Soc. 1907 p. 17) that both σοφοῖς and σκαιοῖς are to be taken as datives iudicantis—a which seems to have been anticipated by Ellendt, who remarks: ’deum dicit sapientibus obscura et ambigua, stultis intellectu facilia portendere uideri.’ points out that the interpretation adopted by J. cannot be reconciled with the meaning either of σκαιοῖς or of φαῦλον: thus φαῦλος does not mean ’simple’ in the sense of clear, lucid (τορός), or and σκαιός, when used in a moral sense, always implies moral obli- quity, i.e. it is equivalent to ’perverse’ or ’ ’ He quotes Aesch. Prom. 637 λέξω τορῶς σοι . . . οὐκ ἐμπλέκων αἰνίγματ᾿ ἀλλ᾿ ἁπλῷ λόγω, Suppl. 473 αἰνιγματῶδες τοὔτος· ἀλλ᾿ ἁπλῶς φράσον, adding that the contrast is different here where φαῦλος and not ἁπλοῦς is used. n. renders accordingly: ῾ to the wise a hinter of deep meaning oracles, but in the eyes of the perversely stupid only a poor and meagre teacher.’ I doubt this gives the tone of the last line. The wise view the god as αἰνικτήρ, and seek for an interpretation; the fool regards only the surface meaning. The attitude of the σκαιοί, who think that they understand the oracle but do not, is admirably illustrated in Dio Chrys. 10. 32. The clown (for σκαιός see on Eur. Ηclid. 458, and Starkie on. Vesp. 1183) thinks there is nothing to understand; Apollo is a plain person, of few words — like himself; an expounder in brief, μὴ ἐν πολλοῖς ὀλίγα λέγων ἀλλ’ ἐν ὀλίγοις πολλά, as Pythagoras recommended; no longwinded sophist, such as Protagoras, with his μακρολογία. (The difficulties of brevity the σκαιός does not realize: σοφοῦ πρὸς ἀνδρὸς ὅστις ἐν βραχεῖ | πολλοὺς καλῶς οἷός τε συντέμνειν λόγους Eur. fr. 28.) ἁπλοῦς ὁ μῦθος τῆς ἀληθείας ἔφυ (Eur. Phoen. 469) is the creed of the ordinary person φαῦλος). Subtilty or elaboration, the refinements (ἀκριβεια) of the philosopher or the smoothness of. the rhetorician, he treats with equal —ταῦτ᾿ ταῦτ᾿ αὔθ᾿ ἕκαστα, μῆτερ, οὐχὶ περιπλοκὰς | λόγων ἀθροίσας εἶπον, ἀλλὰ καὶ σοφοῖς | καὶ τοῖσι φαύλοις ἔνδικα (ib. 494 ff.). Just what Mark Antony feigned to be, ‘ a plain blunt ’ who ’speaks right ’ that Heracles really was: Eur. fr. 473 φαῦλον ἄκομψον, τὰ μέγιστ’ ἀγαθόν, | πᾶσαν ἐνἔργῳ περιτεμνόμενον | σοφίαν, λέσχης ἀτρίβωνα. φαῦλος was a word of censure, which those at whom it was aimed somewhat contemptuously accepted: so it is applied by Cleon in Thuc l.c., by Eur. Bacch. 431 Ion 834, and elsewhere. Hence φαυλότης is the condition of the ordinary person, ’the man in the street, ’ who has no technical skill: Eur. fr. 635 οἱ rds rixvas δ’ ἔχοντες ἀθλιώτεροι | τῆς φαυλότητος, fr. 641 ἐν τῷ γὰρ ὄλβῳ φαυλότης ἔνεστί τις, | πενία δὲ σοφίαν ἔλαχε διὰ τὸ συγγενές. See also Plat. legg. 966 E ὁ γὰρ ἰδὼςν ταῦτα μὴ φαύλως μηδ᾿ ἰδιωτικῶς—he who has looked upon Nature scientifically never becomes dtieos. But the best illustration of all is in Plat. Phaed. 69 c κινδυνεύουσι καὶ οἱ τὰς τελετὰς ἡμῖν οὗτοι καταστήσαντες οὐ φαῦλοι εἶναι ἀλλὰ τῷ ὄντι πάλαι αἰνίττεσθαι ὅτι κτἑ., where Jowett's ‘ triflers ’ triflers ’ scarcely renders point: the contrast is rather between the letter and the sptrii (πολλοὶ ναρθηκοφόροι βάκχοι δέ τε παῦροι). Eur. fr. 162 κἂν φαῦλος ᾖ | τἄλλ’ εἰς ἔρωτα πᾶς ἀνὴρ σοφώτατος. It is not easy to say whether φαῦλον should stand alone, as I should on the whole prefer, or whether, like ἐν βραχεῖ, it is an attribute
of διδάσκαλον. For the prepositional phrase qualifying the noun see Εl. 61 Eur. Hel. 1071 etc. — H. pointed out that τοιοῦτον in V. I may refer either to the following explanation, or to something that has gone before, as= ‘ of the like nature.’ Jebb on Ο. T. 435 supported latter alternative. ’s conjecture ὄντ᾿ ἐπίσταμαι is mistaken: for the οmission of the supplementary participle see on fr. 108. ’s κἂν βράχῃ—῾ even though he roar ’—id perhaps worth recording as a curiosity. — For the riddles of the Delphic oracle cf. Aesch. Ag. 1254 Kal γὰρ τὰ πυθόκραντα (sc. are in Greek) δυσμαθῆ δ᾿ ὅμως. Eur. Suppl. 138 Φοίβου μ’ ὑπῆλθε δυστόπαστ᾿ αἰνίγματα. Heraclitus fr. 93 D. ὁ ἄναξ οὗ τὸ μαντεῖόν ἐστι τὸ ἐν Δελφοῖς οὔτε λέγει οὔτε κρύπτει ἀλλὰσημαίνει. There is a similar — but political —contrast in Theogn. 681 f. ταῦτάμοι ᾐνίχθω κεκρυμμένα τοῖς ἀγαθοῖσι· | γινώσκοι δ᾿ ἄν τις καὶ κακός, ἂν σοφὸς ᾖ.
τόθ᾿ ηὗ]ρον ἐς πόσ[ιν] ῥυτόν σίκιννι]ν

772 Demetr. Lacon in Here. pap. 1012 col. 39 ὁ Σοφοκλῆς ἔγραψεν οὕτως· ῾ τόθ᾿ . . . σίκιννιν.᾿ Such is the restoration of Diels in Sitzungsb. d. Berl. Akad. 1897, 1073 of a very fragmentary original. His view has since been supported by Cronert, Kolotes u. Menedemos, p. 120 ff.
The words must have been taken from a satyr-play. For ῥυτόν, said to be a variety of κέρας, see Athen. 496 F — 497 E. σίκιννις (or σίκινις) was the ’ dance: cf. Eur. Cycl. 37.
Θήβας λέγεις μοι καὶ πύλας ἑπταστόμους, οὗ δὴ μόνον τίκτουσιν αἱ θνηταὶ θεούς.

773 Pseudo-Dicaearch. descript. Graec. fr. 59. 17 (Mueller, GGM 1 103 FHG II 259) αἱ δὲ γυναῖκες αὐτῶν τοῖς μεγέθεσι, πορείαις, ῥυθμοῖς εὐσχημονέσταταί τε Καὶ εὐπρεπέσταται τῶν ἐν τῇ Ἑλλάδ γυναικῶν. μαρτυρεῖ Σοφοκλῆς ῾ Θήβας . . . θεούς.᾿ This is an extract from an extremely interesting description of Thebes included in one of three prose fragments of a treatise on Greek geography, which are contained in two Paris MSS of the 12th and 15th centuries (gr. suppl. no. 443 and gr. 571) and wrongly attributed to Dicaearchus. Mueller (FHG 11 232) was able to show from Apollonius the Paradoxographer (mir. hist. 19) that they were actually written by Heraclides ὁ κριτκός, who lived in the 3rd century B.C. (Schultz in Pauly-Wissowa Vlll 486). The extract relating to Thebes is translated and discussed by Frazer, Pausanias, v p. 27 f.

1 See or. n. There is some error m the tradition, for which Salmasius conjectured τὰς πύλαις ἑπταστόμους, Brunck ταῖς πύλαις ἑπταστόμους, Nauck καὶ πόλισμ᾿ ἑπτάστομον (comparing Eur. Bacch. 919 δισσὰς δὲ Θήβας καὶ πόλισμ᾿ ἑπτάστομον), and Blaydes Θήβης . . . ἑπταστόμου. Headlam ejected πύλας, thinking that something had fallen out between μοι and τὰς: he quotes Anaxandr. fr. 41 20 II 151 K. τοτὲ μὲν Σπάρτην τὴν εὐρύχορον, τοτὲ δ’ αὖ Θήβας τὰς ἑπταπύλους, and Tr. fr. adesp. 177 σὺ δ’ ἀμφὶ Θήβας στεῖχε τὰς Καδμηΐδας. The simplest remedy is merely to substitute καί for τάς; καί, as is well known, often disappears. Ihe converse error occurs in Aesch. fr. 266. 3. Jebb on Ant. 118 understood ’seven-mouthed as to its ’ which is hardly satisfactory: cf. Eur. Suppl. 401.

2 ’The gods whom mortal women bore in Thebes are Dionysus, the son of Zeus by Semele, and Heracles, the
son of Zeus by ’ So H., who compares Find. Νem. 10 10 (of Argos) καὶ γυναιξὶ καλλικόμοισιν ἀριστεύει πάλαι· | Ζεὺς ἐπ᾿ Ἀλκμήναν Δανάαν τε μολὼν ἐτὸν κατέφανε λόγον. Weil (Journ. des Savmits, 1904, p. 570), conjecturing Beds for θεούς in the line as quoted by Dicaearchus, supposed that the text of Sophocles was modified by an admirer of Theban beauty. Stephanus corrected οἱ θνητοὶ θεάς, which he ascribed to Sophocles, and was followed by Bothe.
μύω τέ καὶ δέδορκα κἀξανίσταμαι, πλέον φυλάσσων αὐτὸς ἢ φυλάσσομαι.
774. 1 καὶ ξυνίσταμαι P 2 πλεῖον vulgo edebatur

774 Dion. Hal. de comp. verb. g οἷά ἐστιν ἐν μὲν τοῖς μέτροις τὰ Σοδόκλεια ταυτί· ῾ μύω τε . . . φυλάσσομαι.᾿ Dionysius is discussing under what circumstances a reduction ought to be made in the contents of the kQXu, and suggests that this should be done when any of the words logically necessary are apt to offend the taste of the reader, and when their removal improves the style. He then quotes the present fragment as a case in point, since, if fully expressed, the second line would be ῾ πλέον φυλάσσων αὐτὸς ἑτέρους ἢ φυλασσόμενος ὑφ᾿ ἑτέρων.᾿

1 The words seem to describe the position of one who has been overcome by his enemies, and left by them as if he were senseless or in helpless captivity. Nevertheless he manages, without betraying his activity, to keep watch on tlieir movements in the hope of foiling their plans. For the words μύω τε καὶ δέδορκα, ῾ with half-closed eyes I see,’ see Verrall on Eur. Med. 1183. They are less likely to refer to after-visions or dreams, as in ’s φαίνεται καὶ μύουσιν ὁράματα (de an. 3. 3. 428a 16). For the ironical antithesis cf. Eur. Ale. 521 ἔστιν τε κοὐκέτ᾿ ἔστιν (Hel. 138 n.). Hartung, who is hardly ever at a. loss for a guess, refers the passage to the Inachus, supposing that it describes Argus being lulled to sleep by the incantations of Hermes. Rhys Roberts, comparing Horn. B 24 οὐ χρὴ παννύχιον εὕδειν βουληφόρον ἄνδρα, suggested that the idea might well be that of ’ uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.’ conjectured κλύω for μύω.
2 φυλάσσων . . . φυλάσσομαι : the tables are turned, and the biter is bit. For similar collocations see on fr. 236.
H. renders: ’ I close my eyes and see and rise erect. Myself the watcher rather than the watched.’
775 Elym. Flor. in Miller, Mélanges de litt. gr. p. 32 ἄναξ . . . σημαίνει καὶ τὸν φύλακα, ὡς παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ, οἷον ῾ πύλης ἄναξ θυρωρέ.᾿

This metaphor is condemned by Arist. rhet. 3. 2. 1405a 32, quoting Eur. fr. 705, as ἀπρεπές, ὅτι μεῖζον τὸ ἀνάσσειν ἢ κατ᾿ ἀξίαν. No other example occurs in Sophocles, but ’s note requires to be supplemented by a reference to this passage. Similarly in Aeschylus κώπης ἄναξ (Pers. 381) stands alone; but in Euripides there are several instances, for which see n. οn Hel. 1040. It is probable, however, that ἄναξ originally had a wider meaning than Aristotle contemplated: such at least seems the proper inference from ῾ Ιππῶναξ, χειρῶναξ, etc. See also Blomfield on Aesch. Prom. 45. Wecklein thought that ἄναξ could not have been addressed to an ordinary porter, and inferred that the words were spoken to Cerberus and taken from the Phaedra. The Heracles at Taenarum would be a more likely source (fr. 224); but the suggestion is too fanciful to be approved.
776 καλύπτει καλύψει Plut.) πλευρὰ Pint., Suid., Greg. Cypr., Macar. | νῶτα: ὦτα schol. ΙΙ. | βοός: ἁλός schol. Theocr.

776 Etym. M. p. 26, 16 Ἄθως· ἀκρωτήριον Θρᾴκης. Σοφοκλῆς ῾ Ἄθως . . . βοός.᾿ Schol. Theocr. 7. 76 Σοφοκλῆς ῾ Ἄθως . . . ἁλός.᾿ The line is also quoted by several other authorities as proverbial τὸ τεθρυλημένον ἰαμβεῖον Plut.) without the name of the author: Plut. fac. lun. 22 p. 935 F, schol. LV Horn. Ξ 229 Εustath. II. p. 980, 46, Suid. s.v. Ἄθως, Zonar. s.v. Ἄθως p. 58, Macar. 1. 46 (Paroem. II 139), Greg. Cypr. 1. 70 (ib. I 355), Cramer Anccd. Paris, iv p. 96 18. As regards the reading, we are clearly entitled to prefer that of the authorities who expressly cite Sophocles: Plutarch, for example, who is nominally the earliest, is undoubtedly quoting from memory. The reading ἁλός (adopted by Campbell as well as by Pierson on Moeris p. 268) is given only by schol. Theocr. l.c., and is plainly an oversight, as J. remarks: shortly afterwards in the same scholia the v. is again quoted as Ἄθως καλύπτει πλευρὰ Λημνίας βοός.

Poos is explained as follows by the ancient authorities: (i) Macar. l.c. speaks of τὴν ἐν Λήμνῳ ἐΚ μαρμάρου βοῦν, and similarly Suidas: τὴν βοῦν τὴν ἐν Λήμνῳ λευκοῦ λίθου πεποιημένην. (2) Plut. l.c.: ἐπιβάλλει γὰρ ἡ σκιὰ τοῦ ὄρους ὡς ἔοικε καλκέῳ τινὶ βοιδίῳ, in agreement with Etym. M. (3) Eustath. l.c. merely mentions ἄγαλμα Λημνίας βοός. See further Crusius, Anal. crit. p. 69.

The distance of Athos from the nearest point of Lemnos is about 40 miles, and from Kastro about 44. [Eustath. l.c., who makes it 300 stadia, is approximately correct, and Steph. Byz. p. 36, 9 evidently followed the same tradition: it is absurdly exaggerated by Plut. l.c. as 700 stadia, and by Plin. n. h. 4. 73 (cf. Solin. II. 33) as 87 miles.] The height of Athos is given in the Admiralty Chart as 6348 ft (1935 m.).

The shadow cast by Mt Athos upon Lemnos is also alluded to by (i) Apoll. Rhod. 1. 601 Ἄθω ἀνέτελλε κολώνη Θρηικίη ἣ τόσσον ἀπόπροθι Λῆμνον ἐοῦσαν ἀκροτάτῃ κορυφῇ σκιάει, καὶ ἐσάχρι Μυρίνης, with schol. ib. ἡ δὲ σκιὰ αὐτοῦ ἀφικνεῖται, φησί, καὶ μέχρι Μυρρίνης (mod. Kastro, on west coast of Lemnos). (2) Plin. l.c.: Myrinam, in ctiiiis forum solstitio Athos eiaeulatur umbram. (3) Stat. Theb. 5. 49 ff. Aegeo premitur circumflua Nereo | Lemnos... ingenli tellurem proximus umbra | vestit Athos nemorumque ohseurat imagine pontum.

The proverb is applied by Macarius ἐπὶ τῶν βλαπτότων ἐκ γειτνιάσεως, and by Suidas ἐπὶ τῶν τινας λυπούντων ἢ βλαπτόντων. Somewhat more to the point is Eustathius: ἐπὶ τῶν ἐχόντων καὶ πόρρωθεν ἐφικνεῖσθαι ἢ καθικνεῖσθαι τῶν ταπεινοτέρων δι᾿ ὑπεροχήν τινα. In Aesch. Ag. 296 the beacon-signal is passed from the Ἑρμαῖον λέπας in Lemnos to Mt Athos.

[The physical question raised by this interesting line, whether the shadow could in fact be seen, should be capable determination by the observation of travellers. The ancient evidence quoted above, particularly that of Pliny, is fairly strong, and appears to be confirmed by that of modern times. Tozer [Islands of the Aegean, p. 248 f.), after speaking of the alleged phenomenon as an impossibility, remarks as follows: ‘ At one period of the summer the sun is seen from this part of Lemnos to set behind Athos: of this I was assured by a resident in Kastro who had noticed it; and it may be inferred from ’s remark that on July 2 he saw the sun go down a little to the right of that mountain. This also must be a striking sight, and one that would appeal to the imagination. ’ Among Sir R. ’s papers were certain letters and memoranda which had been com- municated to him by the Rev. J. B. Pearson, of Emmanuel College, Cambridge. Dr Pearson had made calculations which supported the occurrence of the phenomenon as being scientifically possible, and forwarded corroborative evidence from the writings of travellers. Thus Belon, Observations de plusieurs és (Paris, 1553), Bk I c. 25 p. 26 v. : ’ ’isle est estendue plus en longueur ’en largeur, ’orient de Occident, en
sorte que quand le soleil va coucher, ’ombre de mont Athos qui est a plus de huict lieues de la vient respondre (sic) sur le port, et dessus le bout de ’isle qui est an coste senestre de Lemnps; chose que ’observay le deuxiesme jour de Juing (O.S., June 12 N.S.). Car le mont Athos est si hault ’encores que le soleil ne fust bien bas, neantmoins rombre touchoit la senestre corne de ’isle.’ Conze, Jieise auf den Inseln des Thrakischen Meeres, p. 109 ‘ Ich sah am Strande von Kastro am 2 Juli 1858 die Sonne ein wenig rechts von Athos ’ Admiral Whatton, formerly Hydrographer General, wrote to Dr Pearson on 18 Oct. 1901 as follows: ’ Sophocles had every reason for his remark (Ἄθως σκιάζει etc.), it to mean that the peak of Mt Athos would throw the ox or any point into shadow while the sunshine was still on the houses or hills near. It can scarcely mean that the shape of the peak would be discernible. It would be impossible for the apex, for the sun would be showing on either side; and the shadow of the edge would pass so rapidly that the eye would not detect it. The air is very clear in those parts, and I have seen the shadow of Mt Athos peak thrown on banks of clouds that must have been 100 miles from it. I was at Beshika Bay, twice the distance of Lemnos, and after watching the sun pass behind the peak, sharply defined against the bright sky, I turned round and saw this great “ spectre of the ” on the clouds.’ Dr Rouse tells me that Athos is a vast mass, very marked in form; and that at a distance of 100 miles he has seen it high above the sea. I am indebted to the late Mr J. Greaves, of ’s College, for the following remarks: ‘ I make the amount by which “ dip ” would lower the apparent height to be 1290 ft., so that the altitude above the horizon would be about 10 13. I worked out also the appearance of Snaefell as seen from the Cumberland coast. Its altitude would be only about 15. The figure gives the appearance of the sun and Mt Athos as seen on the horizon from Kastro, and the sun and Snaefell as seen from the Cumberland coast.

When you take into account the extra ana clearness of the atijiosphere at Lenmos, and the fact that Athos is isolated and Snaefell not, it is evident that the phenomenon of the sun setting behind Athos is a very much more remarkable one than when it sets behind Snaefell. I make out that the sun will set behind Athos about May 23 and July 22; but this is without taking refraction into account . . . . I do not know whether Kastro is at the sea level or not' [the citadel was in fact on a promontory]: ’if it is above, the phenomenon will be more marked. The whole thing is absolutely clear to me, after consulting the map, working out the figures, and taking the clearnessof the atmosphere into account. From Kastro Mt Athos will be a fairly prominent and isolated object on the NW, horizon, so much so, that I should expect the inhabitants of Kastro to say when May was advanced, “ we shall soon have the sun setting behind Athos. ” I should expect all the intelligent boys and girls to know the days when the phenomenon would occur. I am also quite sure that if the day was clear, the sun would be seen to set on July 2, 1858, a little to the right of Athos.

I arrived at Admiral ’s conclusions independently. If there is ground near higher than the “ ox,” it would be in the sun-light, while the ox was in shadow, but I ’t believe the outline of the shadow of the peak would be visible. The fact that the sun is a large disc and not a point of light would be against it.’]
777 Θεσσαλῆς Dindorf Θεσσαλικῆς codd., Θεσσαλίδος Valckenaer

777 Etym. Μ. p. 125, 13 ἁπληγίς· τὸ ἁπλοῦν ἱμάτιον, ὅπερ Ὅμηρος ἁπλοΐδα καλεῖ. Σοφοκλῆς ‘ τρύχει . . . ἁπληγίδος.᾿ Nauck adds Strab. 530 καὶ τὴν ἐσθῆτα δὲ τὴν Ἀρμενιακὴν Θετταλικήν φασιν, οἷον τοὺς βαθεῖς χιτῶνας οὓς καλοῦσιν Θετταλικοὺς ἐν ταῖς τραγῳδίαις καὶ ζωννύουσι περὶ τὸ στήθη, καὶ ἐφαπτίδας, ὡς καὶ τῶν τραγῳδῶν μιμησαμένων τοὺς θετταλούς. I have slightly altered the ordinary punctuation of this passage for the sake of clearness, and believe that τάς should be added before ἐφαπτίδας. Even thus the sentence is awkwardly put together; for the meaning must be that the ἐφαπτίδες also were called θετταλικαί. It will be observed that the quotation from Strabo is only relevant in so far as it attests that Thessalian ἐφαπτίζες ( = χλαμύδες) were commonly worn by actors.
H. renders : ‘ Wrapped in a worn shred | Of a Thessahan ’ singlet.᾿

τρύχει. The word is almost entirely tragic, not appearing in prose before Aristotle. When used in comedy, it is paratragoedic (Starkie on Ar. Ach. 418). —Θεσσαλῆς ἁπληγίδος. The ἁπληγίς may be taken to be identical with the Homeric dTrXotJ, which was an outer garment worn over the χιτών, and thrown round the shoulders like a shawl or a plaid. It is contrasted with διπλῆ οr δίπλαξ, which was a larger piece of stuff worn folded, so that it always required to be fastened at the shoulders by buckles. Both were of wool, and belonged as species to the genus χλαῖνα (Horn. Ω 230, ω 276). The Homeric dTrXoifs did not differ essen- tially from the later χλαμύς, except that the former was cut square, the latter round: see Studniczka, äge zur Geschichte d. altgr. Tracht, p. 73,,, Amelung in Pauly-Wissowa in III 2336. Thus it appears that θεσσαλῆ ἁπληγίς is a description of the χλαμύς; for (1) we never read of a doubling of the χλαμύς in classical times, and (2) the χλαμύς was called Thessalian in virtue of its origin: Philostr. heroic. 3, 4 χλαμύδα ἐνῆπται, ξένε, τὸν θετταλικὸν τρόπον, Poll. 7. 46 ἐντεθετταλίσμεθα ἔλεγον τὸ χλαμυδοφοροῦμεν, 10. 124. See Amelung, l.c. 2343. — Dindorf seems to be clearly right in proposing θεσσαλῆς, which is the normal form in tragedy: the corruption was only what might have been expected, and would not have arisen so easily from θεσσαλίδοσ (O.C. 314).

778 Εtym. Voss. p. 577 F Gaisf. (Etym. Flor. Mill. p. 66) βλιμάζειν . . . λαμβάνεται δὲ ἡ λέξις (sc. βλίττειν) καὶ ἐπὶ τοῦ τὰ κηρία τῶν μελισσῶν τρυγᾶν, ὡς Ἀριστοφάνης (Eq. 794) ῾ ἀλλὰ αὐτὸν βλίττεις᾿ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς ῾ ἢ σφηκιὰν τινά.᾿

βλίσσειν comes from μ(ε)λιτιειν, strictly of squeezing honey from the comb, but metaphorically applied to a ’s nest not as an equivalent for useless labour, but in reference to those who unnecessarily seek out trouble for them- selves: ῾ to bring a ’s nest about ’s ’ Cf. Ar. Lys. 475 ἢν μή τις ὥσπερ σφηκιὰν βλίττῃ με κἀρεθίζῃ. Μacar. 7. 94 σφηκιὰν ἠρέθισας· ἐπὶ τῶν ἑαυτοῖς κακὰ κινούντων. Eustath. ΙΙ. p. 897, 56 (Ael. et Pans. fr. 160 Schw.) ἰστέον δὲ ὡς οὐ μόνον σφῆκεσ ὑπὲρ τέκνων ἀμυντικοί, διὸ καὶ παροιμία τὸ σφηκιὰν ἐκίνησας, ἤγουν βλάβην ἤγειρας κατὰ σεαυτοῦ. Ar. Vesp. 404 ἡνίκ᾿ ἄν τις ἡμῶν ὀργίσῃ τὴν σφηκιάν.

Ellendt preferred βλίζουσιν on the strength of Etym. Μ. p. 200, 34 ἀπὸ τοῦ μέλι μελίζω καὶ κατὰ συγκοπὴν καὶ τροπὴν βλίζω. But the evidence favours βλίττω βλίσσω). For ’s view that the fr. is quoted from the Pandora see on fr. 484.
779 ἔχω Hemsterhuis: ἐγὼ codd. | ἀγρίαν Brunck
779 Ely in. M. p. 213, 26 βρίακχος· θηλυκῶς, ἡ βάκχη. Σοφοκλῆς ῾ ἐγὼ . . . βρίακχον.᾿ εἴρηται δὲ ἡ βριαρῶς ἰακχάζουσα. Cf. Hesych. I p. 398 βρίακχος· βριαρῶς βριαρῶς βρίαγχος] βαρέως ἰακχάζουσα.

See cr. nn. ἔχω appears to be a certain emendation, but it is otherwise with Brunck's ἀγρίαν. Blaydes ἔχω δὲ χερσὶν νῦν βρίακχον ἀγρίαν; but the text may as well have been χερσὶν δ’ ἔχω | ἄγραν βρίακχον.

BpiaKxos (or βρίαχος) is found as the name of a satyr on an amphora in the British Museum (790), on a lecythus in the Berlin Museum (2256), and on an oenochoe described by Ο. Jahn, ArcA. Αufs. 14240. For the details see H. Heydemann, Satyr- und Bakchennamen, Halle 1880, p. 35 f. The text is the only evidence that the word was also applied to a maenad. Roscher in Curtius, Stud. I. 2. 122, followed Hesychius in interpreting it as crying aloud. He was no doubt right in comparing it with ἴακχος and βάκχος, but scarcely in deriving all three from ἰάχειν, ἰαχή. The first syllable of βρίακχος may have been identical with the βρι- of βριαρός etc.
780 Etym. M. p. 265, 24 δημόκοινος· δημόσιος βασανιστής, ἢ ὁ δήμιος· ἤγουν ὁ ἐκ τοὐ δήμου τὸ φονεύειν κληρωθείς. Σοφοκλῆς· ῾ οἷος . . . . οἴχεται.᾿

The text has been suspected, not without reason; and the choice seems to lie between ’s ἡμῖν and ’s δ’ ἀφ᾿ (perhaps better παρ’) for γάp. The sense appears to be ’What a blood-stained torturer we have lost For For δημόκοινος cf. Hesych. ι p. 482 δημόκοινος· δημόσιος βασανιστής, πόρνος, καὶ δήμιος. δημόκοινος was synonymous with with δήμιος, the public ’ as is clear from Antiphon 1 20 τῷ γὰρ δημοκοίνῳ τροχισθεῖσα παρεδόθη. Here it is almost certainly a term of abuse: Eustath. Οd. p. 1833, 54 ἀπὸ τοῦ παρὰ τοῖς ὕστερον κολαστικοῦ δημίου, ἐξ οὗ σκῶμμα πονηροῖς ἐπέκειτο τὸ δημόκοινος ὃς καὶ ἄνδραχνος ἢ ἄνδραγχος ἐπεκαλεῖτο. So Lycophr. fr. 2 (Nauck, p. 817). Philo leg. ad Cat. 13 11 p. 559 M. ἀνδροφόνων καὶ δημοκοίνων θίασος. The ’s calling made him necessarily impure. But from the interpretation βασνιστής a certain Confusion has arisen, shown by the distinction which Herodian (ap. Lobeck's Phryn. draws: δημόκοινος δὲ ὁ στρεβλῶν καὶ βασανίζων· δήμιος δὲ ὁ ἀπάγων τὴν ἐπὶ θανάτῳ. This distinction is held to be entirely unfounded (Thalheim in Pauly- Wissowa IV 2854), and is due to a mistaken inference from Isocr. 17. 15.
τὸ δ᾿ ἔγχος ἐν ποσὶν κυλίνδεται
781 Etym. Μ. p. 313, 3 ἔγχος . . .ὁ δὲ Σοφοκλῆς τὴν σφαῖραν ἔγχος κέκληκεν, οἷον ῾ τὸ ἔγχος ἐν ποσὶ κυλίνδεται.᾿

The fragment is generally assigned to the Nausicaa, on the suggestion of Schneider and Bergk. The situation may be that of ζ 115, as described by Odysseus to Alcinous in η 290 : ῾ the ball rolls close to my ’

Sophocles was a bold innovator in his use of ἔγχος, although it appears with the general sense of ῾ weapon ’ in other
writers as well: see schol. Ai. 906 πᾶν δὲ ἀμυντήριον καὶ δόρυ καὶ ἔγχος καλοῦσιν οἱ νεώτεροι. So Find. Pyth. 9. 26 λέοντι ὀβρίμῳ μούναν παλαίοισαν ἄτερ ἐγχέων. Hence the distinguishing epithets in Bacchyl. fr. 3 J. (13 Β.), 8 ἔγχεά τε λογχωτά (secus Jebb), Eur. Her. 1098 πτερωτά τ’ ἔγχη (of arrows). In Track. 1013 οὐ πῦρ, οὐκ ἔγχος τις ὀνήσιμον οὐκ ἐπιτρέψει; the sense is quite general, ’saving ’ but the intention is to suggest πῦρ καὶ δίδηρον, as in Anacreont. 24 τί ὖν; δίδωσι κάλλος | ἀντ᾿ ἀσπίδων ἁπσᾶν, | ἀντ’ ἐγχέων ἁπάντων. | νικᾷ δὲ καὶ σίδηρον | καὶ πῦρ καλή τις οὖσα. But the most remarkable instance is Ο. Τ. 169 οὐδ᾿ ἔνι φροντίδος ἔγχος ᾧ τις ἀλέξεται. H. holds that this was copied by Opp. Ηal. 3. οὐδέ οἱ ὅπλον ἐνὶ φρεσίν, οἷον ἄρηρεν ἐΚ γενύων. Blaydes suggested the insertion of ἡμῶν (or ἡμῖν) after ἔγχος.
782 Etym. Μ. p. 315, 5 καὶ τὸ πῦρ (sc. ὁ Σοφοκλῆς ἔγχος κέκληκεν), οἷον ῾ ἔγχος ἱέμενος,᾿ τὸ τὴν ὁρμὴν ἔχον.

I think that Sylburg was right in read- ing ἱέμενον (a change silently adopted by Brunck and Dindorf), as is indicated by the words τὸ τὴν ὁρμὴν ἔχον, i.e. set in motion: cf. Hesych. 11 p. 345 ἵεμαι· . . . ὁρμῶ. ἱεμένη περ· καίπερ . . . ὁρμωμένη, and ib. p. 346 ἵενται· ὁρμῶσιν, referring to Horn. Χ 304. So Suid. s.v. ἵενται. Nauck agrees that the words are corrupt, but suggests ἔγχους μένος, without any probability. I cannot, however, avoid the suspicion that the grammarian may have intended to refer to fr. 535 (n.), in which case ἱέμενον would be a gloss and not part of the original text.
πολὺς δὲ πηλὸς ἐκ πίθων τυρβάζεται.

783 Εtym. Μ. p. 490, 3 κάπηλος, ὁ μεταβολεὺς καὶ οἰνοπώλης. παρὰ τὸ χέειν τὸν πηλόν, ἤγουν τὸν οἶνον . . .τινὲς οἴονται ἔ ἀνθ᾿ ἑνὸς εἶναι, πηλὸν καὶ οἶνον, ἐΚ τοῦ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ῾ πολὺς . . . τυρβάζεται.᾿ ὁ μὲν οὖν Σοφοκλῆς εὐεπίφορος εἰς τὸν πηλόν. See also Cramer anecd. Oxon. 11 p. 455 29; Etym. Gud. p. 298. 1, where the same extract occurs. It is mutilated in Suid. s.v. In schol. Ar. Plut. 426, 435 κάπηλος is derived from κακύνειν πηλόν, i.e. οἶνον. Hesych. Ill p. 31 πηλός· οἶνος. Ἴωνες. ἔνθεν καὶ κάπηλος ὁ τὸν οἶνον πωλῶν.

It is of course incredible that Sophocles used πηλός in the sense of οἶνος, as the grammarians admit ὁ μέντοι οἶνος οὐΚ εστι πηλός); rather it is the wine-lees stirred up from the bottom of the cask. Wine spilt on the floor was called πηλός: Plut. cohib. ir. 15 p. 463 A ῾ πηλόν᾿ ὥς τις εἶπεν τις ῾ οἴνου καὶ σπαράγματα στεφάνων.᾿ Chariton 1. 3 οἴνου πηλὸν ἐποίησαν. Hence the joke of the μάγειρος, rebuking the clumsy cupbearer, who either spills the wine or lets the sediment mix with the liquid, μὴ δεῖν τὸν Οἰνέα Πηλέα ποιεῖν Athen. 383 C, Eustath. Od. 1401, 57. Demetrius de eloc. 171 ὡς καὶ τὸν οἶνον τὸν προχυθέντα ἐπισχών τις ῾ Πηλέα ἀντὶ Οἰνέως.᾿

τυρβάζεται. Neil on Ar. Eq. 310 remarks that τυρβάζω is colloquial, if not coarse, and infers that this fr. as well as fr. 838 came from a satyric play. It is connected with πηλός also in Ar. Vesp. 257 τὸν πηλὸν ὥσπερ ἀτταγᾶς τυρβάσεις βαδίζων.
784 Etym. M. p. 511, 55 κηρύκειον . . . ἔστι καὶ κτητικόν, σημαῖνον τὸ τοῦ κήρυκος, ὡς παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ‘γράμμα κηρύκειον.’ So also Etym, Gud. p. 320 24.
Suid. has a lemma κηρύκειος γραφή without any explanation. Presumably the words refer to the written instructions from which the herald makes his proclamation.

785 Εtym. M.p. 561, 28 λευγαλέον· τὸ ὑγρόν. παρὰ Σοφκλεῖ ‘μόρῳ λευγαλέῳ’ (so cod. A Etym. gen.: μύρῳ λευγαλέῳ codd. Etym. M. [μύρω λευγαλέ cod. M]). Cf. Phot. lex. p. 216, 16 λευγαλέα· διάβροχος. οὕτω Σοφοκλῆς: hence Nauck deduced μύρῳ λευγαλέα as the text of Sophocles.

This fragment has had a curious history. Sophocles, probably in one or other of the plays in which he reproduced the subject-matter οΙ the Odyssey, imitated the Homeric line νῦν δέ με λευγαλέῳ θανάτῳ εἵμαρτο ἁλῶναι (Φ 281, ε 312). Τhis latter was explained by the comment τουτέστι, τῷ δι᾿ ὕδατος, which in course of time led to the erroneous conclusion that λευγαλέος and ὑγρός were identical in meaning : see schol. A Hom. Φ 281 λευγαλέῳ] ὅτι ἐκ τούτου οἱ νεώτεροι ἐξεδέξαντο λευγαλέον τὸν δίυγρον κτἑ., schol. Townl. ibid. λευγαλέῳ χαλεπῷ οὐ διύγρῳ ὡς Ἡσίοδος (does this refer to Op. 525?). τί γὰρ ἐπὶ τοῦ ‘λευγαλέοι τ᾿ ἐσόμεσθα (β 61)’; schol. Q ε 312 refers the interpretation τὸν ἐν ὑγρῷ (θάνατον) to οἱ γλωσσογράφοι. Nauck quotes Hesych. II p. 427 καταλευγαλέα· κάθυγρος, καταληλιμμένη, and schol. A Hom. Y 109 ὅτι λευγαλέοις οὐ διύγροις, ὡς οἱ νεώτεροι. In the quotation from Sophocles the blunder μύρῳ perpetuated the delusion that he had employed λευγαλέος in the sense of moist, and the fragment was connected by Meineke (Callim. p. 245) and others with fr. 361. The truth was explained by Reitzenstein in a Rostock dissertation of 1891/92, p. 14, where he published the reading μόρῳ for the first time. Campbell, justly sceptical of the use οf λευγαλέος, had proposed μυδαλέα. But the source of Photius’ λευγαλέα (not λευγαλέῳ) still remains obscure.

lg.l: οὐπώποθ᾿ ἥβης ἐς τὸ σῶφρον ἵκετο,
ἀλλ᾿ ἐν νέοις ἀνθεῖ τε καὶ πάλιν φθίνει.

div.p: 786. 2 ἡβήσει τῷ σώφρονι ἵκετο codd.: corr. Pierson 3 πάλιν φθίνει D (πάλιν φθείνει Μ): φθίνει πάλιν vulgo
786 Etym. M. p. 601 extr. νεῖκος· ἡ φιλονεικία, παρὰ τὸ νέοις ἐοικέναι. ἡ γὰρ φιλονεικία τοῖς νεαροῖς ἁρμόζει. Σοφοκλῆς ‘ὕβρις . . . φθίνει.’

1 f. The first clause has been variously interpreted, especially in regard to the meaning and construction of ἥβης. (i) Headlam in ΟR xvii 293 pointed out that σωφροσύνη is the proper virtue of old age (see however on fr. 210, 73),
comparing Theogn. 1325 μερμήρας δ’ ἀπόπαυε κακάς, δὸς δ᾿ εὔφρονι θυμῷ | μέτρ᾿ ἥβης τελέσαντ᾿ ἔργματα σωφροσύνης. He held that ἥβης is temporal, ’ in the season of youth, and (apparently) by ’came ’ passed into sober- ’ The objection to this view is that, if there is no reference here to later life, the balance of the contrasting clauses is destroyed. (2) Blaydes joins joins ὕβρις ἥβης ’ the wantonness of ’ and we might then take τὸ σῶφρον as personal = τοὺς σώφρονας: cf. El. 1507 τὸ πανοῦργον. But the order of the words is decisive against connecting ἥβης with ὕβρις. (3) All difficulty disappears if we remember that ἥβη, like the Latin hiventus, is more flexible than our ’youth’: the literal rendering is ῾ wantonness wantonness has never lasted till the sober stage of manhood.’ O.T. 741 τίνα δ᾿ ἀκμὴν ἥβης ἔχων (of Laius). Track. 547 ὁρῶ γὰρ ἥβην τὴν μὲν ἕρπουσαν πρόσω | τὴν δὲ φθίνουσαν, where Deianira is contrasting her own ‘ maturity ’ with that of lole. Thus ἥβης is a partitive gen., for which cf. Thuc. i. 118 ἐπὶ μέγα ἐχέρησαν δυνάμεως. Hdt. 8. 52 καίπερ ἐς τὸ ἔσχατον κακοῦ ἀπιγμένοι. Eur. Suppl. 709 ἀλλ᾿ ᾤχετ᾿ ἐς τὸ κάμνον οἰκείου στρατοῦ. F. W. Schmidt proposed to alter ἥβης to ὥρας, but the corruption is extremely unlikely, as it does not seem probable that uipas would have been glossed by ἥβης.
3 Blaydes quotes Tr. fr. adesp. 574 ἅπαντα θάλλει καὶ πάλιν μαραίνεται, which he believes to be Sophoclean.
787 ὀργάσι Etym. M., ὀργάσασθαι Etym. Gud.

787 Eiym. M. p. 629, 35 and Etym. Gud. p. 432, 53 ὀργάσαι τὸ πηλοποιῆσαί ἐστι καὶ ὑγρῷ ξηρὸν μῖξαι. Σοφοκλῆς ῾ θέλοιμι πηλὸν ὀργάσι ὀργάσασθαι).᾿ Hesych. Ill p. 216 ὀργάσαι· ἑτοιμάσαι. καὶ ῾ τὸν πηλὸν ὀργάσαι᾿ φασίν, ὅ ἐστιν ἑτοιμάσαι, φυρᾶσαι, βρέξαι, ἀναδεῦσαι. It has been conjectured with some probability that this fragment belongs to the Pandora: see on fr. 482.
788 φιταλιμῷ vel φυταλιμῷ codd.: corr. Sylburg
788 Etym. M. p. 803, 4 φυτάλιμος Σοφοκλῆς ῾ προσῆλθε μητρὶ καὶ φιταλιμῷ φυταλιμῷ VD) πατρί.᾿

φυταλμίῳ πατρί. The adjective signifies procreative ([Eur.] Rhes. 920 λέκτροις ἐπλάθην Στρυμόνος φυταλμίοις), and, when combined with πατήρ, the sire who begat (him). The force of the adjective is more or less accentuated according to the occa- sion: in Aesch. Ag. 339 φυταλμίων παῖδες γερόντων (or, with Weil and others, φυτάλμιοι παίδων γέροντες) it is merely pathetic. So τοῦ φυτουργοῦ πατρός in Ο.Τ. 1482 τοῦ φυτεύσαντος πατρός ib. 15 14, τὸν φυτουργόν Eur. Τro. 481. τὸν φυτοσπόρον in Track. 359 and φυτουργόν Eur. Ι. Α. 949 are more formal. In Aesch. Suppl. 600 πατὴρ φυτουργὸς αὐτόχειρ ἄναξ the lofty phrase expresses the pride of descent.

789 Etym. Sorb. ed. Gaisf. p. 1131 (Bekk. anecd. p. 1376) εὐνοῦχοι· οἱ τὴν εὐνὴν ἔχοντες, ὡς γεοῦχοι. εὐνούχους δὲ Σοφοκλῆς καὶ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς τοὺς εὔνεις καὶ ὕπνου μὴ μετέχοντας μετασχόντας Bekk.), τουτέστι τηροῦντας ῾οὐχ ὅπου . . . ὄμμασιν.᾿

For τηροῦντας Nauck formerly proposed πηροὺς ὄντας, but the text is better. The suggested derivation from εὔνεις ὕπνου) is the grammarian’s attempt to distinguish this application of the word from the ordinary meaning of εὐνοῦχος. But the bold metaphor (for which cf. fr. 761 n.) may be justified. In Erotic literature the λύχνος is the constant companion of the ἐρωμένη, either keeping vigil with her when she waits for her lover, or as the only witness of her meeting with him: see Headlam on Aesch. Ag. 881 τὰς ἀμφὶ σοὶ κλαίουσα λαμπτηρουχίας. Especially to the point here is Anth. Pal. 5. 165 ἢ νέος ἄλλος ἔρως, νέα παίγνια; πήποτε, λύχνε, | ταῦτ᾿ ἐσίδῃς, εἴης δ’ ἧς παρέδωκα φύλαξ. The metre is doubtful, but the words are not necessarily corrupt.

790 Eustath. Il. p. 1237, 22 διαγνωμονοῦντος Ἀχιλλέως ὅτι τε εὐψύχως ἔτι διάκειται καὶ διερῷ ποδί, καθ᾿ Ὅμηρον ι 43), ἢ χλωρὸν γόνυ κατὰ Θεόκριτον (14. 70) ἔχων, καὶ οὔπω δέος εἰς ἀλίβαντα καταπεσεῖν ζῶντι ποδὶ χρώμενον, ὥς φησι Σοφοκλῆς.

This extract, which is not quoted in sufficient fullness by Nauck, is a comment on Φ 301 ff. πολλὰ δὲ τεύχεα καλὰ δαϊκταμένων αἰζηῶν | πλῶον καὶ μέκυες. τοῦ δ᾿ ὑψόσε γούνατ᾿ ἐπήδα | πρὸς ῥόον ἀΐσσοντος. Nauck, regarding the sequence οf the quotations, selected ζῶντι ποδὶ χρώμενον as the only part of the extract which belonged to Sophocles. But it is difficult to believe that the words ὔπω δέος εἰς ἀλίβαντα καταπεσεῖν were the composition of the grammarian who is the ultimate source of Eustathius. To disintegrate the actual language of Sophocles is another matter: we might write εἰς ἀλίβαντα καταπεσεῖν | οὔπω δέος νιν ζῶντι χρώμενον ποδί, or εἰς ἀλίβαντα καταπεσεῖν οὔπω δέος | ...ζ. χ. π. , or as in the text. The first alternative gives an unusual tribrach in the fifth foot: see however Phil. 1302, Jebb on Ο. Τ. 719. The quantity of dXifiai is doubtful, though the a is generally stated to be long: see Adam on Plat. rep. 387 c, who however should not have spoken of the a as ῾certainly long’ in this passage. Schneider, Callim. 11 254, argues that it was short, against Lobeck, Path. Prol. p. 289. Bergk wished to read χλωρῷ for ζῶντι from Hesych. IV p. 290 χλωροπέδῳ νεαρῷ, just as Toup restored χλωρόν τε in Aesch. Ag. 682. But it is unlikely that χλωρῷ ποδί, if it had formed part of the original quotation, would have been corrupted in this context; nor is it by any means certain that the words ζῶντι ποδὶ χρώμεν ον belong to Sophocles at all. It should be observed that the purpose of the note was to bring out the contrast between the inert corpses and the vigorous vitality of Achilles, and that, though τε is misplaced, the clauses ὅτι τε εὐψύχως κτἑ. and καὶ οὔπω δέος κτἑ. are intended to balance each other. Cf. however Ο. Τ. 878 ἔνθ᾿ οὐ ποδὶ χρησίμῳ χρῆται, fr, 248. —εἰς ἀλίβαντα appears to be an equivalent of εἰς Ἅιδου. That Alibas was the name of a river in the underworld is stated by Suid. s. v. κήρ: λέγουσι δὲ καὶ Ἀλίβαντά τινα εἶναι ποταμόν (sc. ἐν Ἅιδου, as the context shows)· ἀπὸ τοῦ καταξηραίνειν, καὶ μηδὲ λιβάδα ὑπάρχειν, ἤγουν ἰκμάδα: to the same effect Etym. Μ. p. 550, 33 s.v. κωκυτός. The river of Death parches instead of relieving thirst, like vinegar to which Callimachus (fr. 88) gave the name ἀλίβας. The ancients derived the word ἀλίβας, which has also the
sense of νεκρός, from ἀ- and λιβάς, i.e. deficient in moisture: see Plut. qu. conv. 8. 10. 3 p. 735 F, aq. an ign. util 2 p. 956 A, Cornut. 35 p. 75, 9 ff. Didym. ap. schol. Ar. Ran. 186. The local habitation of the Alibas-myth may be taken to have been Metapontum in Lucania, which was at one time known as Alybas (Eustath. in Od. p. 1961, 62), and subsequently received its later name from Metabus, the son of Alibas (Etym. M. p. 579, 29). It is also significant that Metapontum was sad to have been colonized byNeleids from Pylow (Bacchyl. 10. 120, Strab. 264); and that Pylos was reputed ῾ the gate of Hell,᾿ and the original home of Hades-worship (Hom. E 395 Pausan. 6. 25. 2). Lastly, it should be mentioned that Alybas was the name of an evil spirit who infested the town οἱ Temesa, on the borders of Lucania and Bruttium, until he was overthrown by the Locrian Euthymus: see the curious story related by Suid. s.v. EOOvfioi. Cf. fr. 994 n.
791 Eustath. Od. p. 1479, 44 (after speaking of κοκκύζειν as used of the crowing of the cock) ὑποβάλλει δὲ τοιοῦτον νοῦν καὶ Σοφοκλῆς, φασίν, ἐν τῷ ῾κοκκοβόας ὄρνις.᾿

κοκκυβόας is ῾chanticleer.᾿ Hesych. II p. 504 κοκκυβίας· ὄνομα κύριον, Dindorf conjectured Κοκκυγίας (a wind), and Μ. Schmidt Κυκίβιος, both contrary to the order. H. thinks that the gloss may possibly be due to some misconception of Ar. Eccl. 31 ὡς ὁ κῆρυξ δεύτερον κεκόκκυκεν, whcre ὁ κῆρυξ is the cock. In reference to κοκκύζειν = ῾to crow,’ we the dictum οf Phrynichus (praep. soph. p. 35, 14 de B.) ᾀδειν ἀλεκτρυόνας ἀττικῶς· τὸ δὲ κοκκύζειν κωμικοὶ λέγουσιν. So Cratin. fr. 311 (1 103 K.) κοκκύζειν τὸν ἀλεκτρυόν᾿ οὐκ ἀνέχοντα, Plat. com. fr. 209 (1 659 K.) τὲ δὲ κοκκύζων ἀλέκτωρ προκαλεῖται. Antiatt. (Bekk. anecd) p. 101, 4 κοκκύζειν τοὺς ἀλεκτρυόνας· Δίφιλος Πλινθοφόρῳ (fr. 65, 11 562 K.). Phot. ed. Keitz. p. 47, 26. We should not infer that κοκκυβόας is below the dignity of tragedy, or on the same level as our ’cock-a-doodle-doo’: see Theocr. 7. 123 ὁ δ᾿ ὄρθριος ἄλλον ἀλέκτωρ | κοκκύζων νάρκαισιν ἀνιαραῖσι διδοίη, and Poll. 5. 89 καὶ ἀλεκτρυόνας ᾄδειν καὶ κόκκυγας κοκκύζειν—Ὑπερείδης (fr. 239 B.) δὲ καὶ Δημοσθένης ἐπ᾿ ἀλεκτρυόνων τὸ κοκκύζειν εἶπον. The latter statement appears to rest on the authority of Aristophanes of Byzantium (fr. 73 Nauck), from whom Phrynichus and the rest derive. See Miller, Milanges, p. 428.
792 Eustath. Od. p. 1625, 44 λέγει δὲ καὶ (sc. Ἀριστοφάνης ὁ γραμματικός) ὅτι κατὰ τὴν δάμαλιν Σοφοκλῆς ἔφη ῾γηγενῆ βούβαλιν,᾿ καὶ Αἰσχύλος (fr. 330) ῾λεοντόχορτον βούβαλιν νεαίρετον.᾿

Aristophanes might be thought to have meant nothing more than that δάμαλις and βούβαλις are parallel formations, but in view of the fact that the extract is taken from his περὶ ὀνομασίας ἡλικιῶν, βούβαλις was clearly parallel to δάμαλις νέα βοῦς) also in meaning. The Latin bubalus is said to mean both ‘buffalo’ and ‘antelope’; but Plin. n. h. 8. 38 condemns the former interpretation as due to ignorance: tiros, quibus imperitum vulgus bubalorum nomen imponit, cum id gignat Africa vituli potius cervique quadam similitudine. Polybius was hardly open to ’s reproach, although some of his interpreters render βουβάλων as ῾buffaloes᾿ in 12. 3. 5. However this may be, the form βούβαλις is well established, and, so far as we can tell, denotes
the antelope: with the fr. of Aeschylus should be compared Aelian nat. an. 3. 1. 5. 48. But it is not easy to understand γηγενῆ. Ellendt thinks it meant ‘wild’ ῾ haud dubie ἀγρίαν, feram’); but I find any authority for this, and should prefer ῾indigenous.’
793. 2 μητέρες αἶγές τ᾿ Dindorf: αἶγες μητέρες τ’ Eustath. 3 πόνον R. Ellis

793 Eustath. Od. p. 1625,49 (quoting from Aristophanes Byz. περὶ ὀνομασίας ἡλικιῶν) ἔμβρυα δὲ τινα καὶ ἀρτιγενῆ δὴ ψάκαλα λέγει καλεῖσθαι καὶ ὀρταλίχους. ὅθεν φησὶ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ῾ψακαλοῦχοι... ἀναφαίνοιεν.᾿ Cf. Eustath. Il. p. 777, 62 (schol. Hom. I 601 in Cramer anecd. Par. III p. 242, 33) ψάκαλα τὰ ἔμβρυα καὶ ἄρτι δὴ γεγονότα, ὅθεν καὶ ψακαλοῦχοι μητέρες παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ. Hesych. IV p. 305 ψακαλοῦχοι· φακάδας ἔχουσαι. εἰσὶ δὲ ἔμβρυα.
The fragment appears to be a prayer for the increase of the flocks. Welcker conjectured that it belonged to the Ποιμένες, and Hartung referred it to the Inachus.

1 ψακαλοῦχοι. In addition to the above evidence that the young of animals were called ψάκαλα see Ael. nat. an. 7. 47 (who professedly follows Aristophanes of Byzantium) τὰ δὲ τῶν ὀρνίθων καὶ τὰ τῶν ὄφεων καὶ τὰ τῶν κροκοδείλων ἔνιοι καὶ ψακάλους καλοῦσιν, ὧν εἰσι καὶ Θετταλοί. The word is generally compared with δρόσος as used by Aesch. Ag. 147 δρόσοισι λεπτοῖς μαλερῶν λεόντων, and the Homeric ἕρσαι applied to very young lambs in ι 222. Giles C. R. Ill 3), comparing ἕρσαι with the Lat. verres, suggested that the passages of Aesch. and Soph, were due to a mistaken imitation of the Homeric usage; but the evidence of Aelian indicates that ψάκαλον (or ψάκαλος) was something more than a literary curiosity.

3 γόνον should rather be γονήν according the prevailing usage of Sophocles, although γόνον could of course be defended from other writers (see Lexx.). This consideration makes in favour of Robinson Ellis’s elegant emendation πόνον, which he supported by Aesch. Ag. 54 δεμνιοτήρη πόνον ὀρταλίχων ὀλέσαντες. The commentators on Aesch. are not agreed as to whether wbvov there is concrete (‘the young brood, their care’), abstract (‘their loving care for their young’). If πόνον is right here, it favour the view, for which Eur. Phoen. 30 ἣ δὲ τὸν ἐμὸν ὠδίνων πόνον | μαστοῖς ὑφεῖτο may also be compared. — ὀρταλίχων, elsewhere only of the young of birds: Α. P. 5. 291 ὄρνιθες δροσερῶν μητέρες ὀρταλιχων. We may compare the transference of νεοσσός, and the more limited use of cktck in English.
794 Eustath. Od. p. 1923, 61 λέγει δέ, φασί, καὶ Σοφοκλῆς πληθυντικῶς ῾σὺ ... βουλεύεις,᾿ ἤγουν παλαιά, ἀρχαῖα.

Eustathius is commenting on Hom. χ 184 σάκος γέρον, and quotes also γέρον γράμμα from Aesch. fr. 331. The adjectival use of γέρων, as applied to things, is found again in O.C. 1259 ὁ δυσφιλὴς γέρων γέροντι συγκατῴκηκεν πίνος, where see Jebb’s note. Cf. also Aesch. Cho. 801 γέρων φόνος, and Soph. fr. 868. Nauck thinks the harshness of the present example would be softened by reading σὺ γα]ρ <γέρων> γέροντα, preferred σὺ γάρ, | <νέος περ ὤν> <ὅμως>, Naber proposed to the line with ἄγαν (lost before ἤγουν). Such guesses are harmless
enough, but the proposal of R. Ellis βουλεύεις λόγον, after Eur. Her. 26, violates the tradition, which no doubt Eustathius faithfully preserved. The neuter plural perhaps occurs also in Etym. M. p. 227, 10 γέροντα πράγματα, but the reading is doubtful.
795 μολοσσῆσι Choerob. | ἐντείνων πέδας Nauck: ἐκτείνων πέλας Choerob., ἐκτείνων χεῖρας Anon. Ambr.

795 Georg. Choerob. exeg. in Hephaest. enchir. p. 60, 23 (p. 217, 15 Consbr.) τοὺς δὲ μηκίστους τὸ παλαιὸν μολοσσοκὺς ἐκάλουν, ὡς Σοφοκλῆς ἀντὶ τοῦ μεγάλαις. Anonymus Ambrosianus de re metr. in Studemund, anecd. I p 227, 1 τὰ μέγαλα μολοσσικὰ ἐκάλουν· Σοφοκλῆς ῾μολοσσικαῖσι. . . χεῖρας.᾿

The text has been brilliantly and convincingly restored by Nauck, who points out that Μολοσσικαὶ χεῖρες must be understood not as ‘big hands’ but simply as ‘the hands of Molossians.’ In support of use of the adjective he quotes (Lex. Vindob. p. 260) Eur. Hec. 1153 κερκίδ᾿ Ἠδωνῆς χερός. The Molossians would most naturally appear in a play connected with the fortunes of Neoptolemus, perhaps the Peleus or the Hermione.

lg.l: ὡς μήτε κρούσῃς μηθ᾿ ὑπὲρ χεῖλος βάλῃς

div.p: 796 χεῖλος Salmasius: χειρὸς vel χεῖρα codd.

796 Harpocr. p. 147, 17 παρακρούεται ἀντὶ τοῦ ἐξαπατᾷ. . .μετῆκται δὲ τοὔνομα ἀπὸ τοῦ τοὺς ἱστάντας τι ἢ μετροῦντας κρούειν τὰ μέτρα καὶ διασείειν ἔνεκα τοῦ πλεονεκτεῖν, καὶ ὡς Σοφοκλῆς που ῾ὡς. . . βάλῃς.᾿ Dind.'s note suggests that Harpocration's MSS give ὑπό for ὑπέρ: ῾ vulgo ὑπὸ χεῖρα: sed codices tres ὑπὸ χειρός.᾿ Bekker implies that all his MSS support ὑπέp. Hesych. iv p. 332 ὡς μήτε κροῦσαι μήθ᾿ ὑπὲρ χεῖλος βαλεῖν· παροιμία ἐπὶ τοῦ συμμέτρου τασσομένη.

The general meaning of the proverb is indicated by Hesychius: ῾ Observe the proper measure.’ Hemsterhuis well ῾Mens Sophoclis est, sic animum institue ut in metiendo nee nimium vel parcus sis et alium defraudes, vel profusus etaequolargior, quod tibimetipsi damnum ferat. Hoc dictum, quum venit in proverbii consuetudinem, monet medium inter opposita vitia utrimque reductum debere servari.’ The details are less certain. κρούειν, ‘to knock, strike,’ cones a fraudulent act in connexion with measuring in the compounds κρουσιμετρεῖν and παρακρουσιχοίνικος (Poll. 4. 169). The former of these is interpreted ῾to cheat in selling corn by knocking the measure and spilling the grain’ (Neil Ar. Eq. 859 κρουσιδημῶν). This appears to be the meaning indicated by Harpocation. It should however be mentioned that there was another method of cheating, in which εἰσκρούω (if not κρούω) was employed. This was to beat inwards the bottom of the measure, so that it held less: cf. Pherecr. fr. 105 (I 173 K.) μὲν τῆς χοίνικος τὸν πύνδακ᾿ εἰσέκρουσεν, Theophr. char. 30 (26 J.) Φειδωνίῳ μέτρῳ τὸν πύνδακα ἐγκεκρουμένῳ (surely we should read εἰσκεκρουμένῳ, with Edmonds and Diels) μετρεῖν αὐτὸς τοῖς ἔνδον, σφόδρα ἀποψῶν, τὰ ἐπιτήδεια, where J. renders ‘with the bottom dinted inward.’ As applied to weighing, it means ῾to depress (the scale)’: Phocyl. 13 κρούειν σταθμὸν ἑτερόζυγον. Sophocles is not concerned with that, but it is possible that the variant ὑπὸ χεῖρα in Harpocration may be due to the influence of another quotation μὴ σταθμὸν κρούσῃς μηδ’ ὑπὸ χεῖρα βάλῃς. in which depressing and lifting the scales
were contrasted. Blaydes wished to read κρούσῃ, as if from κρούομαι used like παρακρούομαι.

μήθ᾿ ὑπὲρ χεῖλος βάλῃς, ‘don't overtop the rim.’ is a clear case of tmesis in the stricter sense of the term; i.e., it cannot be explained except through the compound ὑπερβάλλειν. See on frs. 679, 799. For the general sense J. quotes Luc. ev. 6. 38 μέτρον καλὸν πεπιεσμένον σεσαλευμένον ὑπερεκχυννόμενον, where it should be observed that σαλεύω has an entirely different intention from that of διασείω in Harpocration. Neil on Ar. Eq. 814 points out that ὑπερχειλής means quite full, not running over, since χεῖλος is ῾the lip in the proper sense, the saucer-like part above the neck of the vessel.᾿ Cf. A.Ρ. 12 168 μεστὸν ὑπὲρ χείλους πίομαι. H. adds Ρrον. app. 3. 89 (Paroetn. I 433) μέχρι τῶν ἀμθωτίδων· ἐπὶ τῶν ἄγαν πεπληρωμένων, ἀντὶ τοῦ μέχρι τῶν ὤτων.
797 Herodian π. μον. λέξ. p. 34, 3 ἢ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ‘ὁ σκέπαρνος. . . πληγαί.’ ὅτι γὰρ καὶ ὁ πραγικὸς λέγει σκέπαρνος ἐπ᾿ εὐθείας ἀρσενικῆς ἐν ἑτέροις ἐδήλωσα.

Herodian’s position is that no genitive ending in νος has ρ before it, with the exception of ἀρνός. Then he proceeds: ahiop δὲ τὸ πάθος, following as above. Lehrs altered ἤ to τό and added after the quotation οὐκ ἀντίκειται, thus making Bloch's οὐ not merely plausible but necessary. Egenolff however (Rh. Mus. LVI 291) inserts after πάθος Etym. Μ. p. 146, 19 ἔστι γὰρ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀρήν ἀρῆνος, κατὰ συγκοπὴν ἀρνός, καὶ μετάγεται ἡ γενικὴ εἰς εὐθεῖαν, and continues ᾗ <καὶ τὸ> παρὰ Σ. Undoubtedly this is explanation of πάθος, as Lehrs had pointed out. But I cannot follow Egenolff’s further contention that his reconstruction forbids the change of ὁ to οὐ on the ground that the following remark ὅτι γὰρ κτἑ. would in that case be meaningless. σκέπαρνος: σκέπαρνον is quoted as a new nominative parallel to the supposed development of ἀρνός. In itself οὐ is a great improvement, and recalls Ant. 249.
798 Herodian π. μον. λέξ. p. 42, 24 μάτη· ἔνθεν καὶ γενικὴ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ· ῾οὔτι τοι μέτρον μάτας.’

Wolff for metrical reasons ingeniously proposed to insert the fragment before Soph. Ai. 870: but the meaning ‘search,’ which his suggestion requires, although supported by the schol. on Aesch. Suppl. 827, is rejected by recent critics of that passage (Headlam rendered ῾clamorous lewdness’), and should not be here.
For μέτρον cf. El. 236 καὶ τι μέτρον κακότητος ἔφυ;

lg.l: ἐγὼ δ᾿ ἐρῶ σοι δεινὸν οὐδέν, οὔθ᾿ ὅπως
οὔθ᾿ ὡς ὁ Τυδεὺς ἀνδρὸς αἷμα συγγενὲς
κτείνας ἐν Ἄργει ξεῖνος ὢν οἰκίζεται,
οὔθ᾿ ὡς πρὸ Θηβῶν ὠμοβρὼς ἐδαίσατο
τὸν Ἀστάκειον παῖδα διὰ κάρα τεμών.

div.p: 799. 3 οὔθ᾿ Brunck: οὐδ᾿ codd. ὠμοβρῶτα vel ὠμοβρότως codd.

799 Herodian περὶ σχημάτων p. 57 58 ed. Dind. (Rhet. Gr. vni 601 Walz) ἀστεϊσμὸς δέ ἐστι προσποίησις πιθανὴ τοῦ μὴ γέγειν ἢ μνημονεύειν ἡμᾶς ἃ ὡς παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ εἰσῆκται λέγων Ὀδυσσεὺς τῷ Διομήδει· ‘ἐγὼ . . .τεμών.’ The usual name given to this common rhetorical figure is παράλειψις: see Demetr. de eloc. 263. The Latin renderings are declinatio or occultatio (Cic. de or 3. 207; or. 135, with Sandys’s note).

The passage was unhesitatingly referred by Brunck to the Ἀχαιῶν σύλλογος (i.e. the Σύνδειπνοι); and he was followed by Dindorf, Nauck and Cobet (Coll. Crit. p. 202) On the other hand, Welcker (p. 150) and Wilamowitz assign it to the Λάκαιναι, because that play relates to the stealing of the Palladium, and nowhere else do we hear of a quarrel between Diomedes and Odysseus. The facts, which have been already described (11 p. 35), are recorded in order to explain the proverb Διομήδεια Διομήδειος) ἀνάγκη by Zenob. 3. 8 (Paroem. I 59), schol. Plat. rep. 493 D, Suid. s.v., and (with an important variation) by Conon 34.
1 ἐρῶ σοι. Cobet (Coll. Crit. p. requires σε, but the change is unnecessary, especially as Odysseus is addressing Diomedes. F. W. Schmidt conj. σ’ ὄνειδος.

2 φυγάς. Diomedes was a native of Aetolia Ψ 471 Αἰτωλὸς γενεήν, μετὰ δ’ Ἀργείοισιν ἀνάσσει), and was merely a denizen in Argos: in fact, he inherited his father’s disability ν. infra). After the conclusion of the expedition of the Epigoni, he visited Aetolia in order to avenge the wrongs of his grandfather Oeneus upon the sons of Agrius, but never returned as a permanent inhabitant: see Ephorus (FHG I 240) ap. 462, Pausan. 2. 25. 2, Apollod. 1. 78. 6 οὔθ᾿ Haun.: οὐδ᾿ ceteri | ὠμοβρὼς Brunck: That πατρῴας χθονός refers to Aetolia and not to Argos is clear from Eur. fr. 558. The perf. ἐξελήλασαι ῾art an exile’) expresses maintenance of result (Gildersleeve, § 228). Nauck quotes O.C. 1292 and Eur. Hel. 90. Blaydes strangely says ῾correxerim ἐξελήλαμαι.᾿ J. was inclined to explain the passage as alluding to the story mentioned by Lycophron (610 ff.) and others, that Diomedes was driven from Argos owing to the infidelity and treachery of his wife Aegialia. But he is obliged to suppose that Sophocles placed this incident earlier than the Trojan war, a supposition which conflicts not merely with the authorities containing the story, but also with the principal features of the story itself.

3 Τυδεύς, the son of the Aetolian Oeneus, after slaying his father’s brother, Alcathous (other versions named other relatives), fled to King Adrastus at Argos, and married his daughter Deipyle, who became the mother of Diomedes. Subsequently, he joined the expedition of the Seven against Thebes. See Apollod. 1. 76.—συγγενές: Brunck's συγγενοῦς is unnecessary, for ἀνδρὸς αἷμα forms a single notion: cf. Ant. γρῦ τόδε νεῖκος ἀνδρῶν ξύναιμον.

4 κτείνας governing αἷμα is a bold experiment in language, for which it is not easy to find an exact parallel. J. defends it by quoting Ο. Τ. 996 πατρῷον αἷμα χερσὶ ταῖς ἐμαῖς ἑλεῖν. The analogy would be more complete, if we gave to ἑλεῖν there the meaning ‘to destroy, conquer,’ rather than ‘to achieve.’ Cf. Verg. Αen. 11. 82 caeso sparsurus sanguine flammam. It is dangerous to condemn expressions which we cannot analyse with certainty: thus neither in Aesch. Theb. 705 ἀλλ᾿ αὐτάδελφον αἷμα δρέψασθαι
θέλεις; nor in Eur. Hclid. 583 καρδία σφαγήσεται (n.) is the intention of the metaphor obvious. Besides these examples αἷμ᾿ ἐπισφάζειν (Eur. Εl. 92, 281) does not seem remarkable. We ought, however, to distinguish the cases where αἷμα appears to have acquired the force of φόνος (bloodshed), as Eur. Or. 284 εἴργασται δ᾿ ἐμοὶ μητρῷον αἷμα, ib. 89 αἷμα κατήνυσεν, ib. 406 ὁ συνδρῶν αἷμα, O.C. 407, Pind. Pyth. 2. 32, Bacch. 837 ἀλλ᾿ αἷμα θήσεις ξυμβαλὼν βάκχαις μάχην. Nauck accepts, and Dind. approves, Herwerden’s πράξας, for which cf. Eur. Or. 1139 κακῆς γυναικὸς οὕνεχ᾿ αἷμ᾿ ἐπράξαμεν. Papageorgius, coll. Eur. Suppl. 148, proposed φεύγων; Blaydes, χέας.—οἰκίζεται (historic present), ‘settled.’ For ξεῖνος see Jebb on O.C. 1014.

5 f. ὠμοβρὼς κτἑ. The story is told by Apollod. 3. 75 f. After the death of Capaneus and the first repulse of the Argives, Eteocles and Polynices met in single combat, and both fell. The armies then renewed the struggle, in the course of which Melanippus, one of the sons of Astacus (κεδνὸν Ἀστακοῦ τέκνον, Αesch. Theb. 394), mortally wounded Tydeus. Hereupon, Athena obtained from Zeus a specific (φάρμακον) in order to make Tydeus immortal. But the Argive seer Amphiaraus, who hated Tydeus for forcing on the expedition, thwarted the purpose of Athena by cutting off the head of Melanippus, whom Tydeus with his last effort had slain, and bringing it to the dying Tydeus. Tydeus cut the head open and swallowed the brain (τὴν Μελανίππου κεφαλὴν ἀποτεμὼν ἔδωκεν αὐτῷ· ὁ δὲ διελών, τὸν ἐγκέφαλον ἐξερρόφησεν Αpollod. l.c.). Athena, horrorstricken, revoked her purpose of giving him immortality—a boon which she afterwards conferred on his son Diomedes. Cf. Eur. fr. 537 (from the Meleager, a prophecy concerning Tydeus) εἰς ἀνδροβρῶτας ἡδονὰς ἀφίξεται, | κάρηνα πυρσσῖς γένυσι Μελανίππου σπάσας: ’ he shall come to know cannibal joys, when he has clutched the head of Melanippus with his red-bearded jaws’ (J.). Schol. Ar. Αν. 1536 παρὰ Βακχυλίδῃ (fr. 45 J.) ἡ Ἀθηνᾶ τῷ Τυδεῖ δώσουσα τὴν ἀθανασίαν. Lycophron 1066 τοῦ κρατοβρῶτος παιδὸς ἀτρέστου κάπρου, where Tydeus is called κάπρος (cf. Eur. Suppl. 146 ff.). There can be no doubt that this incident came from the epic (Thebais): see Bethe, Thebanische Heldenlieder, p. 62.—ὠμοβρώς is Brunck’s necessary correction for ὠμοβρῶτ᾿. —ἐδαίσατο: so El. 542 f. ἢ τῶν ἐμῶν Ἅιδης τιν᾿ ἵμερον τέκνων | ἢ τῶν ἐκείνης ἔσχε δαίσασθαι πλέον;—διὰ κάρα τεμών. Tmesis is for the most part only employed by Sophocles at the beginning οf a clause, and where the preposition is immediately followed by δέ or some similar word : see Kuehner-Gerth i 534. and Jebb’s notes on Ο.Τ. 199, Αnt. 106, Phil. 817. As contrasted with fr. 796 this is tmesis in the larger sense : but see on fr. 679. Welcker proposed διακαρατομῶν; but no change is necessary, as the text is completely justified by fr. 271, 5 διὰ κῦμα τεμών. Cobet (V.L. p. 90) illustrates the statement of Phot. lex. p. 418, 4 περὶ κάτω τραπήσεται· ἀντὶ τοῦ περιτραπήσεται κάτω, συνήθως λέγουσιν.

H. renders as follows : ’But I’ll Say nothing hard of thee; I will not say How thou wast banished from thy fatherland, How Tydeus, for an act of kindred blood. Left home and dwelt in Argos; I’ll not speak Οf that raw meal he made before Thebes’ walls On the cleft head of young Astacides !’
800 Λυδική Hesych. iii p. 53 | προσηγάγου Musurus: προσ. γάγου cod.

800 Hesych. ii p. 286 Ἡρακλεία λίθος· ἢν ἔνιοι μαγνῆτιν λέγουσιν, οὐκ ὀρθῶς· διαλλάττουσι <γάρ>, καὶ ἡ μὲν ἐπισπωμένη τὸν σίδηρον Ἡρακλεία ἐστίν, ἡ δὲ ἐτέρα παραπλήσιος ἀργύρῳ. ὥστε Πλάτων ἁμαρτάνει τὴν αὐτὴν ὑπολαμβάνων μαγνῆτιν καὶ Ἡρακλείαν ἐν Ἴωνι (533 D). καὶ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἀλλαχοῦ ἑτέρως καὶ ἑτέραν φησί (Tim. 80 C hardly satisfies the reference). κέκληται δὲ οὕτως ἀπὸ Ἡρακλείας, τῆς ἐν Λυδίᾳ πόλεως. διὸ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς Λυδίαν λίθον αὐτὴν καλεῖ. Cf. iii p. 53 Λυδία λίθος· ἡ βασανίζουσα τὸν χρυσόν. ibid. Λυδικὴ λίθος σίδηρον τηλό-
θεν προσηγάγου. αὕτη γὰρ τὸν σίδηρον ἐπισπᾶται, ἡ δὲ μαγνῆτις διαπατᾷ (so Heindorf for διασπᾶσσι) τὴν ὄψιν, ὡς δοκεῖν ἀργύριον εἶναι. Buttmann inferred with reason that the verse quoted under Λυδία λίθος belonged to Sophocles.

This is the earliest allusion to the loadstone in Greek literature, and apparently the only extant passage where it is called Λυδία λίθος, a description which is elsewhere applied to the touchstone: Bacchyl. fr. 10 J. (14 Bl.) Λυδία μὲν γὰρ λίθος μανύει χρυσόν. At the time when Sophocles wrote the substance was not sufficiently familiar to have acquired a fixed name: Plato in the Ion, l.c., says that Euripides gives the name Μαγνῆτις to what most people call Ἡρακλεία. It is incredible that Plato was mistaken; and he was probably alluding to Eur. fr. 567, a passage which, though corrupt, clearly refers to the magnet, in spite of Suidas and some modern authorities. The theory of the lexicographers (Hesych. supra, Zenob. 4. 22, Phot. Suid. s.v. Ἡρακλεία λίθος) that Μαγνῆτις was a misnomer as applied to the magnet, and that it ought to be confined to the silver-like stone, appears to be derived from Theophrastus de lap. 41 ἡ μαγνῆτις αὕτη λίθος ἡ καὶ ὄψει περιτνὸν (qu. ὄψιν περιττὴν) ἔχουσα καὶ ἧς γε δὴ τινες θαυμάζουσι τὴν ὁμοίωσιν τῷ ἀργυρῷ μηδαμῶς οὔσης συγγενοῦς. It is not at all clear to me that the later theory does not rest on a misunderstanding of Theophrastus' words. He only mentions the appearance of the μαγνῆτις incidentally, and there is nothing to show that he was not speaking of our ῾magnet.’ It should be observed that in § 4 he specifies ἤ τε καλουμένη λίθος ἡρακλεία καὶ ἡ λυδή as touchstones, and gives no name to the stone which he describes as drawing iron in § 29. This last may have been his fiayvrJTis, which he does not define or mention except in § 41. Anyhow, Eubulus (c. 375 B.C.) agreed with Euripides (fr. 77, 11 192 K.); and Μαγνῆτις λίθος soon became an established term. Whether Sophocles had the town Heraclea— or the district Magnesia (Lucr. 6. 908 f.) —definitely in his mind cannot be determined; he may have simply thought of the stone as an Eastern marvel.

J. took the view that ὡς or some other word of comparison preceded the quotation, but this is unnecessary. The verse is, in fact, an excellent illustration of the idiom according to which a simile is expressed by mere juxtaposition without a comparative conjunction: ῾even as the magnet draws iron, you have attracted from ....’ Cf. Theogn. 1361 πέτρῃ προσέκυρσας ἐμῆς φιλότητος ἁμαρτών, Aesch. From. 882 οἳ δ’ ἐπτοημένοι φρένας, | κίρκοι πελειῶν οὐ μακρὰν λελειμμένοι, Theopomp. fr. 40 (l 744 K.) ἣν ἐκπιοῦσ᾿ ἄκρατον ἀγαθοῦ δαίμονος | τέττιξ κελαδεῖ. See Shorey in Class. Phil. IV 433, Starkie on Ar. yesp. 144. It follows that σίδηρον is not the real, even if the grammatical, object of προσηγάγου, and we shall perhaps not go far wrong in guessing that the simile was actually applied to the attraction of love: see Α. Ρ. 12. 152 Μάγνης Ἡράκλειτος, ἐμὸς πόθος, οὐχὶ σίδηρον | πέτρῳ, πνεῦμα δ’ ἐμὸν κάλλει ἐφελκόμενος. Achill. Tat. 1. 17 ἐρᾷ γοῦν ἡ μαγνησία λίθος τοῦ σιδήρου· κἂν μόνον ἴδῃ καὶ θίγῃ, πρὸς αὑτὴν εἵλκυσεν, ὥσπερ ἐρωτικόν τι ἔν δον ἔχουσα. So Milton P. R. 2. 166 Draw out with credulous desire, and lead | at will the manliest, resolutest breast, | as the magnetic hardest iron draws.
801 Hesych. III p. 203 ὀμμάτειος πόθος· διὸ τὸ ἐκ τοῦ ὁρᾶν ἁλίσκεσθαι ἔρωτι. ῾ἐκ τοῦ γὰρ ἐσορᾶν γίνεται ἀνθρώποις ἐρᾶν.᾿ καὶ ἐν Ἀχιλλέως ἐρασταῖς (fr. 157).

Ellendt acutely inferred that the words ὀμμάτειος πόθος are to be attributed to Sophocles on the ground that, while no authority is named for them, the way in which the reference to fr. 157 is introdiced shows that a mention of Sophocles must have preceded. Nauck assents; but the conclusion, though probable, is far from certain. The line ἐκ τοῦ γὰρ ἐσορᾶν κτἑ. is often cited by the Paroemiographi: see Diogen. 4. 49 with Leutsch’s note, who should not however have stated that it was written by Sophocles. For the eyes as the source of love see on fr. 474 and cf. Trach. 106 βλεφάρων πόθον, Ant. 795 βλεφάρων ἵμερος, Eur. Hipp. 525 Ἔρως, ὃ κατ᾿ ὀμμάτων στάζεις πόθον.
802 Hesych. III p. 420 quoted on fr. 699.

Although the evidence seems to justify the attribution of these words to Sophocles, there is a certain preciosity about the phrase (‘goads that smite instead of stabbing’) which is scarcely characteristic of him. It is built upon passages like Aesch. Pers. 399 κώπης ῥοθιάδος ξυνεμβολῇ | ἔπαισαν ἅλμην, Eur. Ι.Τ. 1391. For the adjective cf. Hesych. ibid, ῥακτήρια· τυμπανα.
803 Hesych. ΙV p. 17 σειρίου κυνὸς δίκην. Σοφοκλῆς τὸν ἀστρῷον κύνα· ὁ Ἀρχίλοχος (fr. 61) τὸν ἥλιον, Ἴβυκος δὲ (fr. 3) πάντα τὰ ἄστρα.
The constellation Sirius is among the few mentioned in the early Epic (Gruppe, p. 936). In Horn. X 29 it is described as κύν᾿ Ὠρίωνος. Cf. Aesch. Ag. 958 σκιὰν ὑπερτείνασα σειρίου κυνός.
The general meaning of creCpios is attested by Eratosth. catast. 33 (Sirius) μέγας δ’ ἐστὶ καὶ λαμπρός· τοὺς δὲ τοιούτους ἀστέρας οἱ ἀστρολόγοι σειρίους καλοῦσι.
804 Hesych. IV p. 20 σεμνὰ τῆς σῆς παρθένου μυστήρια. Σοφοκλῆς. τὰ ἄρρητα καὶ ἀνεξήγητα μυστήρια. Cf. Phot. lex. p. 503, 22 σεμνά· τὰ ἄρρητα μυστήρια· οἳ δὲ ἐπὶ τοῦ ἡσύχου καὶ καταστύγνου.

The words seem to be addressed to Demeter, and the reference is doubtless to the Eleusinia: Μ. Schmidt aptly compares carni. pop. 46. 5 (PLG III 675) χἣ μὲν τὰ σεμνὰ τῆς Κόρης μυστήρια. There is thus high probability in Welcker’s view that the passage comes fiom the Triptolemus. The lexicographers unduly attempt to force the meaning of σεμνός, which simply means ‘dread,’ ‘holy’: it is applied to the mysteries in the same manner as to other formal rites. Cf. Ο.C. 1050 οὗ πότνιαι σεμνὰ τιθηνοῦνται τέλη βροτοῖσιν, Eur. Hipp. 25 σεμνῶν ἐς ὄψιν καὶ τέλη μυστηρίων, Track. 765 σεμνῶν ὀργίων, Aesch. fr. 57 σεμνὰ Κοτυτοῦς ὄργι᾿ ἔχοντες, Eum. 1007 σφαγίων τῶνδ᾿ ὑπὸ σεμνῶν. Eur. Suppl. 470 σεμνὰ στεμμάτων μυστήρια awaits elucidation, and is perhaps corrupt.—Wagner thought that the missing word at the beginning of the line was τά or ὡς.—τῆς σῆς παρθένου: the possessive pronoun is boldly used with παρθένος as in Ο. Τ. 1462, ’thy daughter.’ Euripides adds a possessive genitive (Wilamowitz on Her. 834). Erotian, p. 106, 16, glosses it with θυγάτηρ.

805 lohannes Sicel. ap. Walz Rhet. VI 225 φαίνεται δὲ ἡ ἀτοπία τοῦ ποιητοῦ (sc. Αἰσχύλου) μᾶλλον ἐν τῷ τῆς Ὠρειθυίας δράματι, ὅπου ταῖς δυσὶ σιαγόσι φυσῶν ὁ Βορέας κυκᾷ τὴν θάλασσαν (fr. 281)· γὰρ φέρω ἐπὶ μνήμης τὸ ἰαμβεῖα ἐπιλαθόμενος· διὸ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς μιμεῖται οὐ μιμεῖται Ruhnken, μωμεῖται Jannarakis,
μέμφεται conj. Nauck). λέγει δὲ περὶ τούτων ἀκριβέστερον Λογγῖνος ἐν τῷ κα τῶν Φιλολόγων.

The most that can be inferred from this passage is that Sophocles either introduced Boreas as a character in one of his plays, or described his proceedings. Some hold that he wrote an Orithyia, for which see on fr. 768. Others, admitting that Boreas was mentioned as the father of Orithyia, think that sufficient occasion was provided in the Tympanistae or Phineus. Wilamowitz in Hermes X 334 n. regards lohannes as an ignorant impostor, and thinks that the reference to Sophocles may be, either directly or indirectly, merely a reflexion from Plut. prof. virt. 7 p. 79 B. I incline to the view that the passage has no independent value, and that it should probably be treated as a testimonium to fr. 768. It is then nothing more than a very imperfect' recollection of the de sublim., or of a passage from the Φιλόλογοι to the same effect, and μιμεῖται, if sound, means not that Sophocles imitated Aeschylus, but that he also used the figure of the fluteplayer. For μιμεῖσθαι in this sense see Bywater on Arist. poet. 1. 1447a 16.
806 Lex. Sabbait. (ed. Papadopulos- Kerameus, Petersburg 1892) ἄφθονος ἄγρα. Σοφοκλῆς ‘λαβόντες. . . ἄξομεν.’

‘Blest by fortune, we will drive home the rich booty we have taken.’ The two participles are awkwardly combined: see on Eur. Hel. 597. For λαβόντε. . . ἄξομεν cf. Eur. Hclid. 267 ἄξω γε μέντοι τοὺς ἐμοὺς ἐγὼ λαβών.— Nauck was inclined to substitute ἐς for πρός, but surely in a suitable context either might stand (Phil. 488).

lg.l: ζημίαν λαβεῖν ἄμεινόν ἐστιν ἢ κέρδος κακόν

div.p: 807 ἄμεινόν ἐστι ζημίαν λαβεῖν cod.: corr. Meineke et Μ. Schmidt

807 Lex. Vindob. p. 96, 4 ζημίαν λαβεῖν· ἀντὶ τοῦ ζημιωθῆναι. Σοφοκλῆς· ‘ἄμεινόν ἐστι. . . κακόν.’ Phot. lex. p. 53 25 ζημίαν λαβεῖν· ἀντὶ τοῦ ζημιωθῆναι. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. The same gloss occurs in Antiatt. (Bekk. anecd.) p. 98, 7, but without the words οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς.

The tranposition made in the order of the words (see cr. n.) in order to produce a trochaic tetrameter is highly probable; for the tradition is unmetrical and must in any case be corrected. For the nature of the error see on fr. 941, 10.

ζημίαν λαβεῖν is usually illustrated by [Dem.] 11. 11 (a poor authority in any case), where the reading is doubtful. For λαβεῖν cf. Track. 254 τοῦτο τοὔνειδος λαβών = ‘being so disgraced.’ The is to suffer loss (daninum accipere); and EUendt is mistaken in saying ‘poenam, non noxam, interpretaberis.’ is the antithesis of κέρδος (Xen. Cyr. 2. 2. 12, Arist. eth. N. 5. 4. 1232a 10 ff.), and some grammarians derived it from ζῆν and μείωσις (Etym. Μ.). The whole line is simply a re-shaping of the proverbial saying that ἄτη attends κακὸν κέρδος: Hes. Op. 352 μὴ κακὰ κερδαίνειν· κακὰ κέρδεα ἶσ᾿ ἄτῃσι. It was popularly attributed to Chilon (Diels Vorsokr.3 II p. 215 25 ζημίαν αἱροῦ μᾶλλον ἢ κέρδος αἰσχρόν· τὸ μὲν γὰρ ἅπαξ λυπήσει, τὸ δὲ ἀεί), and is echoed in Ant. 312 ff. οὐκ ἐξ ἅπαντος δεῖ τὸ κερδαίνειν φιλεῖν. | ἐκ τῶν γὰρ αἰσχρῶν λημμάτων τοὺς πλείονας | ἀτωμένους ἴδοις ἂν ἢ σεσωσμένους, ib. 326, 1326 εἴ τι κέρδος ἐν κακοῖς, Ai. 1349 μὴ χαῖρ᾿, Ἀτρείδη, κέρδεσιν τοῖς μὴ καλοῖς, Eur. Cycl. 312 πολλοῖσι γὰρ | πονηρὰ κέρδη ζημίαν ἠμείψατο, fr. 459 κέρδη τοιαῦτα χρή τινα κτᾶσθαι βροτῶν, | ἐφ᾿ οἷσι μέλλει μήποθ᾿ ὕστερον στένειν. Nauck quotes
from the sent. sept. sap. v. 99 ed. Woelfflin: πρόκορινε κέρδους τοῦ πονηροῦ ζημίαν. Add Boisson. anecd. Ill 470 ζημίαν αἱροῦ μᾶλλον ἢ ὅθεν οὐ δεῖ κέρδος. The paradox of the Gorgias (508 b) τὸ ἀδικεῖν τοῦ ἀδικεῖσθαι κάκιον is on a different ethical plane from the homely proverb here quoted. Contrast Ο. T. 595 τὰ σὺν κέρδει καλά, where honour and profit coincide, id. 889 κερδανεῖ δικαίως.
808 Libanius decl. ΙΙΙ 365 R. (=IV 450 Foerster) τὴν αὐτὴν τῷ Σοφοκλεῖ φωνὴν ἀφιείς· λέγει γὰρ δή που κἀκεῖνος ‘ὅτι ...ἐξέλοις.᾿

The permanence of natural attributes is a commonplace: Hor. Epist. 1. 10. 24 naturam expellas furca tamen usque recurret, Jun. 239 tamen ad mores natura recurrit | damnatos fixa et mutari nescia (Mayor’s n.). The saw is often combined with a warning of the precariousness of fortune’s gifts see on fr. 194. Cf Eur. fr. 810 μέγιστον ἆρ᾿ ἦν ἡ φύσις· τὸ γὰρ κακὸν | οὐδεὶς τρέφων εὖ χρηστὸν ἂν θείη ποτέ, 904 ἀλλ᾿ ἄκρας εὐηθίας | ἄπτοιτ᾿ ἂν ὅστις τὴν φύσιν νικᾶν θέλει. Libanius quotes Eur. Or. 126 and Hec. 596.
1 ἀνέρι = ἀνθρώπῳ, as in Ant. 768 (Jebb's n.). See also on Eur. Hclid. 609.—For the subjunctive without ἄν see on fr. 659, 4.

On the assumption that the cola are complete, we can hardly avoid the conclusion that there is a triple beat in each line. An anapaestic tripody does not often occur in tragedy, but there is a similar metrical combination in Aesch. Pers. 955 f. νυχίαν πλάκα κερσάμενος | δυσδαίμονά τ᾿ ἀρχάν, where the second line is the so-called Reizianum (Eur. Phoen. p. 232) In other conditions the second line might have been scanned as a dimeter (acephalous glyconic), but it appears as a tripody (prosodiac) in Ο.Τ. 868 f. and elsewhere: see Schroeder’s remarks in Soph. Cant. p. 70.
809 Menander ap. Walz Rhet. IX 156, discussing the class of hymns known as διαπορητικοί, ὥσπερ καὶ τὴν Τύχην Σοφοκλῆς ὕμνησε διαπορῶν γένει.

Nauck prints this with the tragic fragments, but it may well be thought that it should rather find a place with the παιᾶνες (PLG II 248). For the class of hymns known as διαπορητικοί, see Smyth, Greei Melic Poets, p. 356: ‘The figure of thought σχῆμα διανοίας) entitled airopla or διαπόρησις (dubitatio) is particularly suited to the beginning of a poem, where the poet can best feign embarrassment in the presence of over-abundant material.’ Good examples are Pind. Isth. 7 and fr. 29, and Lyr. fr. adesp. 84 (PLG III 713).

The conception of Fortune as a goddess of incalculable Chance as contrasted with foresight is comparatively late: see the anonymous poem preserved in Stob. ecl. 1. 6. 13 p. 86, 4 W, (PLG III 732). Passages like Ο.Τ. 977, Ant. 1158, are insufficient to prove that Sophocles would have addressed Τύχη herself as capricious or inconstant. The Pindaric references are unfortunately fragmentary: cf. Pausan. 4. 30. 6 ᾗσε δὲ Πίνδαρος ἄλλα τε ἐς τὴν Τύχην καὶ δὴ καὶ φερέπολιν ἀνεκάλεσεν αὐτήν. See also on fr. 314, 73.
810 Philodemus de piet. p. 36 G. νοσοῦντα πεποι <ἡ> τ<ὸν> Ἡρακλέ <α> . . . τὸν δ᾿ Ἡρακλέα καὶ μα <νίᾳ> κατά <σ>χετον, <ὡς> Σοφοκλῆς <καὶ Ε> ὐριπίδης.

We know of no play of Sophocles dealing with the story presented in the Ηeracles of Euripides. Wilamowitz (Eur. Her. I p. 138 35) is probably right in supposing that the reference is to the concluding portion of the Trachiniae, from which he quotes v. 999 τόδ᾿ ἀκήλητον μανίας ἄνθος. Gomperz originally gave καὶ μάλ᾿ ἀκατάσχετον, but M. Schmidt’s restoration adopted above is doubtless right.

lg.l: ὅρκους ἐγὼ γυναικὸς εἰς ὕδωρ γράφω

div.p: 811 Hellad. in Phot. bibl. p. 530a 15 ὁ στίχος ὁ καὶ παροιμιαζόμενος ‘ὁρκους . . . γράφω᾿ ἐστὶ μὲν Σοφοκλέους, τοῦτον δὲ παρῳδήσας ὁ Φιλωνίδης (fr. 7, i 256 K.) ἔφη ‘ὅρκους δὲ μοιχῶν εἰς τέφραν ἐγὼ γράφω.’ [For the explanation of this verse see Starkie on Ar. Nub. 1083.] οἱ δὲ τὰς γυναῖκας σκώπτοντες φασίν ‘ὅρκους ἐγὼ γυναικῶν εἰς οἶκτον (leg. γυναικὸς εἰς οἶνον Αthen. 441 E) γράφω᾿ (Xenarchus fr. 6, ii 470 K.). Macar. 6. 48 ὅρκους γυναικὸς εἰς ὕδωρ χρὴ γράφειν. Σοφοκλέους αὕτη ἐστίν.

It is impossible to write in water, and useless to attempt it: see Diogen. 5. 83, Plut. prov. 5 (Paroem. I 267, 344). Cf. Plat. Phaedr. 276 c oὐκ ἄρα σπουδῇ αὐτὰ ἐν ὕδατι γράψει. Philostr. imag. 2. 10 2 oὐκ ὄναρ ταῦτα, ὦ Κρηθηίς, οὐδ᾿ ἐς ὕδωρ τὸν ἔρωτα τοῦτον γράφεις. Apostol. 6. 56. Lucian catapl. 21 παίζεις, ὦ Χάρων, ἢ καθ᾿ ὕδατος, φασί, γράφεις; Cic. de fin. 2. 72 virtutibus, quarum omnia fundamenta vos in voluptate tanquam in aqua ponitis. A woman’s oath is as little likely to be permanent as writing in water : Phryn. praep. soph. p. ρ5, 16 (Bekk. anecd. p. 55 17) ὅρκον γυναικὸς εἰς ὕδωρ χρὴ γράφειν. ὅτι ἀπιστεῖν γυναικὶ δεῖ ὀμνυούσῃ. Catull. 70. 3 mulier cupido quod dicit amanti | in vento et rapida scribere oportet aqua. Similarly of other untrustworthy persons: Menand. mon. 25 ἀνδρῶν δὲ φαύλων ὅρκον εἰς ὕδωρ γράφε. Julian p. 286 C ἐγὼ δὲ τοὺς μὲν ὅρκους αὐτοῖς, τὸ τῆς παροιμίας, οἶμαι δεῖν εἰς τέφραν γράφειν. Ioh. Georgides in Bossion. anecd. i p. 96 χρὴ τὴν μὲν ἔχθραν εἰς ὕδωρ γράφειν, ἵνα ταχέως ἀφανίζηται, τὴν δὲ φιλίαν εἰς χαλκόν, ἵνα διὰ παντὸς μένῃ. Especially of lovers: Anth. Pal. 5. 7 νῦν δ᾿ ὃ μὲν ὅρκιά φησιν ἐν ὕδατι κεῖνα φέρεσθαι. Cf. Prop. 2. 28. 8. The proverbial Ἀφροδίσιος ὅρκος οὐκ ἐμποίνιμος is said to go back to Hesiod (fr. 187): Plat. Phil. 65 C, Symp. 183 B with the schol.
812 Phot. lex. p. 484, 13 ῥάχοι· αἱ μυρίκιναι ῥάχοισιν ὀρχάδος στέγης.᾿ Σοφοκλῆς δὲ τοὺς φραγμοὺς τῆς ποίμνης.

The extract is mutilated. A. Ludwich suggested that the quotation was ῥόχοισιν σιν ὀρχάδος στέγης δετοὺς φραγμούς, but, scansion apart, the phrase is overloaded : and what becomes of τὴς ποίμνης? M. Schmidt inserted λέγει after Σοφοκλῆς δέ.

ῥάχοισιν: the stakes of a wooden fence, or the components of a growing hedge. Cf. Pollux i. 225 θριγκὸν περιβαλεῖν, αἱμασιὰν περιελάσασθαι, ῥάχον περιστήσασθαι. Hdt. 7. 142 ἡ γὰρ ἀκρόπολις τὸ πάλαι τῶν Ἀθηνέων ῥηχῷ ἐπέφρακτο· οἱ μὲν δὴ κατὰ τὸν φραγμὸν συνέ-
βαλλοντο τοῦτο τὸ ξύλινον τεῖχος εἶναι.— ὀρχάδος is more obscure, and its meaning can only be fixed by inference. Ellendt gives cratibus contextam or stipitibus vallatam, L. and S. enclosing,—both depending on Hesych. iii p. 225 ὀρχάς· περίβολος, αἱμασιά. καὶ εἶδος ἐλαίας. While there is no obvious connexion with ὄρχος or ὄρχατος, the indications point to an affinity to ὁρκάνη, for which see Phot. lex. p. 347, 10 ὁρκάνη· περίφραγμά ἀκανθῶδες. ὁρκάνη· ὁ τοῖχος οἴκησιν ἢ χωρίον· λέγεται δὲ ἀπὸ τοῦ ἕρκος, ὅ ἐστι περιβόλου φράγμα. Hesych. III p. 220 ὁρκάνη , . . οἰ δὲ φραγμόν. Harpocr. p. 139, 13, quoting Lycurgus (fr. 74) and Horn, ω 224. Schol. Theocr. 4. 61 μάνδραν] τὴν τῶν προβάτων ὁρκκάνην. Perhaps then we should read ὁρκάδος. ὀρχάμη is possibly a mistake for ὁρκάνη in Pollux 7. 147. Cf. 10. 131 ὁρκάνη (al. ὀρχάνη) καὶ ῥάχος . . . καὶ πάνθ᾿ ὅσα ἀκανθώδη τοῖς παρποῖς ἐπὶ φρουρὰν περιβάλλεται.
813 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 89, 3 ἀμάχετοι· Σοφοκλῆς ‘ἀμάχετοι λοχαγοί.᾿
In Phil. 198 Sophocles prefers the form ἀμάχητος. On the general question of this stem-variation see on fr. 970.

814 Phot. lex. p. 493, 3 and Suid. s. v. τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ὀβελοῦ· ἐπὶ τῶν αἱρουμένων ἀναιρουμένων Phot.) τὰ χείρονα ἀντὶ τῶν κρειττόνων. ἡ παροιμία ἀπὸ τῶν ἀπείρως δρασσομένων κατὰ τὸ πεπυρωμένον τῶν ὀβελίσκων. κέμνηται αὐτῆς Σοφοκλῆς. To the same effect Zenob. 6. 19 (Paroem. I 166).

Since in Zenobius this extract is followed by ‘ὑπὸ παντὶ λίθῳ σκορπίος’ παροιμία, Nauck was inclined to suspect that the words μέμνηται αὐτῆς Σοφοκλῆς have been misplaced, and that they really refer to fr. 37. The proverb is similar to our ‘You have got hold of the wrong end of the stick,’ i.e. the dirty end, or ‘You have the wrong sow by the ear.’

lg.l: ἄκουε σῖγα. τίς ποτ᾿ ἐν δόμοις βοή

div.p: 815 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 63, 25 ἄΚουε· ἀντὶ τοῦ σίγα. Κρατῖνος (fr. 284, I 96 K.). οἷον τόπον δίδου διὰ τῆς σιγῆς τῇ ῾<ἄκουε, σίγα,> πρόσεχε τὸν νοῦν, δεῦρ᾿ ὅρα.᾿ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς· ‘ἄκουε, σίγα, τίς ποτ᾿ ἐν δόμοι, βοή.’ The new text of Photius is a fusion of two glosses which appear separately in Bekker’s anecdota at p. 369 15 ἄκουε . . . τῇ ἀκοῇ, and at p. 372, 10 ἄκουε, σίγα· Κρατῖνος. ῾ἄκουε, σίγα, πρόσεχε . . . βοή.’

The purpose of the grammarian was to illustrate ἄκουε ‘be on the listen,’ whether enforced by the addition of σῖγα (or σίγα) or not. There is nothing to choose between σῖγα and σίγα (unless it be thought that Ar. Thesm. 381 favours the latter), and the usage of Sophocles is indecisive. I follow the punctuation of previous editors, but it is equally possible that the question is indirect after ἄκουε, and that a comma should be placed after σῖγα: so, e.g., Xen. Cyr. 2. 4. 16 ἄκουε τοίνυν, ἄν τί δοι δόξω λέγειν. Nauck, quoting other cases where the readings of our MSS do not correspond with those of citations from Euripides, concluded that the grammarian intended to refer to Eur. Hipp. 790 γυναῖκες, ἴστε τίς ποτ’ ἐν δόμοις βοή; But his scepticism is hardly warranted.

816 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 54, 3 αἱμύλος· ὁ ἔμπειρος ἢ ἡδὺς ἐν τῷ ἀπατᾶν. καὶ κόλαξ. Πλάτων (legg. 823 E) ‘αἱμύλος ἔρως’ φησὶ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς. Εὐριπίδης (fr. 1095) δὲ καὶ αἱμύλην αἱμύλη Bekk. anecd.) εἶπε θηλυκῶς, Σοφοκλῆς (At. 389) δὲ καὶ αἱμυλώτατον, Κρατῖνος (fr. 379 a b, I 119 K.) δὲ αἱμυλόφρων καὶ αἱμυλοπλόκος εἶπεν. The same gloss occurs in Bekk. anecd. p. 363. 1, except that the words Σοφοκλῆς δὲ καὶ αἱμυλώτατον are omitted.

The new text disposes of Nauck’s suggestion that the earher citation of Sophocles is intended for the passage in the Ajax. Plato’s words are μηδ’ αὖ πτηνῶν θήρας αἱμύλος Ἔρως οὐ σφόδρα ἐλευθέριος ἐπέλθοι τινὶ νέων, where Jowett renders ‘insidious’ (blandus et fallax, Stallb.). αἱμύλος in its application to ἔρως is clearly transferred from its proper connexion with a personal agent. It is most likely that Sophocles conceived the cunning of the lover as manifested in seductive speech: so Horn, α 56 αἰεὶ δὲ μαλακοῖσι καὶ αἱμυλίοισι λόγοισιν | θέλγει (sc. Calypso), ὅπως Ἰθάκης ἐπιλήσεται, where Eustathius (p. 1390,64) comments: εἶεν δ’ ἂν τῆς μὲν ἱστορουμένης Καλυψοῦς αἱμύλιοι λόγοι οἱ κατὰ ἔρωτα κολακεύοντες. καὶ οὓς ἂν εἴπη (l. γυνὴ ἐρῶσα, καὶ διὸ τοῦτο κατὰ τὸν Ἡσίοδον (Op. 374) αἱμύλα κωτίλλουσα.
817 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 53, 11 <α> ἱματοσπόδητος· Σοφοκλῆς. ‘τὸν . . . αἱματοσπόδητον.’

The fragment appears to come from a series of trochaic tetrameters, and the sense is perhaps incomplete. It seems that the statue of the god which stood before the altar is described as splashed with the blood of the victim. But it is not clear whether this happens as a normal incident of the sacrifice (Eur. Ι.Α. 1514 βωμόν γε δαίμονος θεᾶς | ῥανίσιν αἱματορρύτοις | χρανοῦσαν, Ι. T. 72 f., 226), or whether it is an exceptional outrage like that of Eur. Andr. 259 σφάζ᾿ αἱμάτου θεᾶς βωμόν, ἢ μέτεισί σε. For the use of σπόδητος cf. Eur. Andr. 1129 πυκηῇ δὲ νιδάδι πάντοθεν σποδούμενος. Rhes. 790 θερμὸς δὲ κρουνὸς . . . βάλλει με δυσθνῄσκοντος αἵματος νέου. Aesch. Ag. 1389 βάλλει μ’ ἐρεμνῇ ψακάδι φοινίας δρίσου.

818 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 68, 16 (Phryn. fr. 146 de B.) ἄκρον φρονεῖν, ἄκρον δρᾶν· οἷον ἐξέχων ἐν τῷ φρονεῖν καὶ πράττειν. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. Reitzenstein remarks that either ἄκρος or ἐξέχοντα should be read. There is the same error in Bekk. anecd. p. 372, 5, where the extract ends at ἐξέχων.

The use of ἄκρος=pre-eminent is illustrated by Blaydes on El. 1499, and Adam on Plat. rep. 366 B.
