1053 Εtym. Μ. p. 450, 50 θήλεια. . . παρὰ τὸ θάλλειν καὶ γεννᾶν· ὅθεν καὶ ἡ ὕπομβρος νὺξ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ θήλεια καλεῖται. To the same effect Etym. Gud. p. 261, 25, with νῦν for νύξ and the addition of διὸ τὸ θάλλειν ἐν αὐτῷ τοὺς καρπούς.

Possibly Sophocles wrote θήλεια νὺξ | ὕπομβρος· The adjective follows the Homeric θῆλυς ἐέρση ε 467 (schol. ἡ τρόφιμος δρόσος), where the context shows that the epithet is conventional. So Hes. Sc. 395 (τέττιξ) ᾧτε πόσις καὶ βρῶσις ἐέρση. Callim. fr. 296 θηλύτατον πέδιον, which Schneider refers to the plain of Eleusis as the scene of the story of Triptolemus. The passages quoted by L. and S. from Theophrastus are beside the mark, and the usage in question was entirely literary. Contrast ἄρσενας χοάς, fr. 523 (n.).

1054 Choerob. in Theod. p. 123 [= p. 221, 6 Hilgard] (Bekk. anecd. p. 1381) τὸ γὰρ θήλθδος παρὰ τῷ Σοφοκλεῖ κλιθὲν διὰ τοὐ δος ἠμάρτηται. Η. refers to p. 232 [= p. 231, 6 H.] (Bekk. anecd. p. 1408) πάλμυς πάλμυος· τὸ γὰρ πάλμυδος διὰ τοῦ δος κλιθὲν παρ᾿ Αἰσχίνῃ (al. Αἰσχύλῳ) ἡμάρτηται· ἔστι δὲ ὄνομα κύριον βασιλέως, where he conjectures παρ᾿ Αἰσχρίωνι, on the ground that the word πάλμυς was used by Hipponax, Callimachus, and Lycophron, and may well have belonged to Aeschrion also.

It is at first sight remarkable enough ος to find θῆλυς passing over to the υδ- stems in a writer like Sophocles, though we are not surprised when Lobeck quotes τοῦ θήλυος from Josephus (Phryn. p. 246). The introduction of δ (cf. χλαμύς, ἔπηλυς) is similar to its appearance in ι- stems (ἔριδος beside ἔριν, μήνιδος later μήνιος). It should not be forgotten that θῆλυς served originally as a feminine (Brugmann, Comp. Gr. 11 p. 335 Eng. tr.), and is actually so found eight times in Homer (Ameis-Hentze on e 467, Leaf on E 269). This may have contributed to its association with a nominal stem.
1055 Phot. ed. Reitz. p. 43, 4 = Bekk. anecd. p. 352, 16 ἄθρακτος· ἀτάραχος· καὶ τὸ συνεχύθη ἐθράχθη Σοφοκλῆς λέγει (ὡς Σοφοκλῆς Phot.). Cf. I p. 65 ἄθρακτοι· ἀτάρακτοι.

θράσσω occurs in fr. 177, as well as in Aesch. Prom. 655, Eur. fr. 600 and Rhes. 863. Cf. Pind. Isth. 6. 39. θράσσω: τραχύς and τέτρηχα shows that in the adjective the aspirates have been dissimilated. Cf. θρίξ: τριχός, θρέξομαι: τρέχω, and other examples given by King and Cookson, p. 200. ταράσσω follows ταραχὴ. ταράσσω became universal later, as is shown by Μοeris’ mistaken θράττει Ἀττικοί, ταράσσει Ἕλληνες (p. 199, 3).

1056 Etym. Μ. p. 42, 41 ἁμάρτημα τὸ παρὰ τῇ Σαπφοῖ (fr. 166) πολυΐδριδι, καὶ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ ἴδριδα (πολυΐδριδα Etym. Flor. ap. Miller, Μélanges, p. is an error) καὶ παρὰ Φρυνίχῳ (fr. 22) ἴδριδες. Schol. A Horn. Γ 219 ὁ γὰρ Σοφοκλῆς ἴδριδα ἔφη τὴν αἰτιατικὴν ὅ τε Φρύνιχος τὴν εὐθεῖαν ἴδριδες. Eustath. Il. p. 407, 38 οὐ γὰρ ἐστιν οὐδὲ τὸ ἄϊδρις παρώνυμον μακροπαράληκτον, ἵνα διὸ τοῦ δ κλίνηται· ὥστε. . . ἁμαρτάνει Σαπφὼ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς καὶ Φρύνιχος διὸ τοῦ δ κλίνοντες.

ἴδριν is accepted by modern editors in Ο. C. 525. The passing of ι- stems wholly or partially into the ιδ- class (ἔριν, ἔριδα: γλαυκῶπιν, γλαυκώπιδα) well known: see Monro, H. G.2 § 97 Giles, Manual, § 348; Brugmann, II 408 By a strange error de Borries includes this gloss in his edition of Phryn, praep. soph. p. 136.
1057 Pollux 7. 185 ἱπποφορβοί ἱπποφορβία, καὶ ὡς Σοφοκλῆς ἱπποβουκόλοι, ἱπποφορβεῖς.

It has been suggested that an error has been made in the name of the poet, and that Pollux (or his authority) intended to refer to Eur. Phoen. 28 (n). However, fr. 659, 2 makes it quite likely that Sophocles used the word.
1058 Etym. Μ. p. 500, 55 κέκονα φοκλεῖ, ἀπὸ τοῦ κτείνω. same in Etym. Gud. p. 313, 14. Cf. Choerob. in Theodos. 11 p. 78, 1 Hilgard προστιθέασι τὸ κݲ καὶ φασὶ

From this gloss Cobet (V. L. p. 322) restored κατακεκονότες in Xen. anab. 7. 6. 36 (κατακεκονότες codd. AB, vulg.). There is no difficulty in the vocalism καίνω: κέκονα, since καίνω is for ABBREV Brugmann, I 198, IV 246.
1059 Phot. lex. p. 151, 14 καῦρος (καυρός cod.)· ΚαΚὸς.

The accentuation of this word as properispomenon is attested by Arcad. p. 69, 21 τὰ εἰς ρݲοݲςݲ δισύλλαβα ἐπὶ τιθέμενα τῇ αݲυݲ διφθόγγῳ βαρύνεται, φλαῦρος, σαῦρος, καῦρος ὁ κακός. For the meaning cf. Hesycb. II p. 451 καῦρος· κακός. Etym. Μ. p. 530, 17 derives κορώνη from κρῴζω or alternatively from καῦρον ἢ γαῦρον, ὅπερ σημαίνει τὸ κακόν. The etymologer treated γαῦρος as a phonetic variation of καῦρος: ib. p. 493, 53 καῦρος· ὁ κοῦφος ταῖς φρεσί, πλεονασμῷ τοῦ κݲ, αὖρός τις ὤν· τὸν κατὰ νοῦν ἐλαφρὸν καῦρον ἐπονομάζουσι. βέλτιον γαῦρον λέγειν κτἑ. The explanation illustrates the familiar Greek confusion of foolishness with vice: see on fr. 925, and Eur. Hclid. 413. There is no probability in Nauck's proposal to substitute καῦρον for μοῦνον in Trach. 958.

1060 Etym. Μ. p. 513, 45 Κιμμερίους ...γράφεται δὲ καὶ Κερβερίων· καὶ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς περιπεπτωκέναι τῇ τοιαύτῃ γραφῇ. Cf. schol. PV Horn. λ 14 Κιμμερίων ...ἔνιοι δὲ γράφουσι χειμερίων. δὲ Κερβερίων, ὡς Κράτης. Eustath. Od. p. 1671, 1.

Schol. H. on Horn. l.c. states that Aristarchus also read Κερβερίων in that passage, so that it was undoubtedly an old variant, which Sophocles may have found in his copy of Homer. That the name was familiar at Athens is shown by Ar. Ran. 186 τίς ἐς τὸ Λήθης πεδίον ἢ εἶς ὄνου πόκας | ἢ ’ς Κερβερίους; The name Κέρβερος was said to mean ‘pallid’ (Hesych. 11 p. 467), a derivation which Gruppe, p. 4082, supports by quoting Κέρβης, the name of a river in Euboea said to make the sheep which drank of it white ([Arist.] mir. ausc. 170). The Κερβέριοι would thus be a phantom race dwelling in the Arctic north, close to the entrance of Hades.

1061 Etym. Μ. p. 514, 27 κινάκης· ἀκινάκης (‘κινάκης addunt DEM,’ παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ. τὸ μὲν γὰρ Ἀνακρεόντειον (fr. 136) χωρὶς τοῦ ἰῶτα γράφεται· γέγονεν ἔκθλιψις τοῦ ἰῶτα· καὶ κράσει τοῦ ωݲαݲ τὠκινάκῃ, ὥσπερ ὦ Ἄπολλον ὦπολλον. The last words are perhaps a reference to Aesch. Ag. 1057, and the writer means that the apparent example of κινάκης in Anacreon is not such, but a regular Ionic crasis: see Weir Smyth, Ionic Dialect, p. 263.

H. remarks: ‘Before accepting κινάκης from Sophocles, I should like to know the word that came before it.’ There a certain amount of evidence to confirm the authority of the Etym. Μ., but not of a very satisfactory character: Hesych. II p. 404 κάνακις· ξίφος, where M. Schmidt conjectured κινάκης. The Latin Thesaurus I 413 quotes Gloss. IV 215, 32 canacem gladium, and V 494, 9 caucem gladium.
1062 Eustath. Od. p. 1761, 27 λέγει δὲ καὶ (sc. Ἀριστοφάνης ὁ γραμματικός) λαπίζειν παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ τὸ συρίζειν. Cf. Aristoph. Byz. ap. Miller, Mélanges, 427 λαπύζειν· τὸ συρίζειν.

There seems to be no other evidence for this use of λαπίζειν and Eustathius mentions it in a list of καινοφώνους λέξεις preserved by Aristophanes. But there was certainly a verb λαπίζειν or λαπίττειν which is glossed by ψεύδεσθαι, ἀλαζονεύεσθαι, and γαυροῦσθαι (Phot. lex. p. 208 1; Bekk. anecd. p. 277, 27; Hesych. III p. 13), with derivatives λαπιστής and λάπισμα; and ἐλάπιζε, if it is the right reading, bears this sense in Cic. Att. 9. 13. 4. Hence Nauck at one time conjectured ὑβρίζειν for συρίζειν. The evidence of Aristophanes seems explicit enough, but it is worth remarking that Photius (l.c.) continues καὶ λαπήκτης (l. λαπίκτης) ὁ ψεύστης διὸ τοῦ κݲ ὡς σαλπίγκτης This may perhaps justify the guess that the grammarian's comment once ran: καὶ λαπίζειν τὸ ψεύδεσθαι διὰ τοῦ ζ ὡς σαλπίζειν συρίζειν, and that it was confused and corrupted by successive epitomizations. Mekler proposed to solve the difficulty by substituting τὸ Συρίζειν, for which he quoted Lucian de mere, cond. 10 ὑπὸ θυρωρῷ κακῶς Συρίζοντς ταττόμενον. But, if Συρίζειν is there rightly interpreted as equivalent to βαρβαρίζειν, it does not seem an appropriate gloss. Cohn in Jahrb. f. Philol. Suppl. XII 296 held that συρίζειν was ‘sine dubio corruptum.’
1063 Phot. lex. p. 219, 25 and Suid. s.v. ληκυθιστής· ὁ μικρόφωνος. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς.

Meineke conjectured μακρόφωνος in place of μικρόφωνος, but it is not clear that he was right, or that L. and S. are correct in their rendering bawler. The origin of this view is to be found in schol. Ar. Ach. 589 κομπολακύθου]. . . ληκυθίζειν γὰρ τὸ μεῖζον βοᾶν καὶ ψοφεῖν. ἦχον γὰρ ἐπιτελεῖ καὶ ἡ λήκυθος, ἐπεὶ Καὶ αὕτη πεφύσηται· πάντα γὰρ τὰ πεφυσημένα κόμπον ποιεῖ. But further search reveals that it was not so much the volume as the quality of the sound that was denoted by κηκυθίζειν etc., and that the central meaning is a hollow, false, affected sound. Hence Hesych. III p. 34 ληκυθιστής· κοιλόφωνος, explained by Phryn. praep. soph. p. 86, 9 (Bekk. anecd. p. 50, 8) ληκυθίζειν· ὁπόταν βούλωνται οἱ φωνασκοῦντες κοῖλον τὸ φθέγμα ποιεῖν, ὥσπερ εἰς ληκύθους προϊέμενοι. Cf. schol. Hephaest. p. 33, 10 G. (explaining ληκύθιον) ἢ διὰ τὸν βόμβον τὸν τραγικόν· βόμβος γὰρ γίνεται περὶ τὸ ληκύθιον ἐκ τοῦ ἐμπεριεχομένου αὐτῷ ἀέρος κινουμένου, ἢ ὑπὸ πνεύματος ἀνδρός, ἢ ὑπ᾿ ἄλλου· διὸ καὶ Καλλίμαχος (fr. 98c) μοῦσαν ληκύθειον τὴν τραγῳδίαν λέγει. So ληκυθισμός becomes a term of abuse for what is unreal and affected in speech: Plut. adu. Epic. 2, p. 1086 E. Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. ληκυθισμός· περιενεγκεῖν εὐστρόφως καὶ κεκλασμένως τὸν ληκυθισμὸν τῶν αἰσχρῶν καὶ γελοίων ᾀσμάτων. The application to the style of tragedy — or elevated literature — is familiar from Cic. Att. I. 1. 14. ep. 1. 2, Hor. Α. Ρ. 97, Epist. 1. 3. 14. Strabo 609 contrasts θέσεις ληκυθίζειν with φιλοσοφεῖν πραγματικῶς, where the point is emptiness of substance. Thus it is by no means certain that the metaphor is derived from the laying on of colour taken from a paint-pot.
1064 Phryn. ecl. p. 187 (CLXIII R.) λίβανον λέγε τὸ δέδρον, τὸ δὲ θυμιώμενον λιβανωτόν, εἰ καὶ διὰ τὴν ποιητικὴν (ἄδειαν add. Lobeck) λίβανον καὶ τοῦτο Σοφοκλῆς λέγει.

λίβανος is used for frankincense τὸ ποιούμενον ἀπὸ τοῦ ποιοῦντος) also in Eur. Bacch. 144 and other passages quoted in Lobeck's excellent note. So μέλισσα for μέλι in O.C. 481, fr. 155, ἐλέφας for ivory, πορφύρα for purple, χελώνη for tortoiseshell.

1065 Phot. lex. p. 227, 19 and Bachm. anecd. I p. 291, 20 λίτρα· ἦν μὲν καὶ νόμισμά τι. . . Σοφοκλῆς δὲ λιτροσκόπον φησὶ τὸν ἀργυραμοιβὸν ἀπὸ (ἐπὶ anecd.) τοῦ νομίσματος. Cf. Hesych. Ill p. 45 λιτροσκόπους· ἀργυραμοιβούς, ἀπὸ τοῦ Σικελικοῦ νομίσματος, ὁ καλεῖται λίτρα.

The locus classicus for λίτρα is Pollux 4. 173 — 175, where Epicharmus and Sophron are quoted. It was a small silver coin current in Sicily, and said to be equivalent to an Aeginetan obol. It was also used as a weight, and corresponded to the Latin libra: see Dict. Ant. ΙΙ 69 a.
1066 Steph. Byz. p. 425, 3 Μαγνησία, πόλις παρὰ τῷ Μαιάνδρῳ καὶ χώρα ...ὁ πολίτης Μάγνης...τὸ θηλυκὸν Μάγνησσα... καὶ Μαγνῆτις παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ.
Besides λίθος μαγνῆτις (fr. 800), ἵπποισι Μαγνητίδεσσιν occurs in Pind. Pyth. 2. 45, with reference to the Thessalian Magnesia.

1067 Phot. lex. p. 247, 17 μαρίλη (μαρινη cod.)· ἡ μεμαρασμένη ὕλη, καὶ <μαριλοκαύτας> τοὺς ἀνθρακευτάς. Σοφοκλῆς. μαριλοκαύτας was restored by Naber from Hesych. III p. 72. μαριλοκαυτῶν· ἀνθρακευτῶν· μαρίλη γὰρ τὸ ἀπόψημα τῶν ἀνθράκων.

The next gloss in Phot. is as follows: μαρίλη· ὁ χνοῦς τῶν ἀνθράκων· καὶ ἡ ἀπ᾿ αὐτῶν ἀσβόλη. Similarly Suidas: μαρίλη. ἀμαυρὸν πῦρ· ὁ χνοῦς καὶ τὸ λεπτότατον τῶν ἀνθράκων.῾χαλκεὺς οἷά τις | γέμων καπνοῦ <τε> καὶ μαρίλης᾿ (Com. fr. adesp. 443, 111 492 K.). καὶ Κρατῖνος ἐν Ὥραις· (fr. 257, 1 90 K.) ῾ἐφθάρη μαρίλης τὴν φάρυγα πλέαν ἔχων.᾿ ἡ ἀπὸ τῶν ἀνθράκων σποδιά. Then Suidas quotes Ar. Ach. 350, where the schol. explains μαρίλη as ἡ ἐξ ἀνθράκων τέφρα. Etym. Gud. p. 379, 35 betrays a later date: μαρίλη σημαίνει τὴν κόνιν τὴν γινομένην ἐκ τοῦ κατασβέννυσθαι τοὺς κάρβωνας. Themistius has appropriated the first quotation in Suidas: or. 21 p. 298, 10 ἀνθρακέως τινὸς ἢ σιδηρέως, καπνοῦ γέμοντος καὶ μαρίλης. It is clear from all this that μαρίλη means coal-dust, and it is difficult to resist the impression that μαριλοκαύτης, which is an inexact substitute for ἀνθρακεύς (-ευτής), has a comic —or at least a contemptuous—innuendo. Cf. Ar. Ach. 609 ἐτεόν, ὦ Μαριλάδη— ‘Coaly.’ μαρίλη also occurs in Hipponax fr. 59. Wilamowitz found a place for the word in the Ichneutae: see fr. 314, 34.

1068 Pollux 3. 45 ὁ δὲ μέλλων γαμεῖν μελλονύμφιος ὑπ᾿ ἐνίων ἐκλήθη ... καὶ ἡ μέλλουσα γαμεῖσθαι μελλονύμφη. βέλτιον δ᾿ ὡς Σοφοκλῆς ὠνόμασεν, ῾τῆς μελλογάμου᾿ (Ant. 627) ... μελλόποσιν δὲ τὸν ἄνδρα ὠνόμασεν. Cf. Hesych. III p. 88 μελλέποσις· ὁ μέλλων ἀνὴρ γίνεσθαι.

There is the same uncertainty as to the vowel in μελλόγαμος and μελλέγαμος, μελλόπταρμος and μελλέπταρμος, and there is no reason for regarding one form as more legitimate or earlier than the other. In Pollux I. 21 Bethe adopts βλεπεδαίμων, but the MSS vary between βλεπεδαίμων, βλεπιδαίμων, and βλεποδαίμων. Lobeck, Phryn. p. 768, holds that the form in -ε- ‘veluti longi temporis praescriptione possessionem obtinet,’ whereas that in -ο- ‘magis publica et praesente nota signata est.’ Jebb (on El. 72 at p. 207) distinguishes ἀρχε- as a verbal stem from ἀρχοas a nominal ; but this cannot apply to μελλε- μελλο-, and is not historically correct. According to Brugmann, wherever a real verbal stem appears as the first member of a compound, it is a new formation, called into existence by conscious association with the verbal stem of a nominal element in an old inherited compound. φιλό-ξενος, by association with φιλεῖν, produced μισό-ξενος. Thus, μελλε- μελλο- are analogues of ἀρχεἀρχο-, which are legitimate nominal components. Whether the -ε- was derived ultimately from an Indo-European stem, or was a Greek innovation when the first component was associated with a verb (ἀρχε- from ἄρχε-ι), has not been determined : see Brugmann, Comp. Gr. II pp. 46, 51 Eng. tr.

1069 Eustath. Il. p. 877, 59 Σοφοκλῆς δέ, φησί (sc. Aristophanes of Byzantium), δόξειεν ἄν που καὶ τὰ θηρία πάντα μὴ. καλεῖν· τὸν γοῦν Ἀχιλλέα τραφῆναί φησιν ἐν τῷ Πηλίῳ πᾶν μῆλον θηρῶντα. This is repeated by Eustath. Od. p. 1648 fin.

The suggestion that this fragment belongs to the Ἀχιλλέως Ἐρασταί seems to have been first made by Hartung: see on fr. 154. In the words immediately preceding Aristophanes was mentioned as attributing to Simonides (fr. 28) the use of μᾶλον (μῆλον) and πρόβατον signify βοῦν ἄρρενα, and as quoting the line μῆλα, βόας κεραοὺς καὶ ὄϊς καὶ πίονας αἶγας. We are, therefore, justified in believing that the gloss which appears in Phot. lex. p. 265, 26, Etym. Μ. p. 584, 2 and Suid. μῆλα· πάντα τὰ τετράποδα· ὅθεν καὶ πᾶσα βύρσα μηλωτὴ καλεῖται goes back to an Alexandrian source. Similarly Hesych. III p. 103 μῆλα· κοινῶς μὲν πάντα τὰ τετράποδα· . . . κατ᾿ ἐπικράτειαν δὲ τὰ πρόβατα Καὶ αἶγες. Phryn. praep. soph. p. 27, 6, Apollon. lex. Horn. p. 458. The wider meaning which μῆλον sometimes bore (cf. the gradual restriction of our ‘cattle’) is not entirely unknown in extant literature (e.g. Pind. Ol. 7. 63). H. refers to Aesch. fr. 158 σπείρω δ’ ἄρουραν δώδεχ᾿ ἡμερῶν ὁδόν, | Βερέκυντα χῶρον, ἔνθ᾿ Ἀδραστείας ἕδος, | Ἴδης τε μυκηθμοῖσι καὶ βρυχήμασιν | ἕρπουσι μήλων πᾶν ὀρεχθεύει πέδον: see his explanation of this passage in C. R. XVI 435. It appears that μηλοσφαγεῖν was the generic term for sacrificing victims, whether sheep or oxen: Ar. Au. 1232 μηλοσφαγεῖν τε βουθύτοις ἐπ’ ἐσχάραις. Thus, Weil and Herwerden proposed to restore μηλοσφαγοῦντες for ταυροσφαγοῦντες in Αesch. Theb. 43 from the parody in Ar. Lys. 188 εἰς ἀσπίδ᾿ ὥσπερ φασὶν Αἰσχύλος ποτέ, | μηλοσφαγούσας, where the schol. remarks ἀντὶ τοῦ τανροσφαγούσας μηλοσφαγούσας εἶπεν, εἰ μὴ ἄρα μῆλα πάντα τὰ τετράποδα. Similarly, it is no valid argument against the adoption of βούτας in Aesch. Ag. 718 ff. (ἔθρεψεν δὲ λέοντος ἶνιν δόμοις ἀγάλακτα βούτας ἀνὴρ φιλόμαστον) to call attention to μηλοφόνοισιν ἄταις in v, 731, although Wilamowitz in C.R. xx 446 speaks as if Headlam, in adopting it, had ignored this consideration. — Aristophanes quotes the substance of Sophocles' text without giving the actual words, and some might be inclined to add to the lemma at least as much as ἐν τῷ Πηλίῳ. . . πᾶν. . . θηρῶντα.
1070 Phot. lex. p. 269, 8 μιαίνεσθαι καὶ ἐκμιαίνεσθαι· τὸ ὀνειρώττειν· Σοφοκλῆς.

Naber concluded that the citation of Sophocles was an error, and that his name should be transferred to the perceding gloss μηχανορράφος (O.T. 387). This is a plausible conjecture, and Nauck in his second edition was persuaded by it to remove the present fragment from his collection (TGF2 p. xx). But we are hardly justified in rejecting the tradition. since Sophocles may have used μιαίνεσθαι in a satyr-play with the meaning stated. The explanation of the gloss will be found in Ar. Ran. 753 with the schol., or in Hor. Sat. 1. 5. 84. Inasmuch as Aristophanes employed the compound verb, it may be that we should refer μιαίνεσθαι (rather than ἐκμιαίνεσθαι) to Sophocles, and that Σοφοκλῆς <καὶ was in the original gloss.

1071 Pollux 3. 10 ὁμοίως δὲ μήτηρ ἡ τεκοῦσα, ἡ ὠδίνουσα, ἡ γεννησαμένη ὁ Πλάτων (Menex. 237 E), ἡ γεννήσασα ὡς Σοφοκλῆς, ἡ μαστὸν ἐπισχοῦσα, ἡ θηλάσασα. I have followed the text of Bethe, who in connecting the words ἡ γεννήσασα with Sophocles, adopts the reading of the codices FS, in preference to that of BC. The latter give the words in the order ἡ μαστὸν ἐπισχοῦσα ὡς Σοφοκλῆς, ἡ θηλάσασα. However that may be, the editors have made a strange mistake in citing the of Pollux as an authority for the use of μήτηρ by Sophocles in a particular sense, — that of foster-mother, according to the reading which they adopted. For it is patent that Pollux compiled a list of expressions used by various authors which were synonymous with μήτηρ, and that ἡ γεννήσασα (or ἡ μαστὸν ἐπισχοῦσα) is to be attributed to Sophocles. The only instance in tragedy of γεννᾶν applied to the mother is Aesch. Suppl. 48, but it is commonly so used in later Greek.

1072 Etym. M. p. 595, 1 μύνδος (μύνδιος Sorb.) ἰχθῦς, Σοφοκλῆς, ὁ αὐδῶν. ὅθεν καὶ ἔλλοψ ἀπὸ τοῦ τὴν ὄπα ἔχειν. Cod. F has μῦνδος ὁ μὴ αὐδῶν, Σοφοκλῆς μῦνδος ἰχθύς. Etym. Gud. p. 400, 35 μῦνδος ὁ μὴ αὐδῶν· Σοφοκλῆς μύνδος ὁ μὴ αὐδῶν.

Sophocles is apparently quoted for the sense dumb, but some scholars consider that the etymologer cited him as using μυνδός = ἰχθύς. See Schneider on Callim. fr. 260 μυνδότεροι νεπόδων. Lycophr. 1375 ἔλλοπος μυνδοῦ δίκην. Bergk, on the strength of this evidence, wished to restore χορὸς δὲ μυνδῶν ἰχθύων in fr. 762 I. On the other hand, van Leeuwen suggested that the name of Sophocles was wrongly introduced into the text of the Etym. M. by someone who remembered Ai. 1297. For the accentuation see Chandler, § 367. Wecklein thinks that μυνδός is not a genuine word, but arose from a corruption of δ’ ἀναύδων to δὲ μυνδῶν in fr. 762.
1073 Pollux 7. 30 καταξῆναι Πλάτων ὁ κωμικός (fr. 245, 1 664 K.), ὁ δὲ φιλόσοφος Πλάτων καὶ τέχνην ξαντικήν (polit. 282 A), Σοφοκλῆς δὲ ξέσμα.
Dindorf conjectured ξάσματι for φάσματι in Trach. 838, to which passage he thinks Pollux was alluding.
1074 Phot. lex. p. 312, 22 ξυνῶνα· article on τὸν κοινωνόν. Σοφοκλῆς.

H. writes: ‘This is the true Attic form, though occurring only here.’ He has discussed the type of formation in an article on τοκέων in C.R. xv 401 ff., where he gives a list of the dialectical varieties affecting the small class of words in question. These words are the presentatives of an old formation (with
suffix ᾱ- Ƒον- or ᾱ- Ƒων-), which ceased at an early date to be productive. Its appearance in literature is rare, and apt to be due to deliberate archaism. Hence the occurrence of certain anomalies is not easy to explain, (I) The accentuation of λυμεών, ἀπατεών, πορθεών )( τοκέων, ξυνέων is treated by Postgate (in C. R. xv 403) as an Attic innovation on the analogy of the κενεών, οἰνεών class (Lobeck, Phryn. p. 166). (2) The vagaries of εων ων are puzzling. Certainly ων was not universal in Attic, for there is no trace of contraction in the three words which alone — proper names apart — can be described as current, viz. ὀργεών, λυμεών, ἀπατεών. On the other hand, εων was often merely graphic (εων: cf. ἅλα of Alex. Aetolus [v. 15] ap. Parthen. 14) in Ionic (Weir Smyth, p. 258); and in Archil, fr. 86, 2 we actually find ξυνωνίην. Moreover in Doric contraction is attested by Pindar's κοινάν (Pyth. 3. 28) and ξυνάν (Nem. 5. 27); and κοινωνός and its derivatives (cf. κοινανέω) prove the antiquity of the contracting tendency. The evidence is not sufficiently uniform to condemn Scaliger's κοινεῶν᾿ ἐκλῄζομεν, adopted by Murray, in Eur. Her. 340: Euripides may have had literary reasons for introducing such a form, although we cannot identify them. Whether these variations are ultimately due to accentposition, producing doublets, one or the other of which, if not changed by analogy, survived in certain conditions, is a question for philologists to determine.
1075 Phot. lex. p. 326, 13 ὀκριάζων· τραχυνόμενος. Σοφοκλῆς. Also in Hesych. Ill p. 193, but without the author's name. M. Schmidt quotes from Theognostus p. 23, 25 the error οἱριαζων, τραχυνόμενος.

We may suppose that Sophocles co Hom. σ 33 οὐδοῦ ἐπὶ ξεστοῦ πανθυμαδὸν ὀκριόωντο, explained By schol. BHQ ἐτραχύνοντο, ἠγριαίνοντο, and by schol. V ἐτραχύνοντο, διεφέροντο, διεπληκτίζοντο. Similarly Apollon. lex. p. 494 ὀκριόωντο. μεταφορικῶς ἐβαρύνοντο, ἐτραχύνοντο κατὰ τὴν ψυχήν.
1076 Phot. lex. p. 329, 15 ὁλοσπάδες· ὅλαι καταπινόμεναι καὶ κατασπώμεναι. Σοφοκλῆς. Cf Hesych. in p. 199 ὁλοσπαδεῖς· ὅλαι κατασπώμεναι καὶ καταπινόμεναι.

ὁλοσπάς was perhaps an epithet of ἄμυστις (schol. Ar. Ach. 1229 τὴν ἀθρόαν πόσιν οὕτως ἔλεγον). For σπᾶν cf. Eur. Cycl. 417 ἐδέξατ᾿ ἔσπασέν τ᾿ ἄμυστιν ἑλκύσας, ib. 571 συνεκθανεῖν δὲ σπῶντα χρὴ τῷ πώματι. The metaphor is quite natural, our draught shows: Paley on Cycl. 572 gives an absurd explanation, as if the verb was applied to the cup rather than to its contents.
1077 Phot. lex. p. 346, 23 ὀρθόφρων· ἀνατεταμένος καὶ μετέωρος ταῖς φρεσίν. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. Hesych. III p. 219 ὀρθόφρων· ἀνατεταμένας φρένας ἔχων, ἢ ὀρθάς. μετέωρος.

It appears that the meaning is ‘with spirit -erect — excited.’ The evidence of compound is interesting, for ὀρθός is not known to occur in this sense before the fourth century: Isocr. 5. 70 (οἵαν) δὲ τὴν Ἑλλάδα πᾶσαν ὀρθὴν οὖσαν ἐφ᾿ οἷς σὺ τυγχάνεις εἰσηγούμενος, 16. 7 ὀρθῆς δὲ τῆς
πόλεως γενομένης διὰ τὸ μέγεθος τῶν αἰτιῶν, Lycurg. 39 ὀρθὴ δ’ ἦν ἡ πόλις ἐπὶ τοῖς συμβεβηκόσιν, Hyperid. fr. 39 K. ὀρθῆς δὲ τῆς πόλεως οὔσης ἐπὶ τούτοις [ = κεκινημένης]. Plut. Demosth. 18, 3 ὀρθὴν δὲ τὴν Ἑλλάδα γενέσθαι καὶ πρὸς τὸ μέλλον. The similarity of these passages, and others quoted by the lexicons from Polyb. and Diod., is remarkable: slightly different is Polyb. 28. 17. 11 ὀρθοὶ καὶ μετέωροι ταῖς διανοίαις ἐγενήθησαν οἱ Ῥόδιοι πάντες. Philostr. vit. Apoll. 2. 36. Contrast Ο.Τ. 528.
1078 Phot. lex. p. 361, 16 οὐράν· αἰδοῖον. Σοφοκλῆς. Hesych. Ill p. 241 αὐρά· ἡ κέρκος, καὶ τὸ αἰδοῖον.
κέρκος is used similarly in Ar. Ach. 785 Lys. 239, and cauda in Cic. fam. 9. 22. 2 Hor. Sat. i. 2. 45. See also Eustath. Od. p. 1968, 41.
1079 Phot. lex. p. 363, 19 ὄφελμα· αὔξημα. Σοφοκλῆς. Cf. Hesych. III p. 246 ὄφελμα· αὔξημα. κάλυμμα. κάλλυντρον.

The explanation κάλλυντρον refers to the fact that ὄφελμα is used by Hipponax in the sense of a droom (fr. 51 ἄνθρωπον εὗρε τὴν στέγην ὀφέλλοντα | —οὐ γὰρ παρῆς ὄφελμα — πυθμένι στοιβῆς); but κάλυμμα is obscure. Perhaps we should read κάλλυσμα, ‘sweepings’: see Herwerdnen, Lex. suppl. s.v.
1080 Pollux 10. 50 πέλλυτρα· οὕτω γὰρ τὰ ποδεῖα Σοφοκλῆς καλεῖ.

It is thought that Sophocles is here cited in error for Aeschylus, to whom Pollux twice elsewhere (2, 196, 7. 91) ascribes the word πέλλυτρα (fr. 259). A warm kind of sock or stocking is meant: see Dict. Ant. II 932 b.
1081 Pollux 7. 203 κυβεία. . . πεττεία ἢ πεσσεία, ὡς Σοφοκλῆς.
The word πεσσεία probably occurred in the Nauplius or the Palamedes. For the distinction between κυρεία and πεσσεία see on frs. 429 and 947.

1082 Phryn. praep. soph. p. 36, 1 (Bekk. anecd. p. 21, 27) αἰκάλλοντες· σημαίνει τὸ σαίνοντες, ὅπερ οἱ κύνες ποιοῦσιν. ὁ μέντοι Σοφοκλῆς καὶ προσσαίνειν. χρῶ οὖν εἰ μὲν φιλοτίμως, αἰκάλλειν, εἰ δὲ πολιτικῶς, τῷ προσσαίνειν.

Wecklein thinks that Sophocles is mentioned in error for Aeschylus, by whom προσσαίνειν is used twice (Prom. 861, Ag. 1665). It occurs also in Eur. Hipp. 863. αἰκάλλω is only found in Eur. Andr. 630, unless Musgrave's correction is accepted in 0. T. 597. In Athen. 99 E δέον αἰκάλλειν μᾶλλον καὶ προσσαίνειν τοῖς συνδείπνοις no distinction is apparent, but Phrynichus treats αἰκάλλειν as the more elevated and poetic word: for φιλοτίμως cf. schol. Ai. 701. It might be argued that αἰκάλλοντες is also quoted from Sophocles, or, at any rate, that he used αἰκάλλειν (so apparently de Borries) of human wheedling. But neither inference is necessary; for Phrynichus may have meant that though writing in the elevated style Sophocles nevertheless employed προσσαίνειν.
1083 Phot. lex. p. 470, 3 πτέρυγας· τὰ πηθάλια. Σοφοκλῆς.

The statement is confirmed by Hesych. Ill p. 403 πτέρυγες· εὐθυντῆρες, τὸ πηδάλια. . . δηλοῖ δὲ καὶ τῶν πηδαλίων τὰ πλατέα καὶ τὰ χείλη. Thus πτέρυξ used specifically for the blade or tip of the paddle: Pollux 1. 90 τὸ δὲ τελευταῖου (τοῦ πηδαλίου) πτερύγιον. πτερόν applied both to ars and sails, but not, so far as we know, to the rudder, although Pflugk suggested this interpretation for Eur. Hel. 147 νεὼς στείλαιμ᾿ ἂν οὔριον πτερόν.

1084 Eustath. Il. p. 948, 19 ὅτι δὲ τὸ πτύον καὶ πτέον ἔλεγον οἱ Ἀττικοὶ ὕστερον Αἴλιος Διονύσιός φησιν (fr. Schw.). ἕτερος δέ τις λέγει· πτέον ἄλλοι, πτύον δὲ Σοφοκλῆς ἀκολουθῶν δηλαδὴ τῷ ποιητῇ (N 588).
That the later or Attic form was πτέον is recorded also by Phot. lex. p. 469, 22, Pollux 1. 245, 10. 128.
1085 Etym. Μ. p. 695, 50 πύγαργος· εἶδος ἀετοῦ· Σοφοκλῆς ἐπὶ τοῦ δειλοῦ, ἀπὸ τῆς λευκῆς πυγῆς, ὥσπερ ἐναντίως μελάμπυγος ἀπὸ τῆς ἰσχυρᾶς (leg. ἐπὶ τοῦ ἰσχυροῦ). See also schol. Lycophr. 91.

Sophocles seems to have applied the word metaphorically to a coward, and this sense probably arose without reference to any observation of the eagle's disposition, ὅτι τοὺς λευκοπύγους ὡς γυναικώσεις ἐκωμῴδουν, as the schol. on Ar. Lys. 802 remarks. In Aesch. Ag. 117 two eagles appeared, ὁ κελαινός, 8 δ’ ἐξόπιν ἀργᾷς and the latter was identified by Calchas with the craven-hearted Menelaus (see Headlam on 1 25 f.). Holzinger on Lycophr. 90 supposes that Paris is there called πύγαργος because of his μαχλοσύνη, but Paris also was taunted with cowardice (Hom. A 390). On the other hand for μελάμπυγος, the traditional epithet of Heracles, see Zenob. 5. 10 (Paroem. 1 119) μὴ σύ γε μελαμπύγου τύχοις. Eubul. fr. 61, 11 185 K. ἐγὼ δέ γ᾿ εἰμὶ τῶν μελαμπύγων ἔτι. Additional evidence is collected by Blaydes on Ar. Lys. I.e. μελάμπυ|γος τε τοῖς ἐχθροῖς ἅπασιν.
1086 Strabo 364 Σοφοκλῆς δὲ καὶ Ἴων (fr. 66) τὸ ῥᾴδιον ῥᾴ (ῥᾶ A and Ἐπίχαρμος δὲ τὸ λίαν λῖ (fr. 223 K.). Eustath. Il. p. 295, 5 καὶ Σοφοκλῆς Τὸ ῥᾴδιον ῥᾴ.

Strabo introduces ῥᾴ as an illustration of apocope in the course of a list of similar examples. But several of these, such as the Homeric κρῖ and δῶ (for which see Brugmann, 11 488, III 102), as well as ῥᾴ itself, are beside the mark. The grammarians attributed the invention of ἀπότρωκτον, as they called it, to Epicharmus (Hesych. I p. 135 ἄλφι etc.); and Philetas and Euphorion may have copied him. Nauck writes γα, and regards it as a contraction of the Homeric ῥέα; but Bergk [PLG III 53), commenting on Alcm. fr. 42 τίς δ᾿ ἄν, τίς ποΚα ῥᾲ ἄλλω νόον ἀνδρὸς ἐνίσποι; reverted to the traditional form, which he regarded as a neut. ace. of ΡΑΙC used adverbially. This would agree well enough with ῥηΐδιος, ῥᾷον, ῥηΐτερος etc. It should be added that the Alexandrian grammarians, althought they wrongly treated ῥᾴ as shortened from Μοι, deliberately rejected the derivation from ῥέα, because (1) the accentuation ought then to be, but was not, γα; (2) tradition invariably supported the ι; (3) the Aeolic form would not then be βρᾴ. See Apollon. Dysc. ap. Bekk. anecd. p. 566 f, abbreviated in Etym. M. p. 700, 26 (cf. ib. p. 210, 43). The origin of the Homeric ῥέα is another matter. Leaf on P 462 says that the original forms of ῥέα ῥεῖα were Ƒρᾶ and Ƒρεῖα (=ῥη-ια), but not explain why ῥέα was written. Meyer wrote Ƒρᾶ wherever the word was monosyllabic. Osthoff connected ῥᾴων (= ῥᾱσίων) with the Lat. rarior.

1087 Phot. lex. p. 480, 15 Ῥαικούς· οἱ βάρβαροι τοὺς Ἕλληνας. Σοφοκλῆς τῇ λέξει κέχρηται. But the testimony of Eustath. Il. p. 890, 14 is to the opposite effect: οὓς (sc. Γραικούς) ἡ μὲν Καὶ Σοφοκλῆς δέ που κατὰ τοὺς παλαιοὺς Καὶ ὁ Λυκόφρων δὲ διὰ τοῦ ἐν ἀρχῇ Γ προφέρουσιν ἐπὶ Ἑλλήνων, οἱ βάρβαροι δὲ Ῥαικοὺς φασὶ δίχα τοῦ Γ, ὡς ἐν παλαιῷ εὕρηται λεξικῷ ῥητορικῷ (Ael. et Paus. fr. 369 Schwabe). Probably Eustathius is nearer to the original statement than Photius. Suid. Ῥαικός· ὁ Ῥωμαῖος is still further degraded. However, even the statement as it appears in Eustathius is open to suspicion, and is possibly merely an echo of fr. 518, where see note. But though it is improbable that it was used by Sophocles, we should be wrong to deny altogether the existence of Ῥαικός. Cf. Hesych. Ill p. 419 Ῥαικός· Ἕλλην. Ῥωμαῖοι δὲ τὸ γݲ προσθέντες Γραικόν ib. p. 424 Ῥᾶχος· Ἕλλην, an error for Ῥαικός. Strabo 231 mentions Rhaeci as inhabitants of Latium. R. Schneider, Bodleiana, p. 6, restored it in Cramer, anecd. Oxon. Ι p. 11, 2. Etym. Μ. 239, 15 seeks a derivation from ῥαίω, — διὰ τὴν κατὰ πολὺ ἀνδρείαν; p. 701, 14. It is especially remarkable to find the word attributed to Epicharmus (fr. 184 Kaibel).
1088 Etym. M. p. 702, 54 = Etym. Gud. p. 491, 3 παρὰ δὲ Σοφοκλεῖ ῥαχία λέγεται ἡ τοῦ ὄρους.

Smyth, lonic Dialect, p. 179, rejects the popular derivation of ῥηχίη (ῥαχία) from ῥήγνυμι on the ground that ῥήγνυμι has pan- Hellenic η, and connects it with ῥάχις. His argument is strengthened by
this use of ῥαχία which is identical with that of ῥάχις in Hdt. 3. 54 ἐπὶ τῆς ῥάχιος τοῦ οὔρεος. Smyth illustrates the application to natural objects of the names given to parts of the body by quoting arm of the sea, shoulder of the mountain, πολυδειρὰς Ὄλυμπος. Closer to the point is Choeril. fr. 2 (p. 719 N.2) <λίθοισι> ὀστοῖσιν ἐγχριμφθ΄εὶς πόδα. The word arête is employed by mountaineers describe a sharp edge of rock. Cf. Hesych. I p. 395 βρακίας· τραχεῖς τόπους.

1089 Phot. lex. p. 485, 10 Ῥειτά· ἐν Ἐλευσῖναι δύο ναμάτια φερόμενα ἐΚ μιᾶς πηγῆς καλούμενα ῥειτά. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. The following gloss is ῥειτῶν τόπος· ἱερῶν ῥευμάτων, which Wagner and Ellendt suppose to contain the words of Sophocles. Blaydes has a similar notion, that Sophocles wrote Ῥειτῶν ἱερῶν or Ῥειτῶν ῥευμάτων. The Gale MS points after ῥειτῶν: should we not read Ῥειτόν (or Ῥειτοί)· τόπος ἱερῶν ῥευμάτων? Anyhow, the natural inference is merely that Sophocles is quoted for the use of Ῥειτά. Elsewhere we find the form Ῥεῖτοι (or Ῥῖτοι), for which see Μ. Schmidt on Hesych. III p. 425. The description of Pausan. 1. 38. 1 is rendered by Frazer: ‘What are called the Rhiti only resemble rivers in that they flow, for their water is salt. One might suppose that they flow underground from the Chalcidian Euripus, falling into a lower sea. The Rhiti are said to be sacred to the Maid and Demeter; and the priests alone are allowed to catch the fish in them.’ See Frazer's note in vol. II p. 486. The first skirmish in the Peloponnesian war, in which the Athenian cavalry was defeated, took place at Rhiti (Thuc. 2. 19). Welcker referred this fr. to the Triptolemus.

1090 Phot. lex. p. 488, 12 ῥήτωρ· συνήγορος, δικολόγος. καὶ ὁ τὴν ἰδίαν ἀποφαίνων γνώμην κριτής, παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ. The same in Cramer, anecd. Par. IV p. 174, 25, Suid. s.v., and, without the reference to Sophocles, Hesych. in p. 428. This is one of the earliest occurrences of ῥήτωρ, which is used quite generally in Eur. Hec. 126 δισσῶν μύθων ῥήτορες ἦσαν. No doubt in Soph, also it bore the same meaning.
1091 Phot. lex. p. 488, 22 ῥικνός· ὁ πεφρικώς, παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ.

The ordinary meaning of ῥικνός is bent or shrivelled. Hesych. Ill p. 429 has the glosses ῥιγνόν· ῥιγεδανόν, φρικῶδες, and ῥικνὴν ὄψιν· φρικτήν, but without giving any authority. Naber conjectured that the latter gloss should be attributed to Sophocles; but, whereas Photius cites Sophocles for the sense shivering, Hesych. seems to understand ῥικνὴν ὅψιν as contorted and so terrible. There is no evidence to clear up the difficulty. For ῥικνοῦσθαι see on fr. 316.
1092 Apollon. lex. Horn. p. 140, 2 σάκος· ἀσπίς. ἀφ᾿ οὐ καὶ οἱ νεώτεροι σακτὴν τὴν ὅλην πανοπλίαν λέγουσι, ὡς Σοφοκλῆς.

σάγη = harness; and the context would limit it to armour, as in Aesch. Pers. 243 Eur. Her. confirmed by Hesych. IV p. 2 σάγη· ἡ ὅλη πανοπλία. Schol. Aesch. Theb. 117 δορυσσόοις σάγαις] πολεμικαῖς πανοπλίαις. Schol. ibid. 378 σάγαις] πανοπλίαις. Etym. M. p. 707, 23, 37 derives σάγμα and σό‘ος from σάγη τουτέστιν ἀσπίς. Villoison's correction is Sophocles πανσαγία in Ant. 106.

1093 Phot. lex. p. 497, 12 = Bachm. anecd. 1 p. 361, 20 σαλάβην· Σοφοκλῆς τὴν ὀπήν. Phot. lex. p. 497, 22 σαλάμβη· ὀπή, καπνοδόκη. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. Hesych. IV p. 5 σαλάμβη· ἡ ὀπή, δι᾿ ἧς τὸ σέλας βαίνει. ἢ πύλη, καπνοδόχη θυρίς. Μ. Schmidt was the first to connect with these glosses Eustath. Od. p. 1908, 40 (Ael. Dion, et Paus. fr. 431 Schw.) σέλας οὐ μόνον πυρός, ἀλλὰ Καὶ ἡλίου· ὅθεν παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ < σαλάμβη > ἡ ὀπή, ὡς ἐν ῥητορικῷ εὕρηται λεξικῷ, παρὰ τὸ σέλας, φασίν, ἐμβιβάζειν, where the word has been accidentally lost.

That σαλάμβη is the correct form of the word appears from Lycophr. 98 δισσὸς σαλάμβας κἀπὶ Γυθίου πλάκας, where Tzetzes says: σαλάμβαι αἱ θύραι λέγονται παρὰ τὸ ἐν σάλῳ βαίνειν, ἢ παρὰ τὸ σείειν καὶ λαμβάνειν τοὺς βαίνοντας. A similar note quoting Lycophron occurs in Etym. Μ. p. 707, 45. See also Etym. Gud. p. 267, 17 ἔνιοι δὲ τὰς θύρας σαλάμας (qu. σαλάμβας) καλοῦσιν, ἀπὸ τοῦ σέλας βάλλειν ἀνοιγομένας, ἢ δι’ ὧν τὸ σέλας βαίνει. Orion p. 148, 1 σαλάμβη. ἡ θυρὶς ἡ ἐν σάλῳ οὖσα, ἢ παρὰ τὸ σέλας βαίνειν δι’ αὐτῆς. The etymology of the word is unknown, but G. Meyer (Gr. Gram. 298) wished to connect it with the O.N. svdela ‘smoke.’ The nasal in the ending may be due to the analogy of ἴαμβος: ἰαίνω etc., just as χιλιόμβη follows ἑκατόμβη. So Sturtevant (Class. Phil. V 341f.), who also points out that with certain exceptions nearly all the words with the suffix βη, βης, βος ‘apply to persons or things of little worth or dignity, and more than half of them imply disapproval or contempt.’
1094 Phot. lex. p. 511, 15 = Bachm. anecd. I p. 364, 9 σίκλος (σίγλος anecd.) καὶ τὸ ἐνώτιον, Καὶ σταθμὸς βαρβαρικὸς δυνάμενος ὀκτὼ ὀβολοὺς Ἀττικούς. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς.

σίκλος (or σίγλος) was a transliteration of the Hebrew shekel, which varied in weight in different localities. Naber and others consider that the reference to Sophocles is a mistake, and that Xen. anab. 1. 5. 6 was originally in its place. I agree with Ellendt that, if Sophocles used the word at all, it probably bore the sense ‘ear-ring,’ which seems rather to belong to the form σίγλης. Pollux 5. 97 calls σίγλης a Dorian word. The grammarians seem to have confused σίγλης and σίκλος (σίγλος). Cf. Hesych. s.vv. σίγλον.
1095 Steph. Byz. p. 9, 15 Ἄβροι· .. βαρύνεται δὲ ὡς Κίμβροι, οὕς τινες φασὶ Κιμμερίους, Σκόμβροι, καὶ οὗτοι ἔθνος, ὡς Σοφοκλῆς. Cf. Hesych. IV p. 48 Σκόμβροι· Θρᾴκιον ἔθνος.

Meineke in his index referred this statement to Sophocles the commentator on Apollonius Rhodius, but Lenz (Herodian, p. CCXXIV) agrees with Nauck on the ground that there is nothing about the Σκόμβροι in the scholia to Apollonius. For the mountain Σκόμβρος, part of the Balkan range to the south of Sofia, see Thuc. 2. 96.

1096 Schol. Hom. Φ 220 (Ox. Pap. II p. 66, col. xi 7) στεινόμενος νεκύεσσι] στενοχωρούμενος· παρὰ ταῦτα Ἀλκαῖος ῾στένω μὰν Ξάνθω ῥόος ἐς θάλασσαν ἵκανε,᾿ καὶ ἐν Ὀδυσσείᾳ σ 385) ῾αἶψά κέ τοι τὰ θύρετρα καὶ εὐρέα περ μάλ᾿ ἐόντα στείνοιτο,᾿ οὐχ ὡς Σοφοκλῆς στενάζοι.

Grenfell and Hunt inferred that Sophocles must have paraphrased the passage in the Odyssey, and suggested that he did so in the Ἀχαιῶν σύλλογος. The latter view can no longer be supported (l p. 94, II p. 198), and it is by no means clear that the editors’ is correct. For the comment is too brief to be free from obscurity. Thus it might mean: (1) ‘In the Odyssey στείνοιτο is equivalent to στενοχωροῖτο, not, as in Sophocles, to στενάζοι.’ So Wilamowitz (GGA 1900 p. 42), who remarked that, in using στείνεσθαι for στένεσθαι, Sophocles gave yet another example of his tendency to lonism. Or (2) ῾στείνοιτο be it observed — not στενάζοι, the word which Sophocles uses in a similar case.’ On the whole, I agree with Mekler (Jahresb. CXXIX 31) that this is the more natural interpretation of the scholium, and it is altogether unnecessary to conclude that Sophocles used the phrase θύρα στενάξει or the like in connexion with a reproduction of the scene from the Odyssey. There remains the question whether he meant by it is thronged, as the scholiast implies, or simply creaks (under the pressure of a crowd forcing its way through). The latter is to be preferred, and we should compare Hom. φ 48 τὰ δ’ ἀνέβραχεν ἠύτε ταῦρος | βοσκόμενος λειμῶνι· τόσ᾿ ἔβραχε καλὰ θύρετρα | πληγέντα κληῖδι, πετάσθησαν δὲ οἱ ὦκα, or Ap. Rhod. 4. 42 θυρέων ὑπόειξαν ὀχῆες, | ὠκείαις ἄψορροι ἀναθρῴσκοντες ἀοιδαῖς. Ar. Ach. 548 στίας στεναχούσης would be a closer parallel, if we could accept the scholiast's interpretation. I suspect that the author of [Theocr.] 25. 97 στείνοντο δὲ πίονες ἀγροὶ μυκηθμῷ purposely availed himself of the etymological association with στένω, as on the other hand Qu. 8. 88 ἐπέστενε δ᾿ αἶα νέκυσσι unquestionably uses ἐπιστένω in the sense of στείνεσθαι (cf. 7. 100, 9. 161).
1097 Schol. Soph. Phil. 1108 οὐ φορβὰν ἔτι προσφέρων] ἀντὶ προσφερόμενος. ἐνίοτε δὲ ἔμπαλίν φησι ἀντὶ τοῦ διακονῶν καὶ στιβαδοποιούμενος ἀντὶ στιβάδα ποιῶν (στιβαδοποιῶν Lasc).

If Sophocles used στιβαδοποιεῖσθαι, the schol. might have regarded it as improperly substituted for στιβαδοποιεῖν, since his parallels are equally unconvincing (for Phil. 1180 see Jebb's n.), and the fluctuation of voice can be illustrated by
the usage of παιδοποιεῖν. But στιβαδοποιεῖσθαι was a scholiastic word (schol. Theocr. 4. 25), and it is much more likely that Sophocles wrote στιβάδα ποιούμενος, as Barges suggested, more particularly since στιβάδα ποιῶν has been ascertained to be the reading of L. Lobeck, Phryn. p. 200, points out that Thuc. 7. 39 has ἀριστοποιεῖσθαι followed by ἄριστον ποιεῖσθαι in c. 40. For the use of the middle (‘to make for oneself’) cf. Ar. ἐγὼ δὲ δοίδυκ᾿ εἰσιὼν ποήσομαι. The schol.'s διακονούμενος is generally to be an inexact reference to Phil. 287, but the inference is far from certain.
1098 Pollux 2. 101 στομώδη δὲ τὰ εὔστομα Καὶ εὔφημα Σοφοκλῆς.
The word was employed in the sense ‘clear-voiced.’ That εὔφημα is consistent with this interpretation appears (e.g.) from schol. O. T. 35 ὅτι τὸ ῾ἀοιδοῦ᾿ εὔφημόν ἐστιν.

1099 Pollux 2. 23 οὐλοκίκιννε δὲ Τελέσιλλα (fr. 8) εἴρηκεν. τὸν δὲ τοιοῦτον στραβαλοκόμαν Σοφοκλῆς ὠνόμασεν. μοχθηρὰ δὲ ἄμφω τὰ ὀνόματα. [στραβολοκόμαν in Bethe's text of Pollux appears to be a misprint: he quotes στραμβαλοκόμαν F, στραμβαλλοκόμαν S, as variants.]

στραβαλός was a secondary formation from στραβός, like ἡδύλος from ἡδύς, δριμύλος from δριμύς. See Brugmann, II p. 202. The disapproval of Pollux may be compared with the Atticist rejection of στραβός in place of στρεβλός: Phryn. praep. soph. p. 108, 4 (Bekk. anecd. p. 62, 23), Pollux 2. 51.

1100 Steph. Byz. p. 610, 16 Τεγέα, πόλις Ἀρκαδίας. . . ἔστι Καὶ Τεγέα ἐν Κρήτῃ ὑπὸ Ταλθυβίου κτισθεῖσα. ὁ πολίτης Τεγεάτης ὡς Ἐλεάτης, καὶ θηλυκὸν Τεγεᾶτις λέγεται Καὶ Τεγεάς ὡς Ἰλιάς. ὀξύνεται. ὡς Σοφοκλῆς.
Meineke has suggested with much probability that the reference was to Auge in the Aleadae. For Τεγεᾶτις cf. fr. 142, ii 7.

1101 Suid. s.v. τέως. ἀντὶ τοῦ πρὸ τοῦ, πρίν, ἕως τινός, ἐπὶ τοσοῦτον ἕως. καὶ τέως τηνικαῦτα. ἢ τότε. Σοφοκλῆς δὲ ἀντὶ τοῦ πρότερον ἢ πρὸ μικροῦ. καὶ Ἀριστοφάνης ἀντὶ τοῦ πρότερον 449). ῾τέως μὲν οὖν ἀλλ᾿ ἡμικακως ἐβοσκόμην.᾿

The various glosses are loose equivalents, not pointing to any sharp distinction of meaning: see also Phot. lex. p. 584, 12,
Bekk. anecd. p. 309, 23, Etym. M. p. 786 2, and especially the elaborate schol. Plat. Hipparch. 229 D. πρότερον was a convenient paraphrase, when τέως was used, as in Τhesm. l. c., with νῦν δέ or the like following: see examples in Blaydes's n., and Blomfield on Aesch. Cho. 980. But an exactly similar instance in Nub. 66 is glossed by- the schol. with μέχριτινός. Where the contrast is not expressed by an adverb of time (νῦν, or the like), it is given by implication in the context, as in Ar. Plut. 834 (gl. πρῴην, πρότερον).
1102 Pollux 7. 32 τὰς δὲ ὁλοστημόνους ταινίας τολύπας Σοφοκλῆς ὠνόμασεν.

τολύπη is not only the ball of unspun wool, as explained in Dict. Ant. I 897 but the prepared and twisted yarn produced by the operation of spinning; and it is in the latter sense that Sophocles is stated to have employed it. So exactly in Ar. Lys. 585 δεῦρο ξυνάγειν καὶ ξυναθροίζειν εἰς ἕν (sc. τὸ κατάγματα), κἄπειτα ποιῆσαι | τολύπην μεγάλην, κᾆτ᾿ ἐκ ταύτης τῷ δήμῳ χλαίναν ὑφῆναι. Thus, τολύπη may be practically identical with ἤμα or στήμων (Plat, polit. 282 E τούτου δὴ τὸ μὲν ἀτράκτῳ τε στραφὲν καὶ στερεὸν νῆμα γενόμενον στήμονα μὲν φάθι τὸ νῆμα), with which it is contrasted in Α.Ρ. 6. 160 καλαθίσκον, | στάμονος ἀσκητοῦ καὶ τολύπας φύλακα.
1103 τριπαία vel τριπαῖα) codd.: corr. post Sylburgium Brunck
1103 Bachm. anecd. i p. 390, 8 = Phot. lex. p. 602, 6 τριπαία (τρίπαια Phot.)· ἡ ἐναντία πνοή. Etym. M. 766, 40 τριπαῖα· ἡ ἐναντία πνοή. οὕτω Σοφοκλῆς εἴρηκε.

τροπαία is not a contrary wind, unless accidentally, but a wind blowing in the reverse direction, having shifted to the opposite quarter. It is used metaphorically by Aesch. Ag. 229 φρενὸς πνέων δυσσεβῆ τροπαίαν, Cho. 771 ἀλλ᾿ εἰ τροπαίαν Ζεὺς κακῶν θήσει ποτέ, Theb. 693. Cf. Eur. El. 1147 μετάτροποι πνέουσιν αὖραι δόμων. The word is becoming substantival, with an ellipse of αὔρα (πνοή).
1104 Hesych. IV p. 188 Τυφῶ· ἀντὶ τοῦ Τυφῶνος. Σοφοκλῆς.

Moeris calls τυφώς the Attic form (p. 210, 23 τυφῶ Ἀττικοί, τυφῶνα Ἔλληνες), with this much of reason that τυφών regularly appears in Hellenistic Greek. Nauck, referring to Aesch. Theb. 504, Suppl. 569 — to which he might have added Ag. 661 — and Ar. Nub. 336, thinks that Sophocles has been substituted in error for Aeschylus or Aristophanes; but his suspicion seems unjustifiable.
1105 Eustath. Od. p. 1496, 35 ἀστείως δὲ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς ὅς λέγεται ὕπουλον εἰπεῖν τὸν δούρειον ἵππον.

For the word ὕπουλος see Jebb on O. T. 1396. It was applied commonly in late Greek to treacherous friends, as may be seen from the passages quoted by Wyttenbach on Plut. Mor, 44 Α (VI p. 378). There may have been an allusion to the Wooden Horse in more than one of the Trojan plays: we might think of Αἰχμαλωτίδες, Ἀντηνορίδαι, Λαοκόων or Σίνων as among the likely sources.
1106 Phryn. praep. soph. p. 117 13 (Bekk. anecd. p. 68, 4) ὑφαυχεῖν. Σοφοκλῆς. Hesych. IV p. 223 ὐψαυχεῖν· μεγαλαυχεῖν. Phot. lex. p. 635, 12 and Suid. τ.υ. ὑψανχεῖν· ὑψηλοφρονεῖν.
The degradation of the metaphor is seen in A. Ρ. 5. 250 ἀλλ᾿ οὐ σῆς κραδίης ὑψαύχενος ὤκλασεν ὄγκος.
1107 Phot. lex. p. 637, I φαικῷ· ἀκμάζοντι Καὶ λαμπρῷ. οὕτως Σοφοκλῆς. Cf. Hesych. IV p. 227 φαικῷ· ἐνεργῷ ἀκμάζοντι, ἀπὸ τοῦ φαίνειν, οἷον λαμπρόν.

Curtius, G. E. II p. 303 E. tr., compared φαι-κό-ς with φαί-δι-μο-ς, φαι-δ-ρό-ς, and Φαίδων, but the explanation of the presence of ι is still to seek, unless φαικός arises from φα Ƒ-ικο-ς (like ἱππικός and the rest: Brugmann, ll Ρ. 260). Ellendt wrote φαϊκός. φαικάς Α.Ρ. 6. 254), a white shoe, may be akin.
1108 φαρμακίδα codd.: corr. Brunck et L. Dindorf
1108 Bachm. anecd. I p. 404, 1 = Phot. lex. p. 640, 18 Φαρμακίδα· τὴν ἐκ τοῦ γήρως (γένους Phot.) ῥυτίδα. Σοφοκλῆς.
For the word cf. Erotian gloss. Hippocr. p. 134, 10 φαρκιδῶδες· ῥυτιτῶδες· φαρκὶς γὰρ λέγεται ἡ ῥυτίς.
1109 Hesych. I p. 332 ἀφάρμακον χρῶμα Οἰδίποδος· ἄνευ. ἄνθους· ἄνθη γὰρ τὰ φάρμακα. καὶ τὰ βαφεῖα φαρμακῶνας φαρμακῶντας cod.: corr. Musurus) Σοφοκλῆς ἔφη.

The lemma of Hesychius is surely a tragic fragment, but Nauck does not include it, and ἀφάρμακος is absent from L. & S. Dindorf inclined to the view that ἀφάρμακον χρῶμα was the expression of Sophocles.
1110 Strabo 433 οὕτω καὶ Σοφοκλῆς τὴν Τραχίνα Φθιῶτιν εἴρηκεν.

Elmsley on Eur. Hclid. 194 restored Τραχίνα for Τραχινίαν in the text of Strabo, and the context certainly favours his view, although for the present purpose the point is not οἱ much importance. Welcker (p. 205) rightly resists Elmsley's inference that the quotation occurred in the Phthiotides, but why Ellendt rejects the fragment altogether is not easy to understand. Trachis was actually in Malis (Trach. 194), but in transferring it to Phthiotis Sophocles may have been influenced by Horn. B 682, where Trachis is included in the district of Achilles and closely connected with Phthia.
1111 Hermog. ap. Walz Rhet. Gr. Ill p. 324 καὶ ὁ Σοφοκλῆς δὲ φίλανδρόν που τὴν Ἀταλάντην εἶπε διὰ τὸ ἀσπάζεσθαι σὺν ἀνδράσιν εἶναι, ἡμῶν πάλιν ἐπὶ ἄλλου πράγματος ταττόντων τοὔνομα τοοῦτο.

φίλανδρος, like φιλάνωρ (Aesch. Ag. 420), is normally applied to a loving wife, but as epithet of the virgin Atalanta means masculine. We may compare φιλομεῖραξ, an ἔπίκλησις of Artemis at Elis, because her temple was in the neighbourhood of the gymnasium (Pausan. 6. 23. 6). Brunck was probably right in ascribing this fr. to the Meleager. For the character of Atalanta cf. Eur. fr. 525.

1112 Bachm. anecd. I p. 415,5 χειμάμυνα· παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ, ἡ (ἢ cod.) παρ᾿ Ὁμήρῳ (ξ 529) ἀλεξάνεμος. Pollux 7. 61 attributes the word to Aeschylus : τὸ μέντοι χειμερινὸν ἰμάτιον χείμαστρον ἂν λέγοις, καὶ χλαῖναν δὲ παχειαν, ἣν χειμάμυναν μὲν Αἰσχύλος (fr. 449), Ὅμηρος δὲ ἀλεξάνεμον κέκληκεν. The reference to Sophocles receives confirmation from a passage to which L. Cohn drew attention in Rh. Mus. XLIII 414, Herodian. Philetacr. from cod. Vat. 2226 suppl.: καὶ ἀμύνεσθαι λέγοντες οὐκέτι τὴν ἄμυναν < λέγουσιν > , εἰ μὴ Θεόπομπος ἔχειν ἄμυναν, ὥσπερ καὶ Σοφοκλῆς. For ἔχειν ἄμυναν Papageorgius by a certain emendation restored χειμάμυναν. Whether he is right in inserting Αἰσχύλος after (HfTiTfp is not so clear; and his change of ἀμύνεσθαι to ἄμυναν I do not understand.

Nauck, who in the addenda to TGF (p. XXV) treated this as a new fragment, afterwards (Index, p. XIV) accepted Papageorgius's emendations. Lobeck's statement (Phryn. p. 23) that ἄμυνα does not occur before the first century A.D. requires qualification, in view of ’s citation of Theopompus. The word χειμάμυνα is further attested by Eustath. Od. p. 1767, 43 παχεῖαν χλαῖναν. . . ὁποία τις ἡ μὴ μόνον ἀλεξήνεμος λεγομένη, ἀλλὰ καὶ χειμάμυνα, ὡς ἐν ῥητορικῷ κεῖται λεξικῷ (Ael. et Paus. fr. 445 Schw.). Hesych. iv p. 277 χειμάμυνα· ἣν Ὅμηρος ἀλεξάνεμον λέγει. Cf. Horn. II 224 χλαινάων τ’ ἀνεμοσκεπέων. By the poets of the New Comedy χλαῖνα is mentioned as a winter wrap (Pollux 10. 123). See also fr. 117.

1113 Etym. Gud. p. 564, 25 χειροβοσκός· ὁ διὰ χειρὸς ζῶν, ὧς φησὶ Σοφοκλῆς. Pollux 7. 7. τὸ γὰρ ἀποχειροβίωτος Καὶ χειρῶναξ καὶ χειρογάστωρ Καὶ χειροβοσκὸς καὶ χειροβάναυσος ἧττον ἄν τις προσοῖτο. Hesych. IV p. 278 χειροβοσκόν χειροβοσκῶν · τὸν διὰ χειρῶν ζῶντα.
For the contemptuous tone of βοσκός see on fr. 140.
1114 Suid. s.v. χλωρανθείς· ἀντὶ τοῦ χλωρὸς γενηθείς. οὕτω Σοφοκλῆς.
This appears to be the only extant example of χλωραίνω.
1115 Herodian περὶ μον. λεξ. p. 14 24 τὰ εἰς ο>υ>ς> λήγοντα ὀνόματα ἀρσενικὰ πέφυκεν εἶναι, ἔσθ᾿ ὄτε δὲ καὶ κοινωνεῖ θηλυκῷ γένει. . . Γλοῦς ὁ λῃστής, χνοῦς παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ.
1116 Schol. Ar. Ran. 1033 τὸν Μουσαῖον παῖδα Μήνης καὶ Εὐμόλπου Φιλόχορος (FHG I 416) φησίν. . . ὁ δὲ Σοφοκλῆς χρησμολόγον αὐτὸν φησί.

Aristophanes' words are Μουσαῖος ἐξακέσεις τε νόσων καὶ χρησμούς. There was extant in the fifth century a collection of oracles which passed by the name of Musaeus : thus Hdt. 7. 6 relates how the Pisistratids had banished Onomacritus because he had been caught interpolating the oracles of Musaeus. Hence no doubt Clem. Alex, strom. I. 21, p. 397, says that according to some the oracles traditionally referred to Musaeus were actually the work of Onomacritus. Oracles belonging to his collection and referring to the battles of Salamis and Aegospotami are quoted by Herodotus (8. 96) and Pausanias (10. 9. 11); and the latter speaks of them as still extant in his time (10. 12. 11), although he did not believe in their genuineness (i. 22. 7). It was, in fact, on these that the fame of Musaeus principally rested: Plat. Prot. 316 D (sophists of old fearing to be so called) πρόσχημα ποιεῖσθαι καὶ προκαλύπτεσθαι, τοὺς μὲν ποίησιν. . . τοὺς δὲ αὖ τελετάς τε καὶ χρησμῳδίας, τοὺς ἀμφί τε Ὀρφέα καὶ Μουσαῖον, Philostr. heroic. 3. Ὀρφέα δὲ ἐν πολλοῖς τῶν κατὰ θεολογίαν ὑπερῆρε (sc. Ὅμηρος), Μουσαῖον δ’ ἐν ᾠδαῖς χρησμῶν. Nauck justly remarks that χρησμῳδός might have been expected, and it is arguable that the schol. is giving the substance rather than the actual words of his quotation. [So also the editors of Steph. Thes.] Welcker assigns the fr. to the Triptoletmus .

div.head: ΣΟΦΟΚΛΕΟΥΣ ΑΜΦΙΣΒΗΤΗΣΙΜΑ KAI ΨΕΥΔΕΠΙΓΡΑΦΑ
div.p: 1117 Pollux 2. 154 ἀχείρωτον δὲ Σοφοκλῆς εἴρηκε τὸ ἀχειρούργητον, δυσχείρωτα δὲ Δημοσθένης (61. 37).

Nauck is almost alone in denying that Pollux is quoting from O.C. 698 φύτευμ᾿ ἀχείρωτον αὐτοποιόν, where see Jebb's n. It may be observed that the occurrence of αὐτοποιόν there would be likely to suggest the false interpretation given by Pollux: in most contexts such an inducement would be absent. But it has not been explained why Suid. and Bekk. anecd. p. 474, 4 have the unintelligible gloss ἀχείρωτον· ἄμωμον.

1118 Phot.ed.Reitz.p. 36, 17 (Phryn. praep. soph. p. 37, 23 ; Bekk. anecd. p. 347, 26) Σοφοκλῆς δὲ τὴν εὐθεῖαν εἶπεν ἀείζως γενεά (fr. 740)· ἀπὸ δὲ τῆς δισυλλάβου εὐθείας φιλόζωος εἶπεν ὁ κωμικὸς Πλάτων (ὁ κ. Πλ. om. Bekk. anecd.).
The new codex of Photius shows that this fragment belongs to Plato the comic poet, and not to Sophocles.

1119 Priscian. inst. Gr. 18.206(11 p. 308, 20) iustum pro vero et verum pro iusto frequenter tarn nos quam Attici ponimus. Sophocles Αἴαντι ῾δίκαιος γόνος.᾿ id. 17. 168 (II p. 193, 18) iuste pro vere ...Euripides Αἴαντι ῾δίκαιος γόνος᾿ pro ἀληθής.

Sophocles thrice uses δικαίως in the sense of ἀληθῶς: O.T. 852 οὔτοι ποτ, ὦναξ, τόν γε Λαΐου φόνον | φανεῖ δικαίως ὀρθόν. ib. 1283 ὁ πρὶν παλαιὸς δ᾿ ὄλβος ἦν πάροιθε μὲν | ὅλβος δικαίως. Ai. 547 εἴπερ δικαίως ἔστ᾿ ἐμὸς τὰ πατρόθεν. But this is in accordance with the usage of other authors: Aesch. Theb. 392 ὀρθῶς ἐνδίκως τ᾿ ἐπώνυμον. Eur. fr. ὅθεν οὐκ ἀδίκως | μήτηρ πάντων νενόμισται. Plat. Crat. 418 Ε (ζυγὸν) δυογὸν δικαίως. ib. 409 B. Tim. 85 B. Xen. oecon. 21 and many Others. [Some of these exx. are due to H.: see also On aiiling Aeschylus, p. 141.] The adverb
stands on an entirely different footing to that of the adjective; and it is hardly credible that Sophocles used δίκαιος γόνος in the sense of ‘a genuine son,’ for no parallel has been adduced. (The quotations in L. and S. will not bear examination: Taylor on Aeschin. Ρ. 441 [3. 197] cites them all, as well as others to which the same remark applies.) It seems probable therefore, as has been generally held, that the grammarian intended to quote At. 547, and that his memory played him false. The reference to ‘Euripides’ is significant. See also Hesych. II p. 90 ἔνδικον· ἀληθές, which may be a reference to Ο.Τ. 1158.

lg.l: ἐπεὶ πέπρακται πᾶν τὸ τοὐ θεοῦ καλῶς,
χωρῶμεν ἤδη, παῖδες, ἐς τὰ τῶν σοφῶν
προσλαμβάνειν δὲ δεῖ καθ᾿ ἡμέραν ἀεί,

div.note: 1120. 2 εἰς L 3 post διδασκαλεῖα distinxit L: corr. Wachsmuth
div.p: 1120 Stob. ecl. 2. 31. 5 p. 200, 16 W. Σοφοκλέους. ῾ἐπεὶ. . . πατρός.᾿

I agree with Nauck in thinking that these lines cannot possibly have been written by Sophocles. Dindorf is of the same opinion, but N. Piccolos (Suppl. ὰ l’ Anthol. gr. Paris 1853, p. 332) seems have been the first to doubt their genuineness. See also on fr. 752. The sententious tone, the tameness of the thought, and the entire absence of distinction from the style, are out of keeping with the existing remains of Sophocles. The general cast of the vocabulary, and particularly the use of παιδεύματα (v. 3) and προῖκα (v. 6) in serious verse, suggests a period later than the fifth centuiy. Now, there were two other tragic poets who bore the name of Sophocles and were sufficiently distinguished to have the numbers of their plays recorded in literary chronicles: (1) Sophocles the younger, a grandson of our poet, who exhibited plays from 398 B.C. onwards; (2) a descendant of the same family, belonging to the early part of the second century, who is sai to have written fifteen plays: see Haigh, Tragic Drama, p. 445, Susemihl, Gesch. d. gr. Lit. Alexandr. i p. 283. It is not improbable that some of the extracts attributed to their ancestor were actually composed by one or the other of these writers. For these lines Sophocles the younger seems the more likely author. J. writes: ‘The difficulty of conceiving a context in tragedy for these verses is the chief objection to their genuineness. They seem to be spoken either (1) by a παῖς to other παῖδες, or (2) by a mother, or a παιδαγωγός, to young persons — the father being absent (v. 12). The composition of the verses would not in itself warrant their rejection. The last two vv., indeed, are either corrupt or defective. But, apart from this, there is perhaps only one suspicious point in the language — κέκτηται, instead of κτᾶται, in v. 9. Welcker (p. 270) refers these vv. to the Ἐπίγονοι or Ἐριφύλη. He suggests that in the Cyclic Tliebais Amphiaraus was described as giving good advice to his young sons, Alcmaeon and Amphilochus, before his own departure for Thebes, from which he knew he was not to return. Welcker supposes that Alcmaeon is here relating (probably in the prologue) his father's departure, and quoting his words of counsel to his sons. But this hypothesis requires a very bold assumption, — viz. that χωρῶμεν refers to the departure of Amphiaraus, and that several words have dropped out after it. The sense was, Welcker imagines, “Let me depart now to — but do you go to your studies.” A further difficulty in ’s view is the use of the first person plural in v. 10 and in v. 12 ( φυλαξώμεσθα δοκῶμεν): though this might be defended as = “our family.” ’ Hartung guesses that the lines were spoken by the coryphaeus in the Κρίσις, which had a chorus of Ephebi (!). Meineke (Stob. flor. IV p. xxxiii) believed them genuine, thinking that they were spoken by a παιδαγωγός to the children of Theseus or Heracles, and that τὸ τοῦ θεοῦ in v. 1 refers to a sacrifice for the return of the absent father.
3 f. The traditional pointing is to

lg.l: παῖς δ᾿ ὢν κακὸν μὲν δρᾶν τι προῖκ᾿ ἐπόσταται,
αὐτὸς παρ᾿ αὑτοῦ μανθάνων ἄνευ πόνου·
τὰ χρηστὰ δ᾿ οὐδ᾿ ἢν τὸν διδάσκαλον λάβῃ
ὦ παῖδες, ὡς ἂν μήτ᾿ ἀπαιδεύτων βροτῶν

div.note: 5 ἕως τ᾿ Wachsmuth | λαμβάνειν coni. Nauck 6 δ᾿ οὖν Nauck | προῖκ᾿ ἐπίσταται Gaisford: προῖκ᾿ ἐπίστασθαι L 7 αὐτοῦ L : corr. Bergk 8 οὐδ᾿ ἢν Nauck: οὐδ᾿ ἂν L, εὖτ᾿ ἂν Meineke 9 ἀλλὰ καὶ κτᾶται coni. J., ἀλλὰ κέχρηται Meineke, fort. ἀλλ᾿ ἐπικτᾶται 11 μὴ ἐξ Herwerden 12 κἀποληροῦντος Μ. Schmidt, κἀπὸ ληροῦντος F. W. Schmidt, κἀπὸ δημότου Wecklein | post h. v. lacunam indicavit olim Nauck
div.p: put a full stop after παιδεύματα. The objections to this, as the text stands, are conclusive: (1) παιδεύματα must then be in apposition to διδασκαλεῖα, and would require the forced sense ῾means of teaching, ᾿for which there is no authority; (2) προσλαμβάνειν, unless attached to βελτίονα, would be without an object, since neither παιδεύματα, with the postulate meaning, nor μουσικήν, which is too narrow, could be supplied. To avoid the latter difficulty Hirsching conjectured προσμανθάνειν, which, if adopted, would almost necessarily involve the acceptance of Nauck's λαμβάνειν. Meineke, punctauting as in the text, read παίδευμα γάρ with δεῖ καί for δὲ δεῖ. But neither this alteration nor Wachsmuth's substitution of γάρ for δέ seems to be necessary: for δέ =γάρ see on fr. 576, 4. The postion of δέ is no objection: see Jebb on Ai. 116, Headlam, On editing Aeschylus, p. 114, Eur, hel. 688 (n.). J. preferred the ordinary punctaution, rendering ῾Let us go to the places where the wise (the poets) teach,—to lessons in the lore of the Muses’; but the crucial difficulty is evaded by th break which he assumes after διδασκαλεῖα.—For παιδεύματα as = ‘subjects of instruction,’ see L. and S. and add [Dem.] 60. 16 οἴδε γὰρ ἐξ ἀρχῆς ν πᾶσι τοῖς παιδεύμασιν ἧσαν ἐπιφανεῖς. For προσλαμβάνειν cf. [Dem.] 61. 42 ὅλως μὲν γὰρ ἄπασα φύσις βελτίων γίγνεται παιδείαν προσλαβοῦσα τὴν προσήκουσαν. Isocr. 1. 18 ἐὰν ᾖς φιλομαθής, ἔσει πολυμαθής· ἄ μὲν ἐπίστασαι, ταῦτα διαφύλαττε ταῖς μελέταις, ἂ δὲ μὴ μεμάθηκας, π ροσλάμβανε ταῖς ἐπιστήμαις.

6 Nauck's δ’ οὖν is generally accepted, but J. rightly objects that these particles are quite out of place. The proper sense put a full stop after παιδεύματα. The objections to this, as the text stands, are conclusive: (1) παιδεύματα must then be in apposition to διδασκαλεῖα, and would require the forced sense ‘means of teaching,’ for which there is no (2) προσλαμβάνειν, unless attached to βελτίονα, would be without an object, since neither παιδεύματα, with the postulated meaning, nor μουσιΚήν, which is too narrow, could be supplied. To avoid the latter difficulty Hirschig conjectured προσμανθάνειν, which, if adoptedv would almost necessarily involve the acceptance of Nauck's λαμβάνειν. Meineke, punctuating as in the text, read παίδευμα γάρ with δεῖ καί for δὲ δεῖ. But neither this alteration nor Wachsmuth's substitution of Τάρ for 84 seems to be necessary: for δέ = yap see on fr. 576, 4. The position of δέ is no objection: see Jebb on At. 116, Headlam, On editing Aeschylus, Ρ. 114, Eur. Hel. 688 (n.). J. preferred the ordinary punctuation, rendering ‘Let us go to the places where the wise (the poets) teach, — to lessons in the lore of the ’; but the crucial difficulty is evaded by the break which he assumes after διδασκαλεῖα. — For παιδεύματα as = ‘subjects of instruction,’ see L. and and add [Dem.] 60. 16 οἵδε γὰρ ἐξ ἀρχῆς ἐν πᾶσι τοῖς παιδεύμασιν ἦσαν ἐπιφανεῖς. For προσλαμβάνειν cf. [Dem.] 61. 42 ὅλως μὲν γὰρ ἅπασα φύσις βελτίων γίγνεται παιδείαν προσλαβοῦσα τὴν προσήκουσαν. Isocr. 1. 18 ἐὰν ᾖς φιλομαθής, ἔσει πολυμαθής· ἃ μὲν ἐπίστασαι, ταῦτα διαφύλαττε ταῖς μελέταις, ἃ δὲ μὴ μεμάθηκας, π ροσλάμβανε ταῖς ἐπιστήμαις. of 8 οὖν is ‘however,’ or, when less strongly adversative, ‘to resume’; there is no interruption to the thought, which proceeds in orderly sequence. So far as the text is concerned, there is no difficulty in the ellipse of τις— or πᾶς τις —as subject. J. quotes Aesch. Eum. 297 κλύει δὲ Καὶ πρόσωθεν ὢν θεός. In sentences of universal import the omission is more common than is generally recognized, and often leads to an unreasonable suspicion of the text : see n. on fr. 951. — προῖκ᾿ ἐπίσταται, ‘readily understands.’ I ’t think that is used ironically here, but rather that it is shedding its primary application : cf. Antiph. fr. 210 (11 103 K.) ἀρετὴ τὸ προῖκα τοῖς φίλοις ὑπηρετεῖν. For the sentiment cf. Democr. fr. 182 Diels τὰ μὲν καλὰ χρήματα τοῖς πόνοις ἡ μάθησις ἐξεργάξεται, τὰ δ᾿ αἰσχρὰ ἄνευ πόνων αὐτόματα καρποῦται.

8 f. Cf. Eur. Hipp. 380 τὰ χρήστ᾿ ἐπιστάμεσθα καὶ γιγνώσκομεν οὐΚ ἐκπονοῦμεν δ’, Plat. Prot. 352 D πολλούς φασι γιγνώσκοντας τὰ βέλτιστα οὐΚ ἐθέλειν πράττειν, Men. 77 C. — ἀλλὰ κέκτηται: see cr. n. ‘If the vulg. is right, “possesses them with difficulty,” “possesses them only after a painful discipline.” ’ (J.) He compares Plat. Theaet. 153 B κτᾶται μαθήματα.

11 f. ὡς ἂν μήτ᾿ . . . κἀποδημοῦντος πατρός. ‘(1) In Eur. Ι. T. 591 we read, σὺ δ’. εἶ γάρ, ὡς ἔοικας, οὔτε δυσγενής, | καὶ τὰς Μυκήνας οἶσθα. This
is very rare [Kuehner-Gerth 11 292 quote no other example ; but see Wecklein in loc.], though οὔτε. . . τε is not so. And it does not help us here. For here, if we take μήτε. . . καὶ as corresponding, the only tenable version is “that we may not seem to be of the uneducated sort, and that we may seem to be the children of an absent father.” (It is impossible to render, “that we may not seem to be both uneducated, and the children of such a father” : the τε cannot be detached from μήτε, and placed after ἀπαιδεύτων.) Hence we must conclude that the passage suffers from one of two defects, (1) It may be incomplete: i.e. another subjunctive verb may have followed in another verse, the sense being, “that we may not seem uneducated, and also that in our ’s absence < we may not neglect our duty > Or (2) the text may be corrupt, in which case I would suggest μήτ’ ἀκηδοῦντος πατρός.’ (J.) The conjectures mentioned above, with the exception of Herwerden's, do not avoid the difficulty of μήτε. . . καὶ. I have adopted the view that the quotation is incomplete: the contrast to be looked for is between the origin of the persons concerned and their own actions, e.g. μήτ’ αὖ σοφῶν γεγῶτες ἀργίᾳ νοσεῖν. H. explained ἀποδημοῦντος πατρός with reference to the phrase ἐΚ μέσης τῆς Ἑλλάδος used of the purest Greek origin, as contrasted with the Greek-speaking races of the Levant. He quoted the following illustrations: Liban. epist. 1350 ἐγὼ δέ σε ἠξίουν, ἐΚ μέσης ἥκοντα τῆς Ἑλλάδος, γράφειν τι διαφεῦγον γὸν ὄχλον· σὺ δ’ ἔοικας ἀμελεῖν λόγων. Liban. IV 363 μὴ τοίνυν νομίζετε τὰ μὲν ἀργυρώνητα ταῦτα ἀνδράποδα, ὄντα τὸ πολλὰ ἐκ Καρίας καὶ Φρυγίας οὕτως εἶναι μεγαλοψύχους. . . τοὺς δὲ ἐΚ μέσης τῆς Ἑλλάδος. . . Lucian iud. voc. 7 (Sigma compains against Tau) κατηγόμην δὲ παρὰ κωμῳδιῶν τινι ποιητῇ, Λυσίμαχος ἐκαλεῖτο, Βοιώτιος μέν, ὡς ἐφαίνετο, τὸ γένος ἀνέκαθεν, ἀπὸ μέσης δὲ ἀξιῶν λέγεσθαι τῆς Ἀττικῆς· παρὰ τούτῳ δὴ τῷ ξένῳ. . . Macho in Ath. 578 B αἰσχρὸν γὰρ ὄνομα Φρυγιακὸν γυναῖκ᾿ ἔχειν, | καὶ ταῦθ᾿ ἑταίραν ἐΚ μέσης τῆς Ἑλλάδος, | μὴ τὴν Ἀθηναίων γε κωλῦσαι πόλιν, | ὑφ᾿ ἧς ἅπαντές εἰσ᾿ ἐπηνορθωμένοι. Philostratus vit. soph. 2. I. 14 τὴν δὲ δὴ γλῶτταν, ἔφη ὁ Ἡρώδης, πῶς ἐπαιδεύθης καὶ ὑπὸ τίνων; οὐ γάρ μοι τῶν ἀπαιδεύτων φαίνῃ· καὶ Ἀγαθίων, ἡ μεσογεία, ἔφη, τῆς Ἀττικῆς ἀγαθὸν διδασκαλεῖον ἀνδρὶ βουλομένῳ διαλέγεσθαι· οἱ μὲν γὰρ ἐν τῷ ἄστει Ἀθηναῖοι, μισθοῦ δεχόμενοι Θρᾴκια Καὶ Ποντικὰ μειράκια καὶ ἐξ ἄλλων ἐθνῶν βαρβάρων ξυνερρυνκότα, παραφθείρονται ἆρ’ αὐτῶν τὴν φωνὴν μᾶλλον ἢ ξυμβάλλονταί τι αὐτοῖς ἐς εὐγλωττίαν· ἡ μεσογεία δὲ ἄμικτος βαρβάροις οὖσα, ὑγιαίνει αὐτοῖς ἡ φωνὴ καὶ ἡ γλῶττα τὴν ἄκραν Ἀτθίδα ἀποψάλλει. —For ὡς ἂν see on fr. 816.

lg.l: τηροῦντα τοὺς λέγοντας καὶ συνάγοντα τὰς ὀφρῦς Καὶ

div.p: 1121 Eustath. Od. p. 1538, 13 τοξοποιεῖ γοῦν τὰς ὀφρῦς καὶ δεσμεῖ καὶ συνάγει ὁ σκυθρωπάζων. λέγει δέ που Καὶ Σοφοκλῆς τὸ ῾τηροῦντα. . . ἐπεγείροντα,᾿ εἰπὼν τοῦτο ἐκεῖνος ὡς ἀπὸ ἰχθύων, οἱ τὰς ἀκάνθας ὀρθοῦσι καιρῷ θυμοῦ.

Brunck suspected Eustathius of a lapse of memory, and suggested Aristophanes as possibly the author of the words quoted. Subsequent editors agree with him, and no other conclusion seems possible. But the slip was probably made by his authority rather than by Eustathius himself. — There are many synonyms for σκυθρωπάζειν, such as ἀνάγειν, αἴρειν, ἀνασπᾶν τὰς ὀφρῦς. For τοξοποιεῖν, which has been comp with our to arch the eyebrows, cf. Ar. Lys. 7 μὴ σκυθρώπας᾿ ὦ τέκνον· | οὐ γὰρ πρέπει σοι τοξοποιεῖν τὰς ὀφρῦς (Blaydes). ὀφρῦς συνάγειν occurs in Ar. Nub. 582 ‘when you elected Cleon’) τὰς συνήγομεν, Plut. 756 ὀφρῦς ξυνήγον ἐσκυθρώπαζόν δ’ ἅμα, fr. 579 (l 539 K.), and often elsewhere. Plut. def. or. 6 p. 412 F has ταῦτα συντείνει καὶ συνίστησι τὸ πρόσωπον: see on fr. 902. — The comic metaphor of τὰς ἀκάνθας ἀπεγείρειν is a tour de force, and does not occur elsewhere. — To recast the words quoted in metrical form seems hopeless.
1122 Athen. 68 A τ[ο δὲ ῥῆμα (i.e. the verb: he has been quoting instances of the noun ἄπτυμα) κεῖται παρὰ σοφοκλεῖ ῾ἐγὼ...σοφῶς᾿

Examples from Cratinus and Eupolis follow: amongst those of the noun which precede is fr. 675. ῾Valckenaer conjectured that the words παρὰ Σοφοκλεῖ were a mistake for παρὰ Σωφίλῳ ἐν Ἀνδροκλεῖ, a play from which Athenaeus quotes elsewhere (123 E, 228 B); and Meineke (Com. 111 584) agreed (though he thinks ἐν Ἀνδροκλεῖ unnecesary), remarking “Videntur autem illa ne satyricae quidem fabulae convenire.” Brunck too, Nauck, and Kock (111 624) are all of opinion that the words come from a comedy. The later comedy is full of cooks, and when a man sees μάγειρος ἀρτύσω in an iambic line quoted by Athenaeus, he is predisposed to suspicion that the source of it was comedy. But there are certain considerations to give us pause: (1) why should Athenaeus go so far afield as to quote Sophilus for an example of ἀρτύω? But if the word occurred with the culinary sensein Sophocles, it was another matter, parallel to the citation of ἀρτύματα, which we know to be correct; and in fact it appears that Athenaeus was seeking for the earliest occurrences of the verb. (2) The line cannot have been spoken by a cook, but must have come from some one who was comparing himself to one: render, “I'll be the cook | To dress this rarely.” If the meanig were “I, the cook,” we must have had ἐγὼ ὁ μάγειρος; and, if spoken by a man who, though not a cook, was about to act as one, the collocation ἐγὼ μάγειρος is out of place. So soon as μάγειρος is added, the cookery becomes only metaphorical. This may be illustrated by Alexis fr. 110, 18 ff. (11 335 K.), where the supposed situation actually occurs, but ἐγὼ μάγειρος is avoided: τούτοιςμάγειρος οὐπρόσεις᾿, οὐκ ὄψεται— οἰμώξεται γὰρ νὴ Δι᾿—ἀλλ᾿ ἐγὼ σοφῶς ταῦτ᾿ οἰκονομήσω καὶ γλαφυρῶς καὶ ποικίλως | οὔτω—ποιῶ γὰρ τοὔψον αὐτό— ὤστε τοὺς | δειπνοῦντας εἰς τὰ λοπάδι᾿ ἐμβάλλειν (l. ἐκβ.) ποιῶ | ἐνίοτε τοὺς ὀδόντας ὑπὸ τῆς ἡδονῆς. This point of Greek has not been observed, e.g. by Ellendt, who, accpting the words as written by Sophocles, ascribes them to the Phaeacians, and argues that it was a satyric play.᾿ (H.) We have thus an examle of the idiom which has been illustrated on fr. 800. See also Blaydes on Ar. Plut. 295 τράγοι δ᾿ ἀκρατιεῖσθε. Among Shorey's examplesare Theogn. 347 ἐγὼ δὲ κύων ἐπέπησα χαράδην, Cephisodor. fr. 1 ἐγὼ δὲ τοῖς λόγοις ὄνος ὔομαι. It must however be admitted, even after H.'s explanation, that the occurrence of this metaphor in a tragedy—or even in a satyr-play—would be remarkable enough; and I have left the fragment among the spuria, where it was placedby Nauck.
1123 Photius lex. p. 148, 6 κατεύχεσθαι· τὸ καταρᾶσθαι. οὔτως Πλάτων. κατεύχεσθαι τῶν Ἀχαιῶν· ἀντὶ τοῦ κατὰ τῶν Ἀχαιῶν εὔχεσθαι῾ οὔτως Σοφοκλῆς.

It is fairly certain that the second lemma of Photius refers to Plat. rep. 393 A ‘Do you know the beginning of the Iliand,’ ἐν οἷς ὁ ποιητής φησι τὸν μὲν χρύσην δεῖσθαι τοῦ Ἀγαμέμνονος ἀπολῦσαι τὴν θυγάτερα, τὸν δὲ χαλεπαίνειν, τὸν δέ, ἐπειδὴ οὐκ ἐτύγχανε, κατεύχεσθαι τῶν Ἀχαιῶν πρὸς τὸν θεόν; Nauck concludes that οὔτως Πλάτων and οὔτως Σοφοκλῆς have changed places; and the alusion to Sophocles is made plain by Suid.: κατεύ- χεσθαι· τὸ καταρᾶσθαι. οὔτω Πλάτων. καὶ Σοφοκλῆς (O.T. 246)· κατεύχομαι δὲ τὸν δεδρακότα τάδε (δεδρακότ᾿ εἴτε τις Soph.). ἀντὶ τοῦ καταρῶμαι. καὶ Αἰλιανός κτἑ. In Suidas the quotation from Plato has dropped out, just as that from Sophocles has been lost in Photius. I think, therefore, that κατεύχεσθαι τῶν Ἀχαιῶν was not a separate lemma in Photius, but represented the quoation from Plato following his name with the explannation ἀντὶ τοῦ...εὔχεσθαι, just as in Suidas the explanation ἀντὶ τοῦ καταρῶμαι follows the line from the O.T.
1124 Etym. M. p. 254, 53 δελήτιον· τὸ δέλεαp. Σοφοκλῆς ῾ἔχε τὸ δελήτιον.᾿ ἢ Σώφρων (fr. 118 K.).
All critics are agreed that the words ought to be attributed to Sophron rather than to Sophocles.

1125 Etym. M. p. 207, 16 Βουθοίη (βούθιο cod. Flor. ap. Miller, p. 68) τῆς Ἰλλυρίδος. Σοφοκλῆς Ὀνομακλεῖ σοφοζ ὀνο κλεῖ cod. M, σοφοκλῆς οἷον ὀνομακλεῖ cod. Flor.) ῾Βουθοίη Βουθόη cod. Flor.) . . . ἐνάσθη.᾿

The corruption is obvious, and O. Schneider (Callim. Ii p. 637) proposed Σοφοκλῇς Οἰνομάῳ (so Gataker before him). Καλλίμαχος ῾Βουθόῃ ἥ᾿ κτἑ. Casaubon conjectured Σοφοκλῆς ἐν Ἡρακλεῖ. Schneider was probably right in recognizing an Alexandrian fragment; but Οἰνομάῳ is unlikely, and Σοφοκλῆς may be a mere blunder. Reitzenstein, Gesch. d. Etym. p. 328, adopting a conjecture of Schwartz, restores the text (Etym. gen.) thus: Σοφοκλῆς οἷον . . . ῾οὔνομα κλειτῇ | Βουθοίῃ᾿ κτἑ, The source was then the note of Sophocles on Ap. Rh. 4. 516. Buthoe was a town in Illyria said to have been founded by Cadmus, which received its name because he travelled from Thebes ἐπὶ βοῶν ζεύγους ταχέως (Etym. M. p. 207, 12). Euripides, though he does not mention Buthoe, was familiar with the ox-waggon : see Bacch. 1333 f. ὄχον δὲ μόσχων, χρησμὸς ὡς λέγει Διός, | ἐλᾷς μετ᾿ ἀλόχου, βαρβάρων ἡγούμενος. It is possible therefore that Sophocles referred to the legend, in the Niobe or elsewhere. Steph. Byz. p. 180 19 (Herodian I 306, 5), gives the alternative derivation from the Egyptian Buto, which is less clearly indicated in Etym. M. The Roman name was Buttia (Pauly- Wissowa III 1092).

lg.l: εἷς ταῖς ἀληθείαισιν, εἷς ἐστὶν θεός,
69 οὐρανόν τ᾿ ἔτευξε καὶ γαῖαν μακρὰν
πόντου τε χαροπὸν οἶδμα κἀνέμων βίας.
θεῶν ἀγάλματ᾿ ἐκ λίθων ἢ χαλκέων

div.note: 1126. 6 ἢ χαλκέων Clem., Euseb., Theod., lust, mon., Cyr. cod. Neap.: τε καὶ ξύλων lust, coh., Cedr.: καὶ ξύλων MaL, anecd. Par.
div.p: 1126 Clem. Alex, strom. 5. 1 4, p. 7 1 7 (Euseb. praep. ev. 13 p. 680 D, Theodoret. therap. 7 p. 109, 36) ὁ μὲν γὰρ Σοφοκλῆς, ὥς φησιν Ἑκαταῖος ὁ τὰς ἱστορίας συνταξάμενος ἐν τῷ κατ᾿ Ἄβραμον τοὺς Αἰγυπτίους ἄντικρυς ἐπὶ τῆς σκηνῆς ἐκροᾷ ῾εἷς ταῖς. . . νομίζομεν.᾿ These verses are quoted by a series of Christian writers. of whom the earliest is Justin Martyr (c. 150A.D.) coh. ad gent. 18, de monarch. 2 p. 136. Clement of Alexandria (c. 200 A.D.) quotes them again in protrept. p. 63 and hence they passed on to Eusebius (c. 320 A.D.), to Cyril of Alexandria (contr. lul. I p. 32 A [c. 420 A.D.]), to Theodoret (c. 450 A.D.) and to George

lg.l: θυσίας τε τούτοις καὶ κενὰς πανηγύρεις

div.note: 7 τύπων anecd. Par. 9 νέμοντες Clem. p. 63: τεύχοντες lust., Cyr.,Cedr., Mal., anced. Par.
div.p: Cedrenus I p. 82, [c. 1100 A.D.] ). Vitelli (ap. Nauck) reports that they also occur in a Naples codex II F 9 fol. 140 v. Verses 1 and 2 are found in Athenag. suppl. pro Christ. 5 (c. 130 A. D.), where however they are supposed to be an interpolation.

The context is of a different character in John Malalas p. 40 ed. Bonn (c. 565 A.D.) ὁ γὰρ σοφώτατος Σοφοκλῆς δρᾶμα ἐξέθετο καὶ ποιητικῶς εἶπεν ὅτι τὴν Παλλάδα εἶδε λουομένην Καὶ γυνὴ ἐγένετο. ὁ Τειρεσίας, φησί, τὴν σοφίαν τοῦ δημιουργοῦ ἐξήτησε γνῶναι καὶ οὐΚ ἐδυνήθη· ὅθεν ἐξέθετο ὁ αὐτὸς Σοφοκλῆς ἐν τοῖς αὐτοῦ συγγράμμασι ταῦτα ἀληθείας εἶναι· εἶς ἔστιν ὁ θεός, ὃς τὸν οὐρανὸν ῾ἔτευξε καὶ γαῖαν μακράν . . . νομίζομεν.᾿ μοναρχίαν γὰρ ἐδόκει δοξάζειν ὁ αὐτὸς Σοφοκλῆς. With the first part of this extract Nauck compares Cramer, anecd. Paris. II Ρ. 259, 4 κατὰ τούτους τοὺς χρόνους Κάδμος ὁ ἐν θήβαις ἐβασίλευσεν, ὃς Τειρεσίαν φιλόσοφον καὶ μάντιν ἐν θήβαις Με, περὶ οὗ φησὶ Σοφοκλῆς ὅτι τὴν Παλλάδα ἰδὼν λουομένην ὁ Τειρεσίας μετεβλήθη ἐξ ἀνδρὸς εἰς γυναικείαν φύσιν. Cramer's publication was actually the editio princeps of the first part of the chronicle of Leo grammaticus (c. 1013 A.D.), which is said to be derived from the lost work of Sextus lulius Africanus (c. 221 A.D.) of Alexandria, the earliest of the series of world-chronicles : see Krumbacher, p. 134. It is obvious that the two passages go back to the same original. The statement about Tiresias does not necessarily stand on the same footing as the verses quoted above. It is in fact a conflation of two stories con- cerning the Theban seer both of which are old, (1) that he saw Athena bathing and was in consequence blinded by her (Pherecydes fr. 50 [FHG 185] = Apollod. 3. 70, Callim. lau. Pall. 75 ff.) ; (2) that, happening to see the union of two snakes, he wounded one of them and was changed to a woman, and that subsequently, on a repetition of the same occurrence, he recovered his original sex (Apollod. 3. 71 Hesiod. fr. 162 Rz., Phlegon mir. 4). Prima facie, there would be nothing surprising in Sophocles having made use of either of these legends; but the fact of their confusion, and the suspicious character of the sources from which our information is derived, are enough to warrant a suspension of judgement.

To return to the fragment itself, it will be observed that Clement professes to rely on the authority of Hecataeus in his book relating to ‘Abraham and the Egyptians.’ Boeckh (Tr. Gr. princ. p. held that this ‘Hecataeus’ was a forged document, by means of which spurious verses were attributed to the classic poets, and Susemihl ( Gesch. d. gr. Lit. Alexandr. I p. 312 16) is of the same opinion. The latter points out that Hecataeus of Abdera (c. 300 B.C.) wrote a treatise Αἰγυπτιακά with romantic tendency, which contained an episode on Jewish history. This latter was undoubtedly used by Diodorus, but there is considerable difference of opinion as to whether the quotations made by Josephus from Hecataeus πρτὶ Ἰουδαίων were taken from the Αἰγυπτιακά, or from a Judaizer who assumed the name of Hecataeus. (Jacoby in Pauly-Wissowa VII 2765 ff. However this may be, there is no doubt that the treatise Κατ’ Ἄβραμον καὶ τοὺς Αἰγυπτίους used by Clement, which was cited also by Josephus (ant. Jud. 1. 158) as the περὶ Ἀβράμου, was the work of a forger, whose object it was to represent the Jews as the original possessors of all true wisdom, and as the instructors of other nations. For such a purpose the utility of fabricated quotations is obvious.

J. writes: ‘Bentley pointed out the general state of the facts in his Letter to Mill (ed. Dyce, vol. 11 p. 256 ff.), published in Mill's edition of the Chronicle of John Malalas...On the internal evidence of spuriousness Bentley makes a few remarks, one of which is just and forcible, — viz. that an Attic poet, at the Dionysia, would not have denounced Greek festivals (vv. 8, 9). But Bentley's verbal remarks are here less happy, (1) In v. 4 he gives πολλόν, and denies its use to tragedy (though Soph, has πολλόν as adv. in a trimeter, Ant. 86, and as ace. sing. masc. in Trach. 1196). A
better reading πολλοί is, however, now established. (2) In v. 6 he objects to χαλκέων, saying that it should be χαλκῶν. But Soph, has λέβητι χαλκέῳ in Track. 556, and χρυσέων in Trach. 1099.

‘On the other hand, Bentley passes over a real mark of late date, viz. the plural ταῖς ἀληθείαισιν (= τῇ ἀληθείᾳ) in v. 1. This adverbial use occurs in Philemon fr. 130 (II 519 K.) εἰ ταῖς ἀληθείαισιν οἱ τεθνηκότες | αἴσθησιν εἶχον. In later Greek it is frequent (Polyb. 10. 40. 5 καὶ λέγεσθαι. . . καὶ ταῖς ἀληθείαις ὑπάρχειν). The earliest example is Isocr. 15. 283 (353 B.C.) καὶ ταῦτα καὶ ταῖς ἀληθείαις οὕτως ἔχει (“in respect to the of the case.” So Rutherford on 75. 19 ought not to say that the instance in Philemon is probably the earliest). The plural of abstract nouns was often used from the fourth century onwards: see my n. on Isocr. l.c. (Selections, p. 257).’ Bernays, who discussed the fr. in his treatise on pseudo-Phocylides p. 36, calls it ‘a capuchin's sermon against paganism. ’ There is not the slightest doubt that these verses are an impudent forgery, being probably, as we have seen, the work of an Alexandrian Jew. The late use of χαροπός (v. 3) is more remarkable than that of ταῖς ἀληθείαισιν, and the leading idea of the last six lines, — not to speak of difficulties in detail which need not be discussed here — the turning to idols of stone and trusting to them for support in time of sorrow, reads like a Hellenized paraphrase from a Hebrew prophet of the Old Testament. I should be content to rest the case on καρδίᾳ πλανώμενοι (v. 4) alone, which ought to be decisive to anyone bearing in mind Psalm 95. 10 τεσσαράκοντα ἔτη προσώχθισα τῇ γενεᾷ ἐκείνῃ, καὶ εἶπα, ἀεὶ πλανῶνται τῇ καρδίᾳ, καὶ αὐτοὶ οὐκ ἔγνωσαν τὰς ὁδούς μου. The difference is instructive; for a Greek would have said γνώμῃ, φρεσί, or διανοίᾳ πλανᾶσθαι.

It should be added that it did not seem worth while to record all the variants, for the most part unimportant, which occur in the citation of the lines by the several authorities mentioned above: those who wish for the information will find it in Nauck.

lg.l: τὴν τοῦδε γάρ τοι Ζεὺς ἔγημε μητέρα

div.p: 1127. 5 νυμφικοῖς: μοιχιΚοῖς vel μυθικοῖς Euseb. | ἐπεστάθη vel ἐπεστάτει Eus. ἐπεσχάλη Clem.

1127 Clem. Alex, strom. 5. 14 p. 716 (recurring in Euseb. praep. ev. 13 p. 680 a) ὁ Σοφοκλῆς δὲ εὐθυρρημόνως γράφει ῾τὴν τοῦδε . . . ἀνήρ᾿ (vv. 1 — 4). εἶτα ὑπελθὼν Καὶ δὴ ἐπήγαγεν ῾ταχὺς. . . ὁ μοιχός᾿ (vv. 5, 6). ἐφ᾿ οἶς ἔτι φανερώτερον τὴν ἀκρασίαν τοῦ μυθοποιουμένου Διὸς ὧδέ πως εκδιηγεῖται ῾ὅ δ᾿ ἐθρύπτετο᾿ (vv. 7 — 9). Nauck thinks that v. 4 is referred to by Hesych. III p. 199 ὁλο- σχερής. . . τέλειος, ὁλόκληρος: but that is very doubtful.

Person on Eur. Med. 284 held that these lines came from a satyr-play on the following grounds: (1) ἐπημφιεσμένος violates the rule that ἀμφί like περί is not used in tragic senarii when compounded with a verb or noun beginning with a vowel: contrast Eur. Cycl. 686 (2) πτίλον, ὑπημβρύωσεν, ὁλοσχερής, and ἐθόρνυτο are not admissible in tragedy. L. Dindorf, in Steph. Thes. s.u. βαθμός p. 21 c, expresses surprise that he should have thought them admissible even in a satyr-play, and pronounces the fragment to be spurious,

lg.l: ὅ δ᾿ οὔτε δαιτὸς οὔτε χέρνιβος θιγὼν

div.note: 7 οὐδὲ χέρνιβος θίβων Clem. ὠχεύετο: ἐθρύπτετο Clem. 9 ἐθύρνυτο Eus., cf. Hesych. II p. 22 ἐθόρνυτο·
div.p: adding that we ought to be on our guard against all citations which rest solely upon the authority of the Fathers.

Jebb, on the other hand, regarded it as genuine. Mentioning the words condemned by Porson, he remarks: ῾Now ἠμφιεσμένος is used by Hipponax fr. 3 Ar. Eccl. 879, Lysias and Plato: it might surely then occur in tragedy. But as to the other words, the objection seems sound. Indeed the whole tenor of the verses suits a ’ Thus, he tacitly denies the truth of what Porson is arguing about the unelided ἀμφί: its validity as a universal rule he had contested in the Appendix on Ο.Τ. 1505.

Headlani appears to have been in agreement with Dindorf: he calls attention to the use of ὁλοσχερής, which is used in verse for the first time by Theocr. 35. 210. The adv. is a discredited variant in Isocr. 5. 135, but is cited from Diphilus (fr. 27, II 548 K.) by Aiitiati. (Bekk. anecd.) p. no, 18. The adjective appears first in Hippocrates, and then in Dioscorides, but is chiefly known from its use by Polybius. ὑπεμβρυόω occurs only here, and ἐμβρυόω not at all: it is the sort of word, H. remarks, which one would expect to find in Theophrastus. The most noticeable feature of the lines is what he calls the ‘virulence of the style’; seem to breathe the spirit of a hostile fanaticism, intent only on exposing the moral corruption of Paganism. Now Is that we are able to contrast them with the description of a similar incident in the satyric Ichmutae (fr. 314, 261 ff.), the difference in tone is startling enough. On the other hand, there is nothing in the language which is demonstrably unclassical, nor would it be possible to refute anyone who should maintain that the context in Sophocles may have been of such a character as to justify the remarkable bitterness of the language. It should be added that, though the immediate context of the quotation is not suspicious, it is found in te same collection with others which are undoubted forgeries.

It is suggested that τοῦδε in v. 1 is Heracles, and that the language of vv. 4 and 7 is suitable to the visit of Zeus in the guise of the newly-arrived Amphitryon, while V. 8 recalls τὴν μίαν τριπλασιάσας νύκτα of Apollod. 2. 61 and the other authorities.
