For the Amphitryon of Sophocles see I p. 76. Brunck and Hartung, who also thought that the subject was the procreation of Heracles, referred the fragment to the satyric Heracles at Taenarum.
2 χρυσόμορφος, referring to the story of Danae: cf. Lycophr. 838, where Perseus is called τὸν χρυσόπατρον μόρφνον.

3 πτίλον is rare even in comedy: Starkie on Ar. Ach. 585. — κόρην Πλευρωνίαν, ‘Leda, daughter of Thestius, king of Aetolia. According to Pherecydes (FHG 178) Leda's mother was a daughter of Pleuron: schol. on Apoll. Rhod. i 146 Αἰτωλὶς Λήδη), who says also Ἴβυκος (fr. 41) Πλευρωνίαν αὐτὴν καλεῖ (cf. Roscher II 1922).’ (J.)
5 βαθμοῖς νυμφικοῖς, ‘the steps leading to the chamber of the νύμφη. — ἐπεστάθη = ἐπέστη (as oft. in poetry).’ (J.)
8 ὠδαγμένος, ‘stung’ with desire : from ὀδάξω. (Cf. Jebb on Trach. 770 ἀδαγμός.) For the metaphor see on fr. 841.

9 ἐθόρνυτο ‘= ἔθρῳσκε, in sexual sense. Her. 3. 109 ἐπεὰν θορνύωνται (when they procreate). Nicander Ther. θορνυμένου ἔχιος (in same sense). As Porson says (Med. 284), the v.l. ἐθρύπτετο in Clement was doubtless a gloss.’ (J.)

lg.l: ἔσται γὰρ ἔσται κεῖνος αἰῶνος χρόνος
χρυσωπὸς αἰθήρ· ἡ δὲ βοσκηθεῖσα φλὸξ
φλέξει μανεῖσ᾿. ἐπὴν γὰρ ἐκτείνῃ τὸ πᾶν,

div.p: 1128. 1 ἔσται καινὸς Clem. 5 ἐπὴν scripsi: ἐπὰν Clem. Eus., ὅταν Iust. γὰρ ἐκτείνῃ scripsi: δ᾿ ἐκλίπῃ vel δ᾿ ἐκλείπῃ Iust. et Eus. codd., δ᾿ ἐκλείπῃ Clem., ἄρ᾿ metri causa add. Grotius

1128 Justin Martyr de vionarch. 3 p. 136 καὶ περὶ τοῦδε ὅτι μόνος δυνατός ἐστι καὶ τῶν ἐν τῷ βίῳ συντελουμένων πράξεων καὶ τῆς περὶ τὸ θεῖον ἀγνωσίας κρίσιν ἐνστήσασθαι, οἰκείους μάρτυρας παραστῆσαι ἔχω, καὶ πρῶτόν γε Σοφοκλέα καὶ περὶ τούτου λέγοντα ῾ἔσται γὰρ... ἀπώλεσεν.᾿ Clem. Alex. strom. 5. 14 p. 722 (Euseb. praep. ev. 13 p. 684 B) συνᾴδει δὲ τούτοις καὶ ἡ τραγῳδία διὰ τῶνδε ῾ἔσται γὰρ...μανεῖσα.᾿ καὶ μετ᾿ ὀλίγα αὖθις ἐπιφέρει ῾ἐπὰν...ἀπώλεσε.᾿

These verses describe the Stoic ἐκπύρωσις, and therefore cannot have been written by Sophocles. They are, however, of no little intrinsic interest, and must have been composed by a Stoic, or at least by some one who was accurately informed respecting the tenets of that system. A knowledge of Stoic principles was widely spread from the third century B.C. onwards; the purpose of the lines appears to be didactic rather than controversial; and the language bears no marks of a late origin. If we proceed to enquire for an author likely to have versified Stoic doctrine, it is natural to think of Cleanthes ; and so far as contents and style are concerned there is no reason why he should not have written them. Indeed, the opening phrases are directly suggestive of his teaching, as will be shown below. But it is necessary to bear in mind that the extract comes from a suspicious source. Together with many genuine quotations Clement has included a number of unmistakable forgeries (Aesch. fr. 464; Eur. fr. 1030, 1031; Menand. fr. 1130; Philem. fr. 246; Diphil. fr. 138), which are also to be found in the de 7nonarchia attributed to Justin Martyr. These are not to be assigned to the Christian apologists themselves, but were derived by them from such writings as those of pseudo-Hecataeus (fr. 1126n., Susemihl II pp. 63258 645); and, inasmuch as Clement twice quotes from Cleanthes (I 557, 560 Arn., frs. 75, 101 P.) in the same chapter, we should have expected to find his name attached also to the present passage, if it was actually composed by him.

‘The primitive substance (Pneuma) was determined by Chrysippus, following Zeno, to be fiery breath or αἰθήρ, a spiritualized sublimed element. This primitive substance is also the creative force, or deity, which shapes the cosmos, or universal order. Out of it the elements which we know are separated off; first, fire (as we know it); then, air or vapour (condensed fire); then water and earth, which are solidified air. But, after these elements have been separated, there remains a residue of the Pneuma or primitive substance. This residue is the αἰθήρ, in the highest sphere of the visible heavens, encircling the world, of which it is lord and head.

‘The cosmos does not remain in one state eternally, but passes through cycles of decay, destruction, and renewal. The individual things in the cosmos will be gradually resolved back into the elements, and the elements into the primary substance or Pneuma, the αἰθήρ. The end of this process will be a general conflagration, when once more the world will be absorbed into the deity (Pneuma, αἰθήρ). "Then in due order a new cycle of development begins, reproducing the last in the minutest detail, and so on for ever." (R. D. Hicks in Encycl. Brit.9 XII at p. 564),’ (J.) For the Stoic texts bearing on the ἐκπύρωσις see von Arnim Stoic. vet. fragm. II p. 183 ff., and for the important fragment of Cleanthes ibid. I 497 p. 111 ( = fr. 24 P.).

lg.l: φροῦδος μὲν ἔσται κυμάτων ἅπας βυθός,
γῆ δ᾿ ἑδράνων ἔρημος, οὐδ᾿ ἀὴρ ἔτι
κἄπειτα σώσει πάνθ᾿ ἃ πρόσθ᾿ ἀπώλεσεν.

div.note: 7 γῆ δ᾿ ἑδράνων (γῆ δὲ ἀνδρῶν F) lust.: γῆ δὲ ἐδραν ὧν (sic) Clem., γῆ δὲ Ens., γῆ δενδρέων Grotius, γῆ δ’ ἀνέρων Coningtoii | οὐδ’ ἀὴρ ἔτι Grotius: οὐδ᾿ ἄρ᾿ ἔτι lust., οὐδὲ ἄρ᾿ ἔτι Eus., οὐ γὰρ ἐπὶ Clem. 8 βαστάσει lust.: βλαστάσει Clem., βλαστήσει Eus. | πυρούμενος Grotius. Post hunc v. ponit lust, καὶ γὰρ καθ᾿ Ἅιδην δύο τρίβους νομίζομεν, | μίαν δικαίων χἁτέραν ἀδίκων ὁδόν, quae Diphilo alibi vel Philemoni (fr. 245, 11 539 K.) tribuuntur
div.p: J. renders thus: ‘The day shall come, in the course of ages, when the golden ether shall release its teeming store of fire, and the flame, long fed within, shall kindle in its fury all things on the earth and in the sky. And when that conflagration has wholly ceased (ἐπὰν δ᾿ ἐκλίπῃ τὸ πᾶν: or “when the universe has ceased ”), the sea with all its depths will have vanished, and the earth will be void of habitations [see, however, below]; and the air, full of fire, will no longer carry the winged tribes. And then the deity will restore all that he has destroyed.’

1 ff. ἔσται. . . ὅταν. This construction with a characterizing subordinate clause, as distinguished from a clause of general assumption, is not provided for by the ordinary grammars : see W. G. Hale, Anticipatory Subjunctive (Chicago Studies in Classical Philology I [1895], p. 19. It is obviously modelled on the pattern of Hom. Z 448 ἔσσεται ἦμαρ, ὅτ᾿ ἄν ποτ’ ὀλώλῃ Ἴλιος ἱρή. I have briefly called attention to certain Attic anomalies of this kind in C. R. XVII 249, but the subject is one which deserves fuller treatment. For the present I will only point out that Aesch. Ag. 1317 is not essentially distinct from Hom. X 358 although grammarians analyse them differently. The example in the text may be profitably compared with Isocr. 4. 138 ἦ που σφόδρα χρἠ δεδιέναι τὸν καιρὸν ἐκεῖνον, ὅταν τὰ μὲν τῶν βαρβάρων καταστῇ. . . ἡμεῖς δὲ πρὸς ἀλλήλους ὥσπερ νῦν πολεμικῶς ἔχωμεν. — πυρός κτἑ. For the predominance of αἰθήρ at the ἐκπύρωσις cf. Dio Chrys. 40. 37 (11 p. 177 R.) ἡ λεγομένη παρὰ τοῖς σοφοῖς ἐπικράτησις αἰθέρος. Ar. Did. fr. 36 (Diels, Doxogr. p. 468) ἐξαιθεροῦσθαι πάντα κατὰ περιόδους τινὰς τὰς μεγίστας εἰς πῦρ αἰθερῶδες ἀναλυομένων πάντων. Plut. comm. not. 36 p. 1077 D ὅταν οὖν ἔκπύρωσις γένηται, μόνον ἄφθαρτον ὅντα τὸν Δία τῶν θεῶν ἀναχωρεῖν ἐπὶ τὴν πρόνοιαν, εἶθ᾿ ὁμοῦ γενομένους ἐπὶ μιᾶς τῆς τοῦ αἰθέρος οὐσίας διατελεῖν ἀμφοτέρους. The language of the present passage points to the ἐκπύρωσις of Cleanthes and his successors in the following particulars: (1) ‘The store of fire accumulated in the αἰθήρ must come from the heavenly bodies. The sun is pure fire, the stars of fiery nature. The heavenly sphere itself, or fiery zone surrounding the world, is called αἰθήρ: totum hoc caelum quod igneus aether, mundi summa pars, claudit, Senec. nat. quaest. 6. 16. 2. Now Cleanthes supposed that the conflagration originated by the sun absorbing the moon and stars: Plut. comm. not. 31 p. 1075 D (l 510 Arn., fr. 25 Ρ.). φλόξ, it may be noticed, was the term employed by Cleanthes for the fire in which all things are consumed: Philo incorr. mund. 18 p. 254, 7 Bern. (1 511 Arn., fr. 23 P.) μεταβάλλειν δὲ ἢ εἰς φλόγα ἢ εἰς αὐγὴν ἀναγκαῖον· εἰς μὲν φλόγα, ὡς ᾤετο Κλεάνθης, εἰς δ’ αὐγήν, ὡς ὁ Χρύσιππος. Conformably with this we find ἐκφλογισθέντος τοῦ πάντος in another extract from Cleanthes: Stob. ecl. I 17. 3 p. 153, 7 (I 497 Arn., fr. 24 P.). But in verse no stress can be laid on a word which it would be most natural to use, even without any reference to Cleanthes.’ R. D. (communicated to J.). (2) The description is consistent with the τόνος doctrine which, though not exclusively Cleanthean, is believed to have been first formulated by him. When the world is moving towards ἐΚπύρωσις. there is a constant progress from the apparent ἰσονομία — the equilibrium of the warring forces — to the ἐκικράτησις θεοῦ (Philo de anim. sacrif. idon. 6 11 p. 242 Μ.). This is due to the increase of tension caused by the everawaxing force of the fiery element collected in the periphery (ἄνω φησὶν αὔξεσθαι).
At length the sun and stars discharge their teeming store throughout the cosmos, and the equilibrium is upset by a vast expansion οf the compressed matter οf which the world as we know it was compact. I have partly discussed this subject in Fragments οf Zeno and Cleanthes, p. 252 Ιf.: but the details cannot be made good here. See also E. V. Arnold, Roman Stoicism, p. 196.—For σχάσῃ see n. on Eur. Phoen. 454.

5 ἐπήν: see cr. n. That ἐπήν rather than ἐπάν was employed by the older Attic writers seems to be established by the MS evidence applying to Ar. Αν. 1355, Lys. 1175 (neither of which passages is paratragoedic), Isocr. 5. 38. In Thuc. ἐπήν occurs three times in treaties. Modern editors follow Hermann in restoring ἐπήν against the tradition in Eur. Her. 1364. On the other hand Alexis fr. 16 (III 303 K.), as recorded, has ἐπάν. ῾ἤν and ἐπήν are foreign to all Attic inscriptions. ἐπάν occurs first in the third century (265 B.C.).’ Weir Smyth, Ionic Dial., p. 609 (cf. p. 71). Meisterhans, p. 252, agrees that ἐπήν was Ionic. It is clear that the tendency of the tradition is for ἐπήν to give way to the later ἐπήν, nd here as in Eur. it is reasonable to prefer ἐπήν.—γὰρ ἐκτείνῃ: see cr. n. γάρ is occasionally ousted by δέ in our MSS (e.g. Xen. Symp. 4. 19), but the converse is far more common (fr. 873 n.). It will be seen that J. gives alternative renderings of the vulgate; but it appears that he preferred to make φλόξ the subject, as he remarks that on the other view the following clauses become somewhat tame. I think there is a much stronger reason against taking τὸ πᾶν as nominative, viz. that in the mouth of a Stoic τὸ πᾶν included the κενὸν ἄπειρον (Aët. plac. 2. 1. 7, Sext. math. 9. 332, Plut. comm. not. 30 p. 1073 E), and the phrase τὸ πᾶν ἐκλείψει would be absurd. It is true that τὸ πᾶν is often used loosely; but, because e.g. τὸ πᾶν ἐκφλογισθήσεται is intelligible, it does not follow that τὸ πᾶν ἐκλείψει could be used. The other view, that τὸ πᾶν is adverbial, is of course possible (Εl. 1009); but in that case it is surely very odd to read that, when the conflagration has entirely ceased, the air is still aflame (v. 8). Another equally vital objection to the text is that the cessation (or quenching) of the fiery process does not complete the destruction of the phenomenal world which is described in the following lines (that is rather the effect οf the ἐπικράτησις αἰθέρος), but is the first stage in the παλιγγενεσία, which begins with the creation οf the σῶμα of the new world by the operation of συστολή. This comes out most clearly in Philo incorr. mund. 19 (II 619 Arn.), which is confirmed by the various statements of Plut. Sto. rep. 41 p. 1053 B, C, Athanas. c. Arian. IV 13 p. 626, and Dio Chrys. 36. 56. These considerations condemn the otherwise attractive proposal of Heyse to alter πᾶν to πῦρ. Hence I cannot accept the ordinary text, which itself rests partly on conjecture, and propose to substitute ἐπὴν γὰρ ἐκτείνῃ, which yields a meaning consonant with Stoic principles. The phrase πῦρ ἐκτείνει τὸ πᾶν is an intelligible if illogical equivalent of πῦρ ἐκτείνεται διὰ τοῦ παντός. There was an infinite void outside the κόσμος, into which at the ἐκπύρωσις the disintegrated elements, indefinitely rarefied and extended, found room to spread. Cf. Aët. plac. 2. 4. 14 μήτε αὔξεσθαι μήτε μειοῦσθαι τὸν κόσμον, τοῖς δὲ μέρεσιν ὁτὲ μὲν παρεκτείνεσθαι πρὸς πλέονα τόπον, ὁτὲ δὲ συστέλλεσθαι. Dio Chrys. 36. 53 (of the horse of Zeus, signifying αἰθήρ), τόπον τε ὡς πλεῖστον καταλαβεῖν καὶ μείζονος χώρας δεηθῆναι τότε. Plut. comm. not. 53 p. 1077 B μετὰ τὴν ἐκπύρωσιν εἰς σπέρμα μετέβαλε τὸν κόσμον ἐκ βραχυτέρου σώματος καὶ ὄγκου χύσιν ἔχοντα πολλήν, καὶ τοῦ κενοῦ προσεπιλαμβάνοντα χώραν ἄπλετον ἐπινεμομένην τῇ αὐξήσει. Philo incorr. mund. 19 p. 507 M. (258 Bern.) ἅπαν σῶμα ἀναλυόμενον εἰς πῦρ διαλύεταί τε καὶ χεῖται, σβεννυμένης δὲ τῆς ἐν αὐτῷ φλογὸς στέλλεται καὶ συνάγεται ... καὶ μὴν ὁ κόσμος ὁ πυρωθεὶς γενήσεται μείζων, ἅτε συμπάσης τῆς οὐσίας εἰς τὸν λεπτότατον ἀναλυθείσης αἰθέρα κτἑ. Cleomed. circ. doctr. 1. 1 εἰ δὲ καὶ εἰς πῦρ ἀναλύεται ἡ πᾶσα οὐδία ... ἀνάγκη πλέον ἢ μυριοπλασίονα τόπον αὐτὴν καταλαμβάνειν.

7 γῆ δ᾿ ἑδράνων ἔρημος. These words have been most unwarrantably suspected: see cr. n. On the other hand J.'s rendering is unsatisfactory: if the only effect of the ἐκπύρωσις upon the earth is to burn down the houses, the ἐπικράτησις θεοῦ is strangely limited in its range. Surely the meaning is rather, ‘earth is reft of its supports’; the solid earth awaits its dissolution. The best description of the whole process is in Philo incorr. mund. 19, part of which has been quoted above. The capacity of extension in the compressed earth is referred to by Cleomed. circ. doctr. 1. 11 τῷ μὲν γὰρ ὄγκῳ βραχεῖά
ἐστιν ἡ γῆ, τῇ δὲ δυνάμει μεγίστη, σχεδὸν αὐτὴ τὸ πλεῖστον τῆς οὐσίας ὑπάρχουσα. εἰ γοῦν ἐπινοήσαιμεν αὐτὴν ἢ εἰς κάπνον ἢ εἰς ἀέρα πᾶσαν ἀναλυομένην, κατὰ πολὺ ἂν μείζων γένοιτο τῆς τοῦ κόσμου περιοχῆς. The significance of ἑδράνων is to be gathered from the fact that to the Stoics the earth alone of the elements was fixed and motion less in the centre of the cosmos: Achill. isag. 4 τὴν τῆς γῆς (σφαῖραν) ἑστάναι. . . καὶ τὴν γῆν δέ, πανταχόθεν ὑπὸ τοῦ ἀέρος ὡθουμένην ἰσορρόπως, ἐν τῷ μέσῳ εἶναι καὶ ἐστάναι. Cf. schol. Ar. Nub. 264 καὶ οὗτος δὲ φιλοσόμφων λόγος ὅτι οὐκ ἐφέδρασται (? ἐφηδρ-) ἡ γῆ, ἀλλ᾿ ὑπὸ τοῦ ἀέρος πάντοθεν περιέχεται, τὸν μέσον τοῦ παντὸς λαχοῦσα τόπον. Heraclit. alleg. Hom. 41 ἑδραιότατον ἀπεφήνατο στοιχεῖον εἶναι τὴν γῆν ὥσπερ ἑστίαν τινὰ τῆς τῶν ὅλων δημιουργίας. Hence they allegorized Ἑστία as γῆ, deriving her name from ἑστάναι: Cornut. 28, Plut. qu. conu. 7. 4. 6 Ρ. 704 B, prim. frig. 21 p. 954 F διαμένει τὸ γεῶδες· ὅθεν οὐ κατὰ χώραν μόνον ἐξ ἔδρας ἀκίνητον οὖσαν αὐτὴν ἀλλὰ καὶ Κατ’ οὐσίαν ἀμετάβλητον Ἑστίαν κτἑ. Cleanthes accused Aristarchus the Samian as κινοῦντα τοῦ κόσμου τὴν ἑστίαν, because he said that the earth moved round the sun (l 500 Arn., fr. 27 P.). The stability of the earth is common property: Hes. Theog. 117 πάντων ἕδος ἀσφαλὲς ἀεὶ | ἀθανάτων, Orph. h. 26. 4 ἕδρανον ἀθανάτου κόσμου.
9 σώσει. ‘The subject is αἰθήρ, which, in the Stoic doctrine, is itself the creative deity.’ (J.)

lg.l: νόσφι Διός· κεῖνος γὰρ ἔχει τέλος ἠδὲ καὶ ἀρχήν

div.p: 1129 Clem. Alex, strom. 5. 14 p. 726 (Euseb. praep. ev. 13 p. 688 A) Σοφοκλῆς δὲ ὁ τραγῳδοποιός ῾οὐδέ θεοῖσι᾿ λέγει ῾αὐθαίρετα. . . ἀρχήν.᾿

Bergk (PLG II 245 ff.) conjectures that these lines may have been taken from a paean of Sophocles. The old Ionic paean is said to have been written in hexameters, of which a trace remains in the chorus O.T. 151 ff., but those which have survived to us from a later date are in aeolic, prosodiac, or ionic metre. The chorus beginning at Trach. 205 is called by some authorities a paean to Apollo and Artemis. There is satisfactory evidence that Sophocles wrote a paean to Asclepius: see Philostr. vit. Apollon. 3. 17, Philostr. iun. imag. Ι4, Lucian, encom. Dem. 27. The younger Philostratus (imag. 14) quotes from it the epithet κλυτομήτης as applied to Asclepius.

H. writes : ‘Whether these verses were actually written by Sophocles it is natural to question, but when Nauck pronounces that recenti falsario debentur versus inanes et absurdi, that they certainly are not. Bergk says (ll p. 248) nihil inest quod antiquo poeta sit indignum, and to my ear they have all the tone of ancient hymn or epic.’

The sentiment agrees with what is found elsewhere. The gods are subject to the ordinances of fate: Eur. Ι.Τ. 1486 τὸ γὰρ χρεὼν σοῦ τε καὶ θεῶν κρατεῖ. Simonid. fr. 5, 16 ἀνάγκᾳ δ᾿ οὐδὲ θεοὶ μάχονται. Zeus alone is absolutely free and uncontrolled: Aesch. Prom. 50 ἐλεύθερος γὰρ οὔτις ἐστὶ πλὴν Διός. Suppl. 603 ὑπ᾿ ἀρχᾶς δ’ οὔτινος θοάζων | τὸ μεῖον κρεισσόνων κρατύνει; | οὔτινος ἄνωθεν Μου σέβει κάτω. His supreme excellence is shown by the exact correspondence of his will with the decrees of destiny: Pind. Nem. 4. 61 τὸ μόρσιμον Διόθεν πεπρωμένον. Thus there is no movement or action which he does not guide throughout from first to last: Theocr. 17. 1 ἐΚ Διὸς ἀρχώμεσθα καὶ ἐς Διὰ λήγετε, Μοῖσαι. Orph. h. ap. Stob. ecl. 1. 1. 23 p. 29, 10 Ζεὺς πρῶτος γένετο, Ζεὺς ὕστατος ἀργικέραυνος, | Ζεὺς κεφαλή, Ζεὺς μέσσα, Διὸς δ’ ἐκ πάντα τέτυκται.
